As long as I pass the direction to the function, I can set the new coordinates - adding or removing a <code class="language-text">y</code> will be up and down, adding or removing an <code class="language-text">x</code> will be left or right.</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="js"><pre class="language-js"><code class="language-js"><span class="token keyword">function</span> <span class="token function">movePlayer</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token parameter">playerCoords<span class="token punctuation">,</span> direction</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span> <span class="token punctuation">{</span>
  <span class="token comment">// Replace previous spot with initial board state (void or empty)</span>
  map<span class="token punctuation">[</span>playerCoords<span class="token punctuation">.</span>y<span class="token punctuation">]</span><span class="token punctuation">[</span>playerCoords<span class="token punctuation">.</span>x<span class="token punctuation">]</span> <span class="token operator">=</span> <span class="token function">isVoid</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span>levelOneMap<span class="token punctuation">[</span>playerCoords<span class="token punctuation">.</span>y<span class="token punctuation">]</span><span class="token punctuation">[</span>playerCoords<span class="token punctuation">.</span>x<span class="token punctuation">]</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span>
    <span class="token operator">?</span> <span class="token constant">VOID</span>
    <span class="token operator">:</span> <span class="token constant">EMPTY</span>

  <span class="token comment">// Move player</span>
  map<span class="token punctuation">[</span><span class="token function">getY</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span>playerCoords<span class="token punctuation">.</span>y<span class="token punctuation">,</span> direction<span class="token punctuation">,</span> <span class="token number">1</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span><span class="token punctuation">]</span><span class="token punctuation">[</span><span class="token function">getX</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span>playerCoords<span class="token punctuation">.</span>x<span class="token punctuation">,</span> direction<span class="token punctuation">,</span> <span class="token number">1</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span><span class="token punctuation">]</span> <span class="token operator">=</span> <span class="token constant">PLAYER</span>
<span class="token punctuation">}</span></code></pre></div>
<p>If the player is moving a block, I wrote a little recursive function to check how many blocks are in a row, and once it has that count, it will check what the adjacent entity is, move the block if possible, and move the player if the block moved.</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="js"><pre class="language-js"><code class="language-js"><span class="token keyword">function</span> <span class="token function">countBlocks</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token parameter">blockCount<span class="token punctuation">,</span> y<span class="token punctuation">,</span> x<span class="token punctuation">,</span> direction<span class="token punctuation">,</span> board</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span> <span class="token punctuation">{</span>
  <span class="token keyword">if</span> <span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token function">isBlock</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span>board<span class="token punctuation">[</span>y<span class="token punctuation">]</span><span class="token punctuation">[</span>x<span class="token punctuation">]</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span> <span class="token punctuation">{</span>
    blockCount<span class="token operator">++</span>
    <span class="token keyword">return</span> <span class="token function">countBlocks</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span>blockCount<span class="token punctuation">,</span> <span class="token function">getY</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span>y<span class="token punctuation">,</span> direction<span class="token punctuation">)</span><span class="token punctuation">,</span> <span class="token function">getX</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span>x<span class="token punctuation">,</span> direction<span class="token punctuation">)</span><span class="token punctuation">,</span> direction<span class="token punctuation">,</span> board<span class="token punctuation">)</span>
  <span class="token punctuation">}</span> <span class="token keyword">else</span> <span class="token punctuation">{</span>
    <span class="token keyword">return</span> blockCount
  <span class="token punctuation">}</span>
<span class="token punctuation">}</span>

<span class="token keyword">const</span> blocksInARow <span class="token operator">=</span> <span class="token function">countBlocks</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token number">1</span><span class="token punctuation">,</span> newBlockY<span class="token punctuation">,</span> newBlockX<span class="token punctuation">,</span> direction<span class="token punctuation">,</span> map<span class="token punctuation">)</span></code></pre></div>
<p>Then, if the block can be moved, it will just either move it or move it and transform it into a success block, if it's over a storage location, followed by moving the player.</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="js"><pre class="language-js"><code class="language-js">map<span class="token punctuation">[</span>newBoxY<span class="token punctuation">]</span><span class="token punctuation">[</span>newBoxX<span class="token punctuation">]</span> <span class="token operator">=</span> <span class="token function">isVoid</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span>levelOneMap<span class="token punctuation">[</span>newBoxY<span class="token punctuation">]</span><span class="token punctuation">[</span>newBoxX<span class="token punctuation">]</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span> <span class="token operator">?</span> <span class="token constant">SUCCESS_BLOCK</span> <span class="token operator">:</span> <span class="token constant">BLOCK</span>
<span class="token function">movePlayer</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span>playerCoords<span class="token punctuation">,</span> direction<span class="token punctuation">)</span></code></pre></div>
<h2 id="rendering" style="position:relative;"><a href="#rendering" aria-label="rendering permalink" class="anchor before"><svg aria-hidden="true" focusable="false" height="16" version="1.1" viewBox="0 0 16 16" width="16"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z"></path></svg></a>Rendering</h2>
<p>It's easy to keep track of the entire game in a 2D array and render the update game to the screen with each movement. The game tick is incredibly simple - any time a keydown event happens for up, down, left, right (or w, a, s, d for intense gamers) the <code class="language-text">move()</code> function will be called, which uses the player index and adjacent cell types to determine what the new, updated state of the game should be. After the change, the <code class="language-text">render()</code> function is called, which just paints the entire board with the updated state.</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="js"><pre class="language-js"><code class="language-js"><span class="token keyword">const</span> sokoban <span class="token operator">=</span> <span class="token keyword">new</span> <span class="token class-name">Sokoban</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span>
sokoban<span class="token punctuation">.</span><span class="token function">render</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span>

<span class="token comment">// re-render</span>
document<span class="token punctuation">.</span><span class="token function">addEventListener</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token string">'keydown'</span><span class="token punctuation">,</span> <span class="token parameter">event</span> <span class="token operator">=></span> <span class="token punctuation">{</span>
  <span class="token keyword">const</span> playerCoords <span class="token operator">=</span> sokoban<span class="token punctuation">.</span><span class="token function">findPlayerCoords</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span>

  <span class="token keyword">switch</span> <span class="token punctuation">(</span>event<span class="token punctuation">.</span>key<span class="token punctuation">)</span> <span class="token punctuation">{</span>
    <span class="token keyword">case</span> keys<span class="token punctuation">.</span>up<span class="token operator">:</span>
    <span class="token keyword">case</span> keys<span class="token punctuation">.</span>w<span class="token operator">:</span>
      sokoban<span class="token punctuation">.</span><span class="token function">move</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span>playerCoords<span class="token punctuation">,</span> directions<span class="token punctuation">.</span>up<span class="token punctuation">)</span>
      <span class="token keyword">break</span>
    <span class="token keyword">case</span> keys<span class="token punctuation">.</span>down<span class="token operator">:</span>
    <span class="token keyword">case</span> keys<span class="token punctuation">.</span>s<span class="token operator">:</span>
      sokoban<span class="token punctuation">.</span><span class="token function">move</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span>playerCoords<span class="token punctuation">,</span> directions<span class="token punctuation">.</span>down<span class="token punctuation">)</span>
      <span class="token keyword">break</span>
    <span class="token keyword">case</span> keys<span class="token punctuation">.</span>left<span class="token operator">:</span>
    <span class="token keyword">case</span> keys<span class="token punctuation">.</span>a<span class="token operator">:</span>
      sokoban<span class="token punctuation">.</span><span class="token function">move</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span>playerCoords<span class="token punctuation">,</span> directions<span class="token punctuation">.</span>left<span class="token punctuation">)</span>
      <span class="token keyword">break</span>
    <span class="token keyword">case</span> keys<span class="token punctuation">.</span>right<span class="token operator">:</span>
    <span class="token keyword">case</span> keys<span class="token punctuation">.</span>d<span class="token operator">:</span>
      sokoban<span class="token punctuation">.</span><span class="token function">move</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span>playerCoords<span class="token punctuation">,</span> directions<span class="token punctuation">.</span>right<span class="token punctuation">)</span>
      <span class="token keyword">break</span>
    <span class="token keyword">default</span><span class="token operator">:</span>
  <span class="token punctuation">}</span>

  sokoban<span class="token punctuation">.</span><span class="token function">render</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span>
<span class="token punctuation">}</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span></code></pre></div>
<p>The render function just maps through each coordinate and creates a rectangle or circle with the right color.</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="js"><pre class="language-js"><code class="language-js"><span class="token keyword">function</span> <span class="token function">render</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span> <span class="token punctuation">{</span>
  map<span class="token punctuation">.</span><span class="token function">forEach</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token parameter">row<span class="token punctuation">,</span> y</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span> <span class="token operator">=></span> <span class="token punctuation">{</span>
    row<span class="token punctuation">.</span><span class="token function">forEach</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token parameter">cell<span class="token punctuation">,</span> x</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span> <span class="token operator">=></span> <span class="token punctuation">{</span>
      <span class="token function">paintCell</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span>context<span class="token punctuation">,</span> cell<span class="token punctuation">,</span> x<span class="token punctuation">,</span> y<span class="token punctuation">)</span>
    <span class="token punctuation">}</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span>
  <span class="token punctuation">}</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span>
<span class="token punctuation">}</span></code></pre></div>
<p>Basically all rendering in the HTML canvas made a path for the outline (stroke), and a path for the inside (fill). Since one pixel per coordinate would be a pretty tiny game, I multiplied each value by a <code class="language-text">multipler</code>, which was <code class="language-text">75</code> pixels in this case.</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="js"><pre class="language-js"><code class="language-js"><span class="token keyword">function</span> <span class="token function">paintCell</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token parameter">context<span class="token punctuation">,</span> cell<span class="token punctuation">,</span> x<span class="token punctuation">,</span> y</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span> <span class="token punctuation">{</span>
  <span class="token comment">// Create the fill</span>
  context<span class="token punctuation">.</span><span class="token function">beginPath</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span>
  context<span class="token punctuation">.</span><span class="token function">rect</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span>x <span class="token operator">*</span> multiplier <span class="token operator">+</span> <span class="token number">5</span><span class="token punctuation">,</span> y <span class="token operator">*</span> multiplier <span class="token operator">+</span> <span class="token number">5</span><span class="token punctuation">,</span> multiplier <span class="token operator">-</span> <span class="token number">10</span><span class="token punctuation">,</span> multiplier <span class="token operator">-</span> <span class="token number">10</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span>
  context<span class="token punctuation">.</span>fillStyle <span class="token operator">=</span> colors<span class="token punctuation">[</span>cell<span class="token punctuation">]</span><span class="token punctuation">.</span>fill
  context<span class="token punctuation">.</span><span class="token function">fill</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span>

  <span class="token comment">// Create the outline</span>
  context<span class="token punctuation">.</span><span class="token function">beginPath</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span>
  context<span class="token punctuation">.</span><span class="token function">rect</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span>x <span class="token operator">*</span> multiplier <span class="token operator">+</span> <span class="token number">5</span><span class="token punctuation">,</span> y <span class="token operator">*</span> multiplier <span class="token operator">+</span> <span class="token number">5</span><span class="token punctuation">,</span> multiplier <span class="token operator">-</span> <span class="token number">10</span><span class="token punctuation">,</span> multiplier <span class="token operator">-</span> <span class="token number">10</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span>
  context<span class="token punctuation">.</span>lineWidth <span class="token operator">=</span> <span class="token number">10</span>
  context<span class="token punctuation">.</span>strokeStyle <span class="token operator">=</span> colors<span class="token punctuation">[</span>cell<span class="token punctuation">]</span><span class="token punctuation">.</span>stroke
  context<span class="token punctuation">.</span><span class="token function">stroke</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span>
<span class="token punctuation">}</span></code></pre></div>
<p>The render function also checks for a win condition (all storage locations are now success blocks) and shows "A winner is you!" if you win.</p>
<h2 id="conclusion" style="position:relative;"><a href="#conclusion" aria-label="conclusion permalink" class="anchor before"><svg aria-hidden="true" focusable="false" height="16" version="1.1" viewBox="0 0 16 16" width="16"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z"></path></svg></a>Conclusion</h2>
<p>This was a fun little game to make. I organized the files like this:</p>
<ul>
<li><a href="https://github.com/taniarascia/sokoban/blob/main/constants.js">Constants</a> for entity data, map data, mapping colors to entities, and key data.</li>
<li><a href="https://github.com/taniarascia/sokoban/blob/main/utils.js">Utility functions</a> for checking what type of entity exists at a particular coordinate, and determining what the new coordinates should be for the player.</li>
<li><a href="https://github.com/taniarascia/sokoban/blob/main/Sokoban.js">Sokoban class</a> for maintaining game state, logic, and rendering.</li>
<li><a href="https://github.com/taniarascia/sokoban/blob/main/script.js">Script</a> for initializing the instance of the app and handling key events.</li>
</ul>
<p>I found it easier to code than to solve. 😆</p>
<p>Hope you enjoyed reading about this and feel inspired to make your own little games and projects.</p></content:encoded><author>hello@taniarascia.com</author></item><item><title><![CDATA[React Architecture: How to Structure and Organize a React Application]]></title><description><![CDATA[There is no consensus on the right way to organize a React application. React gives you a lot of freedom, but with that freedom comes the…]]></description><link>https://www.taniarascia.com/react-architecture-directory-structure/</link><guid isPermaLink="false">https://www.taniarascia.com/react-architecture-directory-structure/</guid><pubDate>Wed, 23 Jun 2021 00:00:00 GMT</pubDate><content:encoded><p>There is no consensus on the right way to organize a React application. React gives you a lot of freedom, but with that freedom comes the responsibility of deciding on your own architecture. Often the case is that whoever sets up the application in the beginning throws almost everything in a <code class="language-text">components</code> folder, or maybe <code class="language-text">components</code> and <code class="language-text">containers</code> if they used Redux, but I propose there's a better way. I like to be deliberate about how I organize my applications so they're easy to use, understand, and extend.</p>
<p>I'm going to show you what I consider to be an intuitive and scalable system for large-scale production React applications. The main concept I think is important is to make the architecture focused on <strong>feature</strong> as opposed to <strong>type</strong>, organizing only shared components on a global level and modularized all the other related entities together in the localized view.</p>
<h4 id="tech-assumptions" style="position:relative;"><a href="#tech-assumptions" aria-label="tech assumptions permalink" class="anchor before"><svg aria-hidden="true" focusable="false" height="16" version="1.1" viewBox="0 0 16 16" width="16"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z"></path></svg></a>Tech assumptions</h4>
<p>Since this article will be opinionated, I'll make some assumptions about what technology the project will be using:</p>
<ul>
<li><strong>Application</strong> - <a href="https://reactjs.org/">React</a> (Hooks)</li>
<li><strong>Global state management</strong> - <a href="https://redux.js.org/">Redux</a>, <a href="https://redux-toolkit.js.org/">Redux Toolkit</a></li>
<li><strong>Routing</strong> - <a href="https://reactrouter.com/">React Router</a></li>
<li><strong>Styles</strong> - <a href="https://styled-components.com/">Styled Components</a></li>
<li><strong>Testing</strong> - <a href="https://jestjs.io/">Jest</a>, <a href="https://testing-library.com/docs/react-testing-library/intro/">React Testing Library</a></li>
</ul>
<p>I don't have a very strong opinion about the styling, whether Styled Components or CSS modules or a custom Sass setup is ideal, but I think Styled Components is probably one of the best options for keeping your styles modular.</p>
<p>I'm also going to assume the tests are alongside the code, as opposed to in a top-level <code class="language-text">tests</code> folder. I can go either way with this one, but in order for an example to work, and in the real world, decisions need to be made.</p>
<p>Everything here can still apply if you're using vanilla Redux instead of Redux Toolkit. I would recommend <a href="https://redux.js.org/tutorials/essentials/part-2-app-structure#redux-slices">setting up your Redux as feature slices</a> either way.</p>
<p>I'm also ambivalent about <a href="https://storybook.js.org/">Storybook</a>, but I'll include what it would look like with those files if you choose to use it in your project.</p>
<p>For the sake of the example, I'll use a "Library App" example, that has a page for listing books, a page for listing authors, and has an authentication system.</p>
<h2 id="directory-structure" style="position:relative;"><a href="#directory-structure" aria-label="directory structure permalink" class="anchor before"><svg aria-hidden="true" focusable="false" height="16" version="1.1" viewBox="0 0 16 16" width="16"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z"></path></svg></a>Directory Structure</h2>
<p>The top level directory structure will be as follows:</p>
<ul>
<li><strong>assets</strong> - global static assets such as images, svgs, company logo, etc.</li>
<li><a href="#components">components</a> - global shared/reusable components, such as layout (wrappers, navigation), form components, buttons</li>
<li><a href="#services">services</a> - JavaScript modules</li>
<li><a href="#store">store</a> - Global Redux store</li>
<li><a href="#utils">utils</a> - Utilities, helpers, constants, and the like</li>
<li><a href="#views">views</a> - Can also be called "pages", the majority of the app would be contained here</li>
</ul>
<p>I like keeping familiar conventions wherever possible, so <code class="language-text">src</code> contains everything, <code class="language-text">index.js</code> is the entry point, and <code class="language-text">App.js</code> sets up the auth and routing.</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="text"><pre class="language-text"><code class="language-text">.
└── /src
    ├── /assets
    ├── /components
    ├── /services
    ├── /store
    ├── /utils
    ├── /views
    ├── index.js
    └── App.js</code></pre></div>
<p>I can see some additional folders you might have, such as <code class="language-text">types</code> if it's a TypeScript project, <code class="language-text">middleware</code> if necessary, maybe <code class="language-text">context</code> for <a href="/react-context-api-hooks/">Context</a>, etc.</p>
<h3 id="aliases" style="position:relative;"><a href="#aliases" aria-label="aliases permalink" class="anchor before"><svg aria-hidden="true" focusable="false" height="16" version="1.1" viewBox="0 0 16 16" width="16"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z"></path></svg></a>Aliases</h3>
<p>I would set up the system to use aliases, so anything within the <code class="language-text">components</code> folder could be imported as <code class="language-text">@components</code>, <code class="language-text">assets</code> as <code class="language-text">@assets</code>, etc. If you have a custom Webpack, this is done through the <a href="https://webpack.js.org/configuration/resolve/">resolve</a> configuration.</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="js"><pre class="language-js"><code class="language-js">module<span class="token punctuation">.</span>exports <span class="token operator">=</span> <span class="token punctuation">{</span>
  resolve<span class="token operator">:</span> <span class="token punctuation">{</span>
    extensions<span class="token operator">:</span> <span class="token punctuation">[</span><span class="token string">'js'</span><span class="token punctuation">,</span> <span class="token string">'ts'</span><span class="token punctuation">]</span><span class="token punctuation">,</span>
    alias<span class="token operator">:</span> <span class="token punctuation">{</span>
      <span class="token string">'@'</span><span class="token operator">:</span> path<span class="token punctuation">.</span><span class="token function">resolve</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span>__dirname<span class="token punctuation">,</span> <span class="token string">'src'</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span><span class="token punctuation">,</span>
      <span class="token string">'@assets'</span><span class="token operator">:</span> path<span class="token punctuation">.</span><span class="token function">resolve</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span>__dirname<span class="token punctuation">,</span> <span class="token string">'src/assets'</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span><span class="token punctuation">,</span>
      <span class="token string">'@components'</span><span class="token operator">:</span> path<span class="token punctuation">.</span><span class="token function">resolve</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span>__dirname<span class="token punctuation">,</span> <span class="token string">'src/components'</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span><span class="token punctuation">,</span>
      <span class="token comment">// ...etc</span>
    <span class="token punctuation">}</span><span class="token punctuation">,</span>
  <span class="token punctuation">}</span><span class="token punctuation">,</span>
<span class="token punctuation">}</span></code></pre></div>
<p>It just makes it a lot easier to import from anywhere within the project and move files around without changing imports, and you never end up with something like <code class="language-text">../../../../../components/</code>.</p>
<h3 id="components" style="position:relative;"><a href="#components" aria-label="components permalink" class="anchor before"><svg aria-hidden="true" focusable="false" height="16" version="1.1" viewBox="0 0 16 16" width="16"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z"></path></svg></a>Components</h3>
<p>Within the <code class="language-text">components</code> folder, I would group by type - <code class="language-text">forms</code>, <code class="language-text">tables</code>, <code class="language-text">buttons</code>, <code class="language-text">layout</code>, etc. The specifics will vary by your specific app.</p>
<p>In this example, I'm assuming you're either creating your own form system, or creating your own bindings to an existing form system (for example, combining Formik and Material UI). In this case, you'd create a folder for each component (<code class="language-text">TextField</code>, <code class="language-text">Select</code>, <code class="language-text">Radio</code>, <code class="language-text">Dropdown</code>, etc.), and inside would be a file for the component itself, the styles, the tests, and the Storybook if it's being used.</p>
<ul>
<li><strong>Component.js</strong> - The actual React component</li>
<li><strong>Component.styles.js</strong> - The Styled Components file for the component</li>
<li><strong>Component.test.js</strong> - The tests</li>
<li><strong>Component.stories.js</strong> - The Storybook file</li>
</ul>
<p>To me, this makes a lot more sense than having one folder that contains the files for ALL components, one folder that contains all the tests, and one folder that contains all the Storybook files, etc. Everything related is grouped together and easy to find.</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="text"><pre class="language-text"><code class="language-text">.
└── /src
    └── /components
        ├── /forms
        │   ├── /TextField
        │   │   ├── TextField.js
        │   │   ├── TextField.styles.js
        │   │   ├── TextField.test.js
        │   │   └── TextField.stories.js
        │   ├── /Select
        │   │   ├── Select.js
        │   │   ├── Select.styles.js
        │   │   ├── Select.test.js
        │   │   └── Select.stories.js
        │   └── index.js
        ├── /routing
        │   └── /PrivateRoute
        │       ├── /PrivateRoute.js
        │       └── /PrivateRoute.test.js
        └── /layout
            └── /navigation
                └── /NavBar
                    ├── NavBar.js
                    ├── NavBar.styles.js
                    ├── NavBar.test.js
                    └── NavBar.stories.js</code></pre></div>
<p>You'll notice there's an <code class="language-text">index.js</code> file in the <code class="language-text">components/forms</code> directory. It is often rightfully suggested to avoid using <code class="language-text">index.js</code> files as they're not explicit, but in this case it makes sense - it will end up being an index of all the forms and look something like this:</p>
<div class="filename">src/components/forms/index.js</div>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="js"><pre class="language-js"><code class="language-js"><span class="token keyword">import</span> <span class="token punctuation">{</span> TextField <span class="token punctuation">}</span> <span class="token keyword">from</span> <span class="token string">'./TextField/TextField'</span>
<span class="token keyword">import</span> <span class="token punctuation">{</span> Select <span class="token punctuation">}</span> <span class="token keyword">from</span> <span class="token string">'./Select/Select'</span>
<span class="token keyword">import</span> <span class="token punctuation">{</span> Radio <span class="token punctuation">}</span> <span class="token keyword">from</span> <span class="token string">'./Radio/Radio'</span>

<span class="token keyword">export</span> <span class="token punctuation">{</span> TextField<span class="token punctuation">,</span> Select<span class="token punctuation">,</span> Radio <span class="token punctuation">}</span></code></pre></div>
<p>Then when you need to use one or more of the components, you can easily import them all at once.</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="js"><pre class="language-js"><code class="language-js"><span class="token keyword">import</span> <span class="token punctuation">{</span> TextField<span class="token punctuation">,</span> Select<span class="token punctuation">,</span> Radio <span class="token punctuation">}</span> <span class="token keyword">from</span> <span class="token string">'@components/forms'</span></code></pre></div>
<p>I would recommend this approach more than making an <code class="language-text">index.js</code> inside of <em>every</em> folder within <code class="language-text">forms</code>, so now you just have one <code class="language-text">index.js</code> that actually indexes the entire directory, as opposed to ten <code class="language-text">index.js</code> files just to make imports easier for each individual file.</p>
<h3 id="services" style="position:relative;"><a href="#services" aria-label="services permalink" class="anchor before"><svg aria-hidden="true" focusable="false" height="16" version="1.1" viewBox="0 0 16 16" width="16"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z"></path></svg></a>Services</h3>
<p>The <code class="language-text">services</code> directory is less essential than <code class="language-text">components</code>, but if you're making a plain JavaScript module that the rest of the application is using, it can be handy. A common contrived example is a LocalStorage module, which might look like this:</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="text"><pre class="language-text"><code class="language-text">.
└── /src
    └── /services
        ├── /LocalStorage
        │   ├── LocalStorage.service.js
        │   └── LocalStorage.test.js
        └── index.js</code></pre></div>
<p>An example of the service:</p>
<div class="filename">src/services/LocalStorage/LocalStorage.service.js</div>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="js"><pre class="language-js"><code class="language-js"><span class="token keyword">export</span> <span class="token keyword">const</span> LocalStorage <span class="token operator">=</span> <span class="token punctuation">{</span>
  <span class="token function">get</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span>key<span class="token punctuation">)</span> <span class="token punctuation">{</span><span class="token punctuation">}</span><span class="token punctuation">,</span>
  <span class="token function">set</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span>key<span class="token punctuation">,</span> value<span class="token punctuation">)</span> <span class="token punctuation">{</span><span class="token punctuation">}</span><span class="token punctuation">,</span>
  <span class="token function">remove</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token parameter">key</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span> <span class="token punctuation">{</span><span class="token punctuation">}</span><span class="token punctuation">,</span>
  <span class="token function">clear</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span> <span class="token punctuation">{</span><span class="token punctuation">}</span><span class="token punctuation">,</span>
<span class="token punctuation">}</span></code></pre></div>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="js"><pre class="language-js"><code class="language-js"><span class="token keyword">import</span> <span class="token punctuation">{</span> LocalStorage <span class="token punctuation">}</span> <span class="token keyword">from</span> <span class="token string">'@services'</span>

LocalStorage<span class="token punctuation">.</span><span class="token function">get</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token string">'foo'</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span></code></pre></div>
<h3 id="store" style="position:relative;"><a href="#store" aria-label="store permalink" class="anchor before"><svg aria-hidden="true" focusable="false" height="16" version="1.1" viewBox="0 0 16 16" width="16"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z"></path></svg></a>Store</h3>
<p>The global data store will be contained in the <code class="language-text">store</code> directory - in this case, Redux. Each feature will have a folder, which will contain the <a href="https://redux-toolkit.js.org/">Redux Toolkit</a> slice, as well as actions and tests. This setup can also be used with regular Redux, you would just create a <code class="language-text">.reducers.js</code> file and <code class="language-text">.actions.js</code> file instead of a <code class="language-text">slice</code>. If you're using sagas, it could be <code class="language-text">.saga.js</code> instead of <code class="language-text">.actions.js</code> for Redux Thunk actions.</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="text"><pre class="language-text"><code class="language-text">.
└── /src
    ├── /store
    │   ├── /authentication
    │   │   ├── /authentication.slice.js
    │   │   ├── /authentication.actions.js
    │   │   └── /authentication.test.js
    │   ├── /authors
    │   │   ├── /authors.slice.js
    │   │   ├── /authors.actions.js
    │   │   └── /authors.test.js
    │   └── /books
    │       ├── /books.slice.js
    │       ├── /books.actions.js
    │       └── /books.test.js
    ├── rootReducer.js
    └── index.js</code></pre></div>
<p>You can also add something like a <code class="language-text">ui</code> section of the store to handle modals, toasts, sidebar toggling, and other global UI state, which I find better than having <code class="language-text">const [isOpen, setIsOpen] = useState(false)</code> all over the place.</p>
<p>In the <code class="language-text">rootReducer</code> you would import all your slices and combine them with <code class="language-text">combineReducers</code>, and in <code class="language-text">index.js</code> you would configure the store.</p>
<h3 id="utils" style="position:relative;"><a href="#utils" aria-label="utils permalink" class="anchor before"><svg aria-hidden="true" focusable="false" height="16" version="1.1" viewBox="0 0 16 16" width="16"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z"></path></svg></a>Utils</h3>
<p>Whether or not your project needs a <code class="language-text">utils</code> folder is up to you, but I think there are usually some global utility functions, like validation and conversion, that could easily be used across multiple sections of the app. If you keep it organized - not just having one <code class="language-text">helpers.js</code> file that contains thousands of functions - it could be a helpful addition to the organization of your project.</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="text"><pre class="language-text"><code class="language-text">.
└── src
    └── /utils
        ├── /constants
        │   └── countries.constants.js
        └── /helpers
            ├── validation.helpers.js
            ├── currency.helpers.js
            └── array.helpers.js</code></pre></div>
<p>Again, the <code class="language-text">utils</code> folder can contain anything you want that you think makes sense to keep on a global level. If you don't prefer the "multi-tier" filenames, you could just call it <code class="language-text">validation.js</code>, but the way I see it, being explicit does not take anything away from the project, and makes it easier to navigate filenames when searching in your IDE.</p>
<h3 id="views" style="position:relative;"><a href="#views" aria-label="views permalink" class="anchor before"><svg aria-hidden="true" focusable="false" height="16" version="1.1" viewBox="0 0 16 16" width="16"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z"></path></svg></a>Views</h3>
<p>Here's where the main part of your app will live: in the <code class="language-text">views</code> directory. Any page in your app is a "view". In this small example, the views line up pretty well with the Redux store, but it won't necessarily be the case that the store and views are exactly the same, which is why they're separate. Also, <code class="language-text">books</code> might pull from <code class="language-text">authors</code>, and so on.</p>
<p>Anything within a view is an item that will likely only be used within that specific view - a <code class="language-text">BookForm</code> that will only be used at the <code class="language-text">/books</code> route, and an <code class="language-text">AuthorBlurb</code> that will only be used on the <code class="language-text">/authors</code> route. It might include specific forms, modals, buttons, any component that won't be global.</p>
<p>The advantage of keeping everything domain-focused instead of putting all your pages together in <code class="language-text">components/pages</code> is that it makes it really easy to look at the structure of the application and know how many top level views there are, and know where everything that's only used by that view is. If there are nested routes, you can always add a nested <code class="language-text">views</code> folder within the main route.</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="text"><pre class="language-text"><code class="language-text">.
└── /src
    └── /views
        ├── /Authors
        │   ├── /AuthorsPage
        │   │   ├── AuthorsPage.js
        │   │   └── AuthorsPage.test.js
        │   └── /AuthorBlurb
        │       ├── /AuthorBlurb.js
        │       └── /AuthorBlurb.test.js
        ├── /Books
        │   ├── /BooksPage
        │   │   ├── BooksPage.js
        │   │   └── BooksPage.test.js
        │   └── /BookForm
        │       ├── /BookForm.js
        │       └── /BookForm.test.js
        └── /Login
            ├── LoginPage
            │   ├── LoginPage.styles.js
            │   ├── LoginPage.js
            │   └── LoginPage.test.js
            └── LoginForm
                ├── LoginForm.js
                └── LoginForm.test.js</code></pre></div>
<blockquote>
<p>Keeping everything within folders might seem annoying if you've never set up your project that way - you can always keep it more flat, or move <code class="language-text">tests</code> to its own directory that mimics the rest of the app.</p>
</blockquote>
<h2 id="conclusion" style="position:relative;"><a href="#conclusion" aria-label="conclusion permalink" class="anchor before"><svg aria-hidden="true" focusable="false" height="16" version="1.1" viewBox="0 0 16 16" width="16"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z"></path></svg></a>Conclusion</h2>
<p>This is my proposal for a sytem for React organization that scales well for a large production app, and handles testing and styling as well as keeping everything together in a feature focused way. It's more nested than the traditional structure of everything being in <code class="language-text">components</code> and <code class="language-text">containers</code>, but that system is a bit more dated due to Redux being much easier to implement with Hooks, and "smart" containers and "dumb" components no longer being necessary.</p>
<p>It's easy to look at this system and understand everything that is needed for your app and where to go to work on a specific section, or a component that affects the app globally. This system may not make sense for every type of app, but it has worked for me. I'd love to hear any comments about ways this system can be improved, or other systems that have merit.</p></content:encoded><author>hello@taniarascia.com</author></item><item><title><![CDATA[Using OAuth with PKCE Authorization Flow (Proof Key for Code Exchange)]]></title><description><![CDATA[If you've ever created a login page or auth system, you might be familiar with OAuth 2.0, the industry standard protocol for authorization…]]></description><link>https://www.taniarascia.com/oauth-pkce-authorization/</link><guid isPermaLink="false">https://www.taniarascia.com/oauth-pkce-authorization/</guid><pubDate>Sun, 20 Jun 2021 00:00:00 GMT</pubDate><content:encoded><p>If you've ever created a login page or auth system, you might be familiar with <a href="https://oauth.net/2/">OAuth 2.0</a>, the industry standard protocol for authorization. It allows an app to access resources hosted on another app securely. Access is granted using different flows, or grants, at the level of a scope.</p>
<p>For example, if I make an application (<strong>Client</strong>) that allows a user (<strong>Resource Owner</strong>) to make notes and save them as a repo in their GitHub account (<strong>Resource Server</strong>), then my application will need to access their GitHub data. It's not secure for the user to directly supply their GitHub username and password to my application and grant full access to the entire account. Instead, using OAuth 2.0, they can go through an authorization flow that will grant limited access to some resources based on a scope, and I will never have access to any other data or their password.</p>
<p>Using OAuth, a flow will ultimately request a token from the <strong>Authorization Server</strong>, and that token can be used to make all future requests in the agreed upon scope.</p>
<blockquote>
<p>Note: OAuth 2.0 is used for <strong>authorization</strong>, (authZ) which gives users permission to access a resource. OpenID Connect, or OIDC, is often used for <strong>authentication</strong>, (authN) which verifies the identity of the end user.</p>
</blockquote>
<h2 id="grant-types" style="position:relative;"><a href="#grant-types" aria-label="grant types permalink" class="anchor before"><svg aria-hidden="true" focusable="false" height="16" version="1.1" viewBox="0 0 16 16" width="16"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z"></path></svg></a>Grant Types</h2>
<p>The type of application you have will determine the grant type that will apply.</p>
<table>
<thead>
<tr>
<th>Grant Type</th>
<th>Application type</th>
<th>Example</th>
</tr>
</thead>
<tbody>
<tr>
<td>Client Credentials</td>
<td>Machine</td>
<td>A server accesses 3rd-party data via cron job</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>Authorization Code</td>
<td>Server-side web app</td>
<td>A Node or Python server handles the front and back end</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>Authorization Code with PKCE</td>
<td>Single-page web app/mobile app</td>
<td>A client-side only application that is decoupled from the back end</td>
</tr>
</tbody>
</table>
<p>For machine-to-machine communication, like something that cron job on a server would perform, you would use the <strong>Client Credentials</strong> grant type, which uses a client id and client secret. This is acceptable because the client id and resource owner are the same, so only one is needed. This is performed using the <code class="language-text">/token</code> endpoint.</p>
<p>For a server-side web app, like a Python Django app, Ruby on Rails app, PHP Laravel, or Node/Express serving React, the <strong>Authorization Code</strong> flow is used, which still uses a client id and client secret on the server side, but the user needs to authorize via the third-party first. This is performed using both an <code class="language-text">/authorize</code> and <code class="language-text">/token</code> endpoints.</p>
<p>However, for a client-side only web app or a mobile app, the Authorization Code flow is not acceptable because the client secret cannot be exposed, and there's no way to protect it. For this purpose, the <a href="https://oauth.net/2/pkce/">Proof Key for Code Exchange (PKCE)</a> version of the authorization code flow is used. In this version, the client creates a secret from scratch and supplies it after the authorization request to retrieve the token.</p>
<p>Since PKCE is a relatively new addition to OAuth, a lot of authentication servers do not support it yet, in which case either a less secure legacy flow like <a href="https://oauth.net/2/grant-types/implicit/">Implicit Grant</a> is used, where the token would return in the callback of the request, but using Implicit Grant flow is discouraged. <a href="https://aws.amazon.com/blogs/security/how-to-add-authentication-single-page-web-application-with-amazon-cognito-oauth2-implementation/">AWS Cognito</a> is one popular authorization server that supports PKCE.</p>
<h2 id="pkce-flow" style="position:relative;"><a href="#pkce-flow" aria-label="pkce flow permalink" class="anchor before"><svg aria-hidden="true" focusable="false" height="16" version="1.1" viewBox="0 0 16 16" width="16"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z"></path></svg></a>PKCE Flow</h2>
<p>The flow for a PKCE authentication system involves a <em>user</em>, a client-side <em>app</em>, and an <em>authorization server</em>, and will look something like this:</p>
<ol>
<li><em>The user</em> arrives at <em>the app</em>'s entry page</li>
<li><em>The app</em> generates a PKCE <strong>code challenge</strong> and redirects to <em>the authorization server</em> login page via <code class="language-text">/authorize</code></li>
<li><em>The user</em> logs in to <em>the authorization server</em> and is redirected back to <em>the app</em> with the authorization code</li>
<li><em>The app</em> requests the token from <em>the authorization server</em> using the <strong>code verifier/challenge</strong> via <code class="language-text">/token</code></li>
<li><em>The authorization server</em> responds with the token, which can be used by <em>the app</em> to access resources on behalf of <em>the user</em></li>
</ol>
<p>So all we need to know is what our <code class="language-text">/authorize</code> and <code class="language-text">/token</code> endpoints should look like. I'll go through an example of setting up PKCE for a front end web app.</p>
<h2 id="get-authorize-endpoint" style="position:relative;"><a href="#get-authorize-endpoint" aria-label="get authorize endpoint permalink" class="anchor before"><svg aria-hidden="true" focusable="false" height="16" version="1.1" viewBox="0 0 16 16" width="16"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z"></path></svg></a>GET <code class="language-text">/authorize</code> endpoint</h2>
<p>The flow begins by making a <code class="language-text">GET</code> request to the <code class="language-text">/authorize</code> endpoint. We need to pass some parameters along in the URL, which includes generating a <strong>code challenge</strong> and <strong>code verifier</strong>.</p>
<table>
<thead>
<tr>
<th>Parameter</th>
<th>Description</th>
</tr>
</thead>
<tbody>
<tr>
<td><code class="language-text">response_type</code></td>
<td><code class="language-text">code</code></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td><code class="language-text">client_id</code></td>
<td>Your client ID</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td><code class="language-text">redirect_uri</code></td>
<td>Your redirect URI</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td><code class="language-text">code_challenge</code></td>
<td>Your code challenge</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td><code class="language-text">code_challenge_method</code></td>
<td><code class="language-text">S256</code></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td><code class="language-text">scope</code></td>
<td>Your scope</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td><code class="language-text">state</code></td>
<td>Your state (optional)</td>
</tr>
</tbody>
</table>
<p>We'll be building the URL and redirecting the user to it, but first we need to make the verifier and challenge.</p>
<h3 id="verifier" style="position:relative;"><a href="#verifier" aria-label="verifier permalink" class="anchor before"><svg aria-hidden="true" focusable="false" height="16" version="1.1" viewBox="0 0 16 16" width="16"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z"></path></svg></a>Verifier</h3>
<p>The first step is generating a code verifier, which the <a href="https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/rfc7636#section-4.1">PKCE spec</a> defines as:</p>
<blockquote>
<p><strong>Verifier</strong> - A high-entropy cryptographic random STRING using the unreserved characters [A-Z] / [a-z] / [0-9] / "-" / "." / "*" / "~" from Section 2.3 of [RFC3986], with a minimum length of 43 characters and a maximum length of 128 characters.</p>
</blockquote>
<p>I'm using a random string generator that <a href="https://github.com/aaronpk">Aaron Parecki</a> of oauth.net wrote:</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="js"><pre class="language-js"><code class="language-js"><span class="token keyword">function</span> <span class="token function">generateVerifier</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span> <span class="token punctuation">{</span>
  <span class="token keyword">const</span> array <span class="token operator">=</span> <span class="token keyword">new</span> <span class="token class-name">Uint32Array</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token number">28</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span>
  window<span class="token punctuation">.</span>crypto<span class="token punctuation">.</span><span class="token function">getRandomValues</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span>array<span class="token punctuation">)</span>

  <span class="token keyword">return</span> Array<span class="token punctuation">.</span><span class="token function">from</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span>array<span class="token punctuation">,</span> <span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token parameter">item</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span> <span class="token operator">=></span> <span class="token template-string"><span class="token template-punctuation string">`</span><span class="token string">0</span><span class="token interpolation"><span class="token interpolation-punctuation punctuation">${</span>item<span class="token punctuation">.</span><span class="token function">toString</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token number">16</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span><span class="token interpolation-punctuation punctuation">}</span></span><span class="token template-punctuation string">`</span></span><span class="token punctuation">.</span><span class="token function">substr</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token operator">-</span><span class="token number">2</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span><span class="token punctuation">.</span><span class="token function">join</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span>
    <span class="token string">''</span>
  <span class="token punctuation">)</span>
<span class="token punctuation">}</span></code></pre></div>
<h3 id="challenge" style="position:relative;"><a href="#challenge" aria-label="challenge permalink" class="anchor before"><svg aria-hidden="true" focusable="false" height="16" version="1.1" viewBox="0 0 16 16" width="16"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z"></path></svg></a>Challenge</h3>
<p>The <a href="https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/rfc7636#section-4.2">code challenge</a> performs the following transformation on the code verifier:</p>
<blockquote>
<p><strong>Challenge</strong> - <code class="language-text">BASE64URL-ENCODE(SHA256(ASCII(code_verifier)))</code></p>
</blockquote>
<p>So the verifier gets passed into the challenge function as an argument and transformed. This is the function that will hash and encode the random verifier string:</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="js"><pre class="language-js"><code class="language-js"><span class="token keyword">async</span> <span class="token keyword">function</span> <span class="token function">generateChallenge</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token parameter">verifier</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span> <span class="token punctuation">{</span>
  <span class="token keyword">function</span> <span class="token function">sha256</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token parameter">plain</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span> <span class="token punctuation">{</span>
    <span class="token keyword">const</span> encoder <span class="token operator">=</span> <span class="token keyword">new</span> <span class="token class-name">TextEncoder</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span>
    <span class="token keyword">const</span> data <span class="token operator">=</span> encoder<span class="token punctuation">.</span><span class="token function">encode</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span>plain<span class="token punctuation">)</span>

    <span class="token keyword">return</span> window<span class="token punctuation">.</span>crypto<span class="token punctuation">.</span>subtle<span class="token punctuation">.</span><span class="token function">digest</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token string">'SHA-256'</span><span class="token punctuation">,</span> data<span class="token punctuation">)</span>
  <span class="token punctuation">}</span>

  <span class="token keyword">function</span> <span class="token function">base64URLEncode</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token parameter">string</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span> <span class="token punctuation">{</span>
    <span class="token keyword">return</span> <span class="token function">btoa</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span>String<span class="token punctuation">.</span><span class="token function">fromCharCode</span><span class="token punctuation">.</span><span class="token function">apply</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token keyword">null</span><span class="token punctuation">,</span> <span class="token keyword">new</span> <span class="token class-name">Uint8Array</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span>string<span class="token punctuation">)</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span>
      <span class="token punctuation">.</span><span class="token function">replace</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token regex"><span class="token regex-delimiter">/</span><span class="token regex-source language-regex">\+</span><span class="token regex-delimiter">/</span><span class="token regex-flags">g</span></span><span class="token punctuation">,</span> <span class="token string">'-'</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span>
      <span class="token punctuation">.</span><span class="token function">replace</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token regex"><span class="token regex-delimiter">/</span><span class="token regex-source language-regex">\/</span><span class="token regex-delimiter">/</span><span class="token regex-flags">g</span></span><span class="token punctuation">,</span> <span class="token string">'_'</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span>
      <span class="token punctuation">.</span><span class="token function">replace</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token regex"><span class="token regex-delimiter">/</span><span class="token regex-source language-regex">=+\$</span><span class="token regex-delimiter">/</span></span><span class="token punctuation">,</span> <span class="token string">''</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span>
  <span class="token punctuation">}</span>

  <span class="token keyword">const</span> hashed <span class="token operator">=</span> <span class="token keyword">await</span> <span class="token function">sha256</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span>verifier<span class="token punctuation">)</span>

  <span class="token keyword">return</span> <span class="token function">base64URLEncode</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span>hashed<span class="token punctuation">)</span>
<span class="token punctuation">}</span></code></pre></div>
<h3 id="build-endpoint" style="position:relative;"><a href="#build-endpoint" aria-label="build endpoint permalink" class="anchor before"><svg aria-hidden="true" focusable="false" height="16" version="1.1" viewBox="0 0 16 16" width="16"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z"></path></svg></a>Build endpoint</h3>
<p>Now you can take all the needed parameters, generate the verifier and challenge, set the verifier to local storage, and redirect the user to the authentication server's login page.</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="js"><pre class="language-js"><code class="language-js"><span class="token keyword">async</span> <span class="token keyword">function</span> <span class="token function">buildAuthorizeEndpointAndRedirect</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span> <span class="token punctuation">{</span>
  <span class="token keyword">const</span> host <span class="token operator">=</span> <span class="token string">'https://auth-server.example.com/oauth/authorize'</span>
  <span class="token keyword">const</span> clientId <span class="token operator">=</span> <span class="token string">'abc123'</span>
  <span class="token keyword">const</span> redirectUri <span class="token operator">=</span> <span class="token string">'https://my-app-host.example.com/callback'</span>
  <span class="token keyword">const</span> scope <span class="token operator">=</span> <span class="token string">'specific,scopes,for,app'</span>
  <span class="token keyword">const</span> verifier <span class="token operator">=</span> <span class="token function">generateVerifier</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span>
  <span class="token keyword">const</span> challenge <span class="token operator">=</span> <span class="token keyword">await</span> <span class="token function">generateChallenge</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span>verifier<span class="token punctuation">)</span>

  <span class="token comment">// Build endpoint</span>
  <span class="token keyword">const</span> endpoint <span class="token operator">=</span> <span class="token template-string"><span class="token template-punctuation string">`</span><span class="token interpolation"><span class="token interpolation-punctuation punctuation">${</span>host<span class="token interpolation-punctuation punctuation">}</span></span><span class="token string">?
    response_type=code&amp;
    client_id=</span><span class="token interpolation"><span class="token interpolation-punctuation punctuation">${</span>clientId<span class="token interpolation-punctuation punctuation">}</span></span><span class="token string">&amp;
    scope=</span><span class="token interpolation"><span class="token interpolation-punctuation punctuation">${</span>scope<span class="token interpolation-punctuation punctuation">}</span></span><span class="token string">&amp;
    redirect_uri=</span><span class="token interpolation"><span class="token interpolation-punctuation punctuation">${</span>redirectUri<span class="token interpolation-punctuation punctuation">}</span></span><span class="token string">&amp;
    code_challenge=</span><span class="token interpolation"><span class="token interpolation-punctuation punctuation">${</span>challenge<span class="token interpolation-punctuation punctuation">}</span></span><span class="token string">&amp;
    code_challenge_method=S256</span><span class="token template-punctuation string">`</span></span>

  <span class="token comment">// Set verifier to local storage</span>
  localStorage<span class="token punctuation">.</span><span class="token function">setItem</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token string">'verifier'</span><span class="token punctuation">,</span> verifier<span class="token punctuation">)</span>

  <span class="token comment">// Redirect to authentication server's login page</span>
  window<span class="token punctuation">.</span>location <span class="token operator">=</span> endpoint
<span class="token punctuation">}</span></code></pre></div>
<p>At what point you call this function is up to you - it might happen at the click of a button, or automatically if a user is deemed to not be authenticated when they land on the app. In a React app it would probably be in the <code class="language-text">useEffect()</code>.</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="js"><pre class="language-js"><code class="language-js"><span class="token function">useEffect</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span> <span class="token operator">=></span> <span class="token punctuation">{</span>
  <span class="token function">buildAuthorizeEndpointAndRedirect</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span>
<span class="token punctuation">}</span><span class="token punctuation">,</span> <span class="token punctuation">[</span><span class="token punctuation">]</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span></code></pre></div>
<p>Now the user will be on the authentication server's login page, and after successful login via username and password they'll be redirected to the <code class="language-text">redirect_uri</code> from step one.</p>
<h3 id="post-token-endpoint" style="position:relative;"><a href="#post-token-endpoint" aria-label="post token endpoint permalink" class="anchor before"><svg aria-hidden="true" focusable="false" height="16" version="1.1" viewBox="0 0 16 16" width="16"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z"></path></svg></a>POST <code class="language-text">/token</code> endpoint</h3>
<p>The second step is retrieving the token. This is the part that is usually accomplished server side in a traditional Authorization Code flow, but for PKCE it's also through the front end. When the authorization server redirects back to your callback URI, it will come along with a <code class="language-text">code</code> in the query string, which you can exchange along with the verifier string for the final <code class="language-text">token</code>.</p>
<p>The <code class="language-text">POST</code> request for a token must be made as a <code class="language-text">x-www-form-urlencoded</code> request.</p>
<table>
<thead>
<tr>
<th>Header</th>
<th>Description</th>
</tr>
</thead>
<tbody>
<tr>
<td><code class="language-text">Content-Type</code></td>
<td><code class="language-text">application/x-www-form-urlencoded</code></td>
</tr>
</tbody>
</table>
<table>
<thead>
<tr>
<th>Parameter</th>
<th>Description</th>
</tr>
</thead>
<tbody>
<tr>
<td><code class="language-text">grant_type</code></td>
<td><code class="language-text">authorization_code</code></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td><code class="language-text">client_id</code></td>
<td>Your client ID</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td><code class="language-text">code_verifier</code></td>
<td>Your code verifier</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td><code class="language-text">redirect_uri</code></td>
<td>The same redirect URI from step 1</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td><code class="language-text">code</code></td>
<td>Code query parameter</td>
</tr>
</tbody>
</table>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="js"><pre class="language-js"><code class="language-js"><span class="token keyword">async</span> <span class="token keyword">function</span> <span class="token function">getToken</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token parameter">verifier</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span> <span class="token punctuation">{</span>
  <span class="token keyword">const</span> host <span class="token operator">=</span> <span class="token string">'https://auth-server.example.com/oauth/token'</span>
  <span class="token keyword">const</span> clientId <span class="token operator">=</span> <span class="token string">'abc123'</span>
  <span class="token keyword">const</span> redirectUri <span class="token operator">=</span> <span class="token template-string"><span class="token template-punctuation string">`</span><span class="token string">https://my-app-server.example.com/callback</span><span class="token template-punctuation string">`</span></span>

  <span class="token comment">// Get code from query params</span>
  <span class="token keyword">const</span> urlParams <span class="token operator">=</span> <span class="token keyword">new</span> <span class="token class-name">URLSearchParams</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span>window<span class="token punctuation">.</span>location<span class="token punctuation">.</span>search<span class="token punctuation">)</span>
  <span class="token keyword">const</span> code <span class="token operator">=</span> urlParams<span class="token punctuation">.</span><span class="token function">get</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token string">'code'</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span>

  <span class="token comment">// Build params to send to token endpoint</span>
  <span class="token keyword">const</span> params <span class="token operator">=</span> <span class="token template-string"><span class="token template-punctuation string">`</span><span class="token string">client_id=</span><span class="token interpolation"><span class="token interpolation-punctuation punctuation">${</span>clientId<span class="token interpolation-punctuation punctuation">}</span></span><span class="token string">&amp;
    grant_type=</span><span class="token interpolation"><span class="token interpolation-punctuation punctuation">${</span>grantType<span class="token interpolation-punctuation punctuation">}</span></span><span class="token string">&amp;
    code_verifier=</span><span class="token interpolation"><span class="token interpolation-punctuation punctuation">${</span>verifier<span class="token interpolation-punctuation punctuation">}</span></span><span class="token string">&amp;
    redirect_uri=</span><span class="token interpolation"><span class="token interpolation-punctuation punctuation">${</span>redirectUri<span class="token interpolation-punctuation punctuation">}</span></span><span class="token string">&amp;
    code=</span><span class="token interpolation"><span class="token interpolation-punctuation punctuation">${</span>code<span class="token interpolation-punctuation punctuation">}</span></span><span class="token template-punctuation string">`</span></span>

  <span class="token comment">// Make a POST request</span>
  <span class="token keyword">try</span> <span class="token punctuation">{</span>
    <span class="token keyword">const</span> response <span class="token operator">=</span> <span class="token keyword">await</span> <span class="token function">fetch</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span>host<span class="token punctuation">,</span> <span class="token punctuation">{</span>
      method<span class="token operator">:</span> <span class="token string">'POST'</span><span class="token punctuation">,</span>
      headers<span class="token operator">:</span> <span class="token punctuation">{</span>
        <span class="token string">'Content-Type'</span><span class="token operator">:</span> <span class="token string">'application/x-www-form-urlencoded'</span><span class="token punctuation">,</span>
      <span class="token punctuation">}</span><span class="token punctuation">,</span>
      body<span class="token operator">:</span> params<span class="token punctuation">,</span>
    <span class="token punctuation">}</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span>
    <span class="token keyword">const</span> data <span class="token operator">=</span> <span class="token keyword">await</span> response<span class="token punctuation">.</span><span class="token function">json</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span>

    <span class="token comment">// Token</span>
    console<span class="token punctuation">.</span><span class="token function">log</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span>data<span class="token punctuation">)</span>
  <span class="token punctuation">}</span> <span class="token keyword">catch</span> <span class="token punctuation">(</span>e<span class="token punctuation">)</span> <span class="token punctuation">{</span>
    console<span class="token punctuation">.</span><span class="token function">log</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span>e<span class="token punctuation">)</span>
  <span class="token punctuation">}</span>
<span class="token punctuation">}</span></code></pre></div>
<p>Once you obtain the token, you should immediately delete the verifier from <code class="language-text">localStorage</code>.</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="js"><pre class="language-js"><code class="language-js"><span class="token keyword">const</span> response <span class="token operator">=</span> <span class="token keyword">await</span> <span class="token function">getToken</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span>localStorage<span class="token punctuation">.</span><span class="token function">getItem</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token string">'verifier'</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span>
localStorage<span class="token punctuation">.</span><span class="token function">removeItem</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token string">'verifier'</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span></code></pre></div>
<p>When it comes to storing the token, if your app is truly front end only, the option is to use <code class="language-text">localStorage</code>. If the option of having a server is available, you can use a Backend for Frontend (BFF) to handle authentication. I recommend reading <a href="https://www.pingidentity.com/en/company/blog/posts/2021/refresh-token-rotation-spa.html">A Critical Analysis of Refresh Token Rotation in Single-page Applications</a>.</p>
<h2 id="conclusion" style="position:relative;"><a href="#conclusion" aria-label="conclusion permalink" class="anchor before"><svg aria-hidden="true" focusable="false" height="16" version="1.1" viewBox="0 0 16 16" width="16"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z"></path></svg></a>Conclusion</h2>
<p>And there you have it - the two steps to authenticate using PKCE. First, build a URL for <code class="language-text">/authorize</code> on the authorization server and redirect the user to it, then POST to the <code class="language-text">/token</code> endpoint on the redirect. PKCE is currently the most secure authentication system that I know of for a front-end only web or mobile app. Hopefully this helps you understand and implement PKCE in your app!</p></content:encoded><author>hello@taniarascia.com</author></item><item><title><![CDATA[How and When to Use Context in React with Hooks]]></title><description><![CDATA[A while ago, I wrote an article about Using Context API in React.
