<p>The newsletter is up to 11,283 subscribers. I don't post very often, but it is really the only way I'm communicating with the world since I'm not active on Twitter or Reddit. I'm glad you all are interested in what I'm creating and I still hope to create interesting things in 2021.</p>
<h3 id="learning" style="position:relative;"><a href="#learning" aria-label="learning permalink" class="anchor before"><svg aria-hidden="true" focusable="false" height="16" version="1.1" viewBox="0 0 16 16" width="16"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z"></path></svg></a>Learning</h3>
<p>I didn't learn most of the things I wanted to this year. Data structures and algorithms have been on the back burner for a few years now, and I never seem to be able to focus on it. I think the best article I wrote this year is <a href="https://www.taniarascia.com/asynchronous-javascript-event-loop-callbacks-promises-async-await/">Understanding the Event Loop, Callbacks, Promises, and Async/Await in JavaScript</a>, which is a deep dive on how JavaScript and the event loop work under the hood. This article was something I wanted to write and understand for a long time, so I'm glad I finally did. I still want to learn computer science fundamentals, so next time I decide to sit down and try to learn something coding related that's probably what I'll do.</p>
<p>So, thank you for reading and I hope this answers your questions if you were wondering why I haven't been around or active much. I appreciate all of your support and I'm looking forward to seeing what 2021 brings.</p></content:encoded><author>hello@taniarascia.com</author></item><item><title><![CDATA[Building TakeNote, a Notes App for Developers With GitHub Sync]]></title><description><![CDATA[Not too long ago, I realized I didn't have a really good system for organizing my thoughts, and I wasn't happy with any of the note-taking…]]></description><link>https://www.taniarascia.com/building-takenote/</link><guid isPermaLink="false">https://www.taniarascia.com/building-takenote/</guid><pubDate>Mon, 30 Nov 2020 00:00:00 GMT</pubDate><content:encoded><p>Not too long ago, I realized I didn't have a really good system for organizing my thoughts, and I wasn't happy with any of the note-taking apps I tried. Evernote was too bloated for me, and required a paid account to sync between multiple devices. SimpleNote was closer to what I wanted, but I found it somewhat ugly and clunky. Keep was too simple, Bear didn't have a web-based version...and so on.</p>
<p>Eventually I thought - why not just make exactly what I want? So I started building an app with the technologies I knew.</p>

<p>That app became <a href="https://takenote.dev/">TakeNote</a> , which I'm proud to say has been completed, thanks to over 50 <a href="https://github.com/taniarascia/takenote/graphs/contributors">open-source contributors</a> who helped along the way. <a href="https://github.com/taniarascia/takenote">The source</a> is up on GitHub for anyone who wants to see how it was done.</p>
<h2 id="what-i-wanted-it-to-do" style="position:relative;"><a href="#what-i-wanted-it-to-do" aria-label="what i wanted it to do permalink" class="anchor before"><svg aria-hidden="true" focusable="false" height="16" version="1.1" viewBox="0 0 16 16" width="16"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z"></path></svg></a>What I Wanted It To Do</h2>
<p>A few of my most important wants for the app:</p>
<ul>
<li>Plain text notes, no WYSIWYG or rich text editor</li>
<li>Accessible from a web browser</li>
<li>Authenticates and syncs with GitHub</li>
<li>Does not require a database</li>
<li>Has the look and feel of an IDE like Visual Studio Code, with syntax highlighting, markdown preview, and keyboard shortcuts</li>
<li>Links to internal notes like a wiki</li>
<li>Drag and drop</li>
<li>Easy to back up and import</li>
</ul>
<p>I'm really happy I saw it through to the end. It took about a full year with some breaks here and there (I started in September, 2019). I learned a lot along the way, much of which became knowledge that I directly used in my job.</p>
<h2 id="why-i-dont-want-to-ship-it" style="position:relative;"><a href="#why-i-dont-want-to-ship-it" aria-label="why i dont want to ship it permalink" class="anchor before"><svg aria-hidden="true" focusable="false" height="16" version="1.1" viewBox="0 0 16 16" width="16"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z"></path></svg></a>Why I Don't Want to Ship It</h2>
<p>TakeNote has two versions - the static, client-side only demo version that only saves to local storage, and a self-hosted complete version that runs on an Express server and authenticates and syncs with GitHub. Originally, I had the full, authenticated version hosted and despite not advertising this app at all, over 1,300 people authenticated with it, but now I have the demo version hosted on Netlify at <a href="https://takenote.dev">takenote.dev</a>.</p>
<p>Although I spent a lot of time on the project and I'm proud of it, I ultimately decided not to ship it. I spent a long time agonizing about what to do with the project, because I knew I didn't want to maintain it or have real users. There were a few reasons for that:</p>
<ul>
<li>I don't want to maintain a server. If I had real users and the app went down, I didn't feel comfortable having that knowledge in the back of mind that if there was a DDoS or DigitalOcean was down or for any other reason the server went down, the app would be down for users.</li>
<li>I don't want to be responsible for anyone's private data. Although the data was saved in GitHub and not a database of mine, I'm just really not interested in people's private data in any capacity, and a note-taking app is inherently going to contain personal data.</li>
<li>GitHub OAuth requires full access to <em>all</em> private repositories to get access to <em>any</em> private repository. There is no way around it. The "GitHub App" flow did not pertain to my use case, and all private repos is the only relevant scope for my app. I didn't feel comfortable having these permissions for any reason, and nor do many other people, which is understandable.</li>
<li>If I were to actually host this, it would have users and likely go over the rate limiting allowed very quickly, rendering the app pretty useless.</li>
<li>After getting far along in the project, I realized it would be impossible to make a good mobile experience for such an involved app, especially since it's impossible to disable zoom on iOS devices. I originally planned to just make a responsive web app for mobile, but after realizing I would need to make iOS/Android apps for mobile to work, I realized I wasn't willing to double the effort that I had already put in to complete this last step.</li>
</ul>
<p>What I've ended up with is an excellent desktop web app, that looks and feels exactly like I'd want a note-taking app to feel. The hosted version is perfectly fine for any private, ephemeral notes anyone wants to take that definitely does not connect to any server or database, and imports/exports to JSON.</p>
<p>Personally, I decided to settle on Bear for a notes app for myself, as I found that it had so many of the features I implemented in TakeNote, and I appreciated it. My only issue with it is that it's not available from the web or for Windows (as I now have a Windows PC for gaming/other activities as well and would like to access notes from there).</p>
<h2 id="what-i-learned-while-writing-it" style="position:relative;"><a href="#what-i-learned-while-writing-it" aria-label="what i learned while writing it permalink" class="anchor before"><svg aria-hidden="true" focusable="false" height="16" version="1.1" viewBox="0 0 16 16" width="16"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z"></path></svg></a>What I Learned While Writing It</h2>
<p>I wrote several articles that were the result of things I learned while writing this app.</p>
<h3 id="authentication-oauth" style="position:relative;"><a href="#authentication-oauth" aria-label="authentication oauth permalink" class="anchor before"><svg aria-hidden="true" focusable="false" height="16" version="1.1" viewBox="0 0 16 16" width="16"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z"></path></svg></a>Authentication (OAuth)</h3>
<p>I wrote <a href="https://www.taniarascia.com/full-stack-cookies-localstorage-react-express/">Client-side Authentication the Right Way (Cookies vs. Local Storage) </a>, which details how to make a secure authentication set up using HTTP Only, Secure, Same-Site cookies with an Express server and a front end. I also learned the OAuth flow, and how easy it is to set up instead of using some third-party system like Auth0, which deceptively sounds similar to OAuth and can easily trick people into thinking they need to use it.</p>
<h3 id="cicd-docker-and-travis" style="position:relative;"><a href="#cicd-docker-and-travis" aria-label="cicd docker and travis permalink" class="anchor before"><svg aria-hidden="true" focusable="false" height="16" version="1.1" viewBox="0 0 16 16" width="16"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z"></path></svg></a>CI/CD (Docker and Travis)</h3>
<p>I wanted to automate deployments and testing for the app, but I had never done it before from scratch. It's easy enough with a static site and something like Netlify or GitHub pages, but it's a whole different beast for a site with a server. I wrote <a href="https://www.taniarascia.com/continuous-integration-pipeline-docker/">Create a CI/CD Pipeline with Docker</a>, which entailed all that I learned while creating an automation pipeline that would test all my code in PRs, and deploy it to a server behind a load balancer every time a merge was made into the <code class="language-text">master</code> branch.</p>
<h3 id="state-management-redux" style="position:relative;"><a href="#state-management-redux" aria-label="state management redux permalink" class="anchor before"><svg aria-hidden="true" focusable="false" height="16" version="1.1" viewBox="0 0 16 16" width="16"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z"></path></svg></a>State management (Redux)</h3>
<p>Before I started this project, I mostly avoided Redux, preferring to use Context in React for projects at work. As a result of setting up Redux Toolkit and Redux sagas for this project, I wrote <a href="https://www.taniarascia.com/redux-react-guide/">An Overview and Walkthrough of Redux</a> which builds demo applications of projects using vanilla Redux and Redux Toolkit. After using Redux, I realized I preferred it greatly to using Context. It does add a lot of boilerplate upfront, but the limitations of Context caused issues in previous projects as they grew.</p>
<h3 id="bundling-and-configuration-webpack" style="position:relative;"><a href="#bundling-and-configuration-webpack" aria-label="bundling and configuration webpack permalink" class="anchor before"><svg aria-hidden="true" focusable="false" height="16" version="1.1" viewBox="0 0 16 16" width="16"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z"></path></svg></a>Bundling and configuration (webpack)</h3>
<p>I wrote <a href="https://www.taniarascia.com/how-to-use-webpack/">How to Set Up webpack 5 From Scratch</a> based on much of what of what I learned setting up a custom webpack config for the app that would support both an Express-serving-a-frontend app and a static frontend app.</p>
<p>So the moral of the story here is it's always a good idea to reinvent the wheel and build a project because you'll learn something along the way. It's never a waste of time.</p>
<h2 id="how-i-made-it" style="position:relative;"><a href="#how-i-made-it" aria-label="how i made it permalink" class="anchor before"><svg aria-hidden="true" focusable="false" height="16" version="1.1" viewBox="0 0 16 16" width="16"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z"></path></svg></a>How I made it</h2>
<p>Here are the decisions and various tech I used to create the app.</p>
<h3 id="language-typescript" style="position:relative;"><a href="#language-typescript" aria-label="language typescript permalink" class="anchor before"><svg aria-hidden="true" focusable="false" height="16" version="1.1" viewBox="0 0 16 16" width="16"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z"></path></svg></a>Language (TypeScript)</h3>
<p>I chose to write TakeNote in <strong>TypeScript</strong>. I had a little bit of experience here and there with TypeScript, but I wanted to make a complete, full-stack app to see if it lives up to the hype. It did get a bit annoying with various React and web types - or using some third-party dependencies, but I did feel confident that a lot of little bugs were prevented by using the strictest settings.</p>
<h3 id="front-end-react--redux" style="position:relative;"><a href="#front-end-react--redux" aria-label="front end react  redux permalink" class="anchor before"><svg aria-hidden="true" focusable="false" height="16" version="1.1" viewBox="0 0 16 16" width="16"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z"></path></svg></a>Front end (React + Redux)</h3>
<p>I used <strong>React</strong> and <strong>Redux</strong> for the front end. It was either that, or Vue and Vuex, and although I've used Vue in the past for work, I just feel faster and more productive with React. I used simple <strong>SCSS</strong> for the styles instead of a CSS-in-JS solution, just because it's easier for me and simpler in my opinion.</p>
<h3 id="back-end-node--express" style="position:relative;"><a href="#back-end-node--express" aria-label="back end node  express permalink" class="anchor before"><svg aria-hidden="true" focusable="false" height="16" version="1.1" viewBox="0 0 16 16" width="16"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z"></path></svg></a>Back end (Node + Express)</h3>
<p>I used <strong>Node</strong> and <strong>Express</strong> for the full version of the app. I only needed a few endpoints, for authenticating and syncing. I decided against making a real update on every change, and instead only sync all the data at once on an interval. The server is necessary to obtain an authentication token and securely store it to allow a user to remain logged in, as GitHub does not have a PKCE setup that would allow OAuth with a front end only app.</p>
<h3 id="data-and-authentication-github" style="position:relative;"><a href="#data-and-authentication-github" aria-label="data and authentication github permalink" class="anchor before"><svg aria-hidden="true" focusable="false" height="16" version="1.1" viewBox="0 0 16 16" width="16"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z"></path></svg></a>Data and authentication (GitHub)</h3>
<p>I used <strong>GitHub</strong> to authenticate, instead of creating a database with users, so all of that security could be handled elsewhere. I also used the GitHub API to make commits on every interval with the changes made to the notes.</p>
<h3 id="primary-component" style="position:relative;"><a href="#primary-component" aria-label="primary component permalink" class="anchor before"><svg aria-hidden="true" focusable="false" height="16" version="1.1" viewBox="0 0 16 16" width="16"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z"></path></svg></a>Primary component</h3>
<p>The text editor is built with <strong>CodeMirror</strong>, which is also used by Chrome and Firefox DevTools, Codepen, GitHub, and basically any other in-browser fiddle environment.</p>
<p>Behind the scenes, it uses <strong>webpack</strong> for bundling, <strong>Jest</strong> and <strong>Cypress</strong> for testing, <strong>ESLint</strong>, and a few other open-source helper libraries.</p>
<h3 id="github-sync" style="position:relative;"><a href="#github-sync" aria-label="github sync permalink" class="anchor before"><svg aria-hidden="true" focusable="false" height="16" version="1.1" viewBox="0 0 16 16" width="16"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z"></path></svg></a>GitHub Sync</h3>
<p>The part I had the most trouble with in the application was syncing to GitHub. I had the app completed up to that point for a long time before I finally finished it. My original intention was that the app would save all the files exactly like you would organize them in a folder on your computer - all categories would be folders, and all notes would be a <code class="language-text">.md</code> file within the folder.</p>
<p>I imagined that every time you sync the data, it would be the equivalent of doing <code class="language-text">git add . &amp;&amp; git commit &amp;&amp; git push</code>. However, it's not so simple to do that with the GitHub API. I spent a lot of time figuring out how to create and edit multiple files at once, and I realized there was really no way to do it without making an API call for every single file. I know it seems like there should be a multi-file create or update API call, but there's not.</p>
<p>What I finally ended up doing is what you see in the <a href="https://github.com/taniarascia/takenote/blob/master/src/server/handlers/sync.ts">sync.ts file</a>, which does the following:</p>
<ul>
<li><a href="https://docs.github.com/en/free-pro-team@latest/rest/reference/git#update-a-reference">Gets a reference</a> to the current head</li>
<li><a href="https://docs.github.com/en/free-pro-team@latest/rest/reference/git#create-a-blob">Creates a blob for each file</a> (I decided on just creating one file for <code class="language-text">notes.json</code> and one file for <code class="language-text">categories.json</code>, instead of having a file for each note)</li>
<li>Creates a tree path</li>
<li><a href="https://docs.github.com/en/free-pro-team@latest/rest/reference/git#create-a-tree">Creates a tree</a></li>
<li><a href="https://docs.github.com/en/free-pro-team@latest/rest/reference/git#create-a-commit">Creates a commit</a></li>
<li><a href="https://docs.github.com/en/free-pro-team@latest/rest/reference/git#update-a-reference">Updates a reference</a></li>
</ul>
<p>With these steps, on every sync a new commit is created for any updates that are made since the last sync.</p>
<h2 id="open-source" style="position:relative;"><a href="#open-source" aria-label="open source permalink" class="anchor before"><svg aria-hidden="true" focusable="false" height="16" version="1.1" viewBox="0 0 16 16" width="16"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z"></path></svg></a>Open Source</h2>
<blockquote class="quotation">
<p>Nobody should start to undertake a large project. You start with a small trivial project, and you should never expect it to get large. If you do, you'll just over design and generally think it is more important than it likely is at that stage. Or worse, you might be scared away by the sheer size of the work you envision.</p>
<p>So start small, and think about the details. Don't think about some big picture and fancy design. If it doesn't solve some fairly immediate need, it's almost certainly over-designed. And don't expect people to jump in and help you. That's not how these things work. You need to get something half-way useful first, and then others will say "hey, that almost works for me", and they'll get involved in the project.</p>
<p><cite>— Linus Torvalds</cite></p>
</blockquote>
<p>I just started building this for a few months and once it got to a state where it was recognizable a note-taking app, people started making issues and PRs. It even made it to the trending list on GitHub one day, and I also think there were a lot of Hacktoberfest contributions (most positive, a little spam I had to shut down immediately).</p>
<p>Ultimately, there were about 250 pull requests and 200 issues created. I divided the issues - everything got a label of a type and a status. <strong>Types</strong> were: features, bugs, refactors, testing, questions, documentation, and accessibility. <strong>Statuses</strong> were: blocked, duplicate, won't do, invalid, can't replicate, in progress, completed, and postponed. Labeling everything kept it all organized and easy to keep track of for me</p>
<p>I <a href="https://github.com/taniarascia/takenote/releases">tagged and released</a> the big changes, and I connected the app with SonarQube to track any bugs or problems (very few due to TypeScript) and Cypress/Jest with Travis to run tests before merging PRs. I learned a lot about managing and maintaining a coding project while working on this.</p>
<p>I took care of the main behavior notes, the authentication, the GitHub sync, and many contributors fixed bugs, designed the logo, set up a testing framework, and suggested and implemented new features.</p>
<h2 id="conclusion" style="position:relative;"><a href="#conclusion" aria-label="conclusion permalink" class="anchor before"><svg aria-hidden="true" focusable="false" height="16" version="1.1" viewBox="0 0 16 16" width="16"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z"></path></svg></a>Conclusion</h2>
<p>Overall, working on TakeNote was a really positive experience for me. It's easy to get excited about a project and never finish it, or get stuck at a road block, but I saw it through to the end making it the fourth big project of mine: <a href="https://github.com/taniarascia/primitive">Primitive</a> the CSS framework, <a href="https://github.com/taniarascia/laconia">Laconia</a> the MVC PHP app, a <a href="https://github.com/taniarascia/chip8">Chip-8 emulator</a>, and now <a href="https://github.com/taniarascia/takenote">TakeNote</a>.</p>
<p>Ultimately, I decided not to release the app as a real service, but leave it out there as a fully functioning open-source project for people to see and learn from, and use and extend if they want. For myself, I decided to go with Bear for my own personal note-taking, as I realized I did not want to maintain something and spend more time on the maintenance of the app than the actual intended purpose of it.</p>
<p>I hope you check out <a href="https://takenote.dev/app">the demo</a> and play around with it! I encourage you to build a project if you have an idea, because it's fun and you'll learn a lot along the way.</p></content:encoded><author>hello@taniarascia.com</author></item><item><title><![CDATA[Building My First PC]]></title><description><![CDATA[I use a Mac for all my software development needs, but recently I decided I wanted to build a PC. I had an old one sitting around for the…]]></description><link>https://www.taniarascia.com/building-my-first-pc/</link><guid isPermaLink="false">https://www.taniarascia.com/building-my-first-pc/</guid><pubDate>Sun, 15 Nov 2020 00:00:00 GMT</pubDate><content:encoded><p>I use a Mac for all my software development needs, but recently I decided I wanted to build a PC. I had an old one sitting around for the occasional game, but it was <em>really</em> old - Windows 8 was new when it came out, making it about 8 years old. Also, it wasn't built for any sort of performance, being a stock machine meant for home office use.</p>
<p>Lately, I've wanted to do some extracurricular projects outside of programming and writing about JavaScript. Building a PC seemed like a fun project, as I'd learn a bit about how a computer works under the hood, it's inspired me to set up a sweet <a href="https://www.reddit.com/r/battlestations/">battlestation</a> and get some decent gear, and I'd have a much better machine for when I do play games or if I want to do anything with 3D modeling. So I went ahead and built one.</p>

<p>After having built one myself now, I can say I'm really glad I decided to do this. For anyone who uses a PC for any reason, not even just games or development, I'd highly recommend building your own as well. It's been a long, long time since I've used a computer with Windows, but in my experience of buying pre-built PCs, they were always loaded up with all the crapware and antivirus software that the hardware manufacturers ship along with Windows. I'm amazed at how fast and clean it is when you do it all yourself.</p>
<p>There was a bit of research I had to do and lingo I had to learn to get up to speed to doing this, so I'll share with you all the components needed, the ones I got, how much they cost, and how to set it up. I am by no means an expert, and as a result my write up might be most helpful for absolute beginners.</p>
<p>Here is <a href="https://pcpartpicker.com/list/MKWPF8">my final parts list</a>.</p>
<h2 id="getting-started" style="position:relative;"><a href="#getting-started" aria-label="getting started permalink" class="anchor before"><svg aria-hidden="true" focusable="false" height="16" version="1.1" viewBox="0 0 16 16" width="16"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z"></path></svg></a>Getting Started</h2>
<p>When building a PC, <a href="https://pcpartpicker.com/">PCPartPicker</a> will be your best friend. You can browse through builds others have made, pick from recommended builds for your needs, and create your own part lists. I was overwhelmed by all the parts, what I should get, what build I should go with, and whether or not the parts would be compatible with each other, and the final build I went with ended up varying a bit from what I started off with.</p>
<p>The questions that will determine your part list are:</p>
<ul>
<li>What will you be using the PC for?</li>
<li>What is your price range?</li>
</ul>
<p>I knew I wanted something around $1200 or below, and I was going to use it for casual gaming, music, and maaaybe a small amount of streaming, 3D modeling, or development work. I ended up paying less than $1200 for the box alone, but the peripherals (monitor, keyboard, webcam, speakers) and other necessities (Windows) made the whole package cost quite a bit more.</p>
<p>I put off pulling the trigger and doing a build for months and months because I wasn't sure if it was going to be worth it or if it was just going to be an extra thing I don't use since I prefer Macs. I realized I play games with friends enough to make it worth it, especially during quarantine.</p>
<p>You can really build something decent for $400-$500 if you don't care about gaming at all. The <a href="https://pcpartpicker.com/guide/">Build Guides</a> on PCPartPicker have a lot of recommended builds, so I used the <a href="https://pcpartpicker.com/guide/WqMnTW/excellent-amd-gamingstreaming-build">Excellent AMD Gaming/Streaming Build</a> as a base for mine.</p>
<h2 id="parts" style="position:relative;"><a href="#parts" aria-label="parts permalink" class="anchor before"><svg aria-hidden="true" focusable="false" height="16" version="1.1" viewBox="0 0 16 16" width="16"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z"></path></svg></a>Parts</h2>
<p>There are 6 essential parts every build needs. There are some additional things you can add, like custom cooling systems and optical drives, but I didn't need any of that.</p>
<ul>
<li><strong>CPU</strong> - the central processing unit, the primary component or "brains" of a computer. AMD and Intel are the main brands.</li>
<li><strong>Motherboard</strong> - the main printed circuit board that connects all the parts of a computer together. CPU, RAM, graphics cards, storage, drives, etc. will all hook into the motherboard.</li>
<li><strong>Memory</strong> - the RAM (random access memory) is where a computer stores and retrieves data on a short-term (volatile) basis.</li>
<li><strong>Storage</strong> - long-term (non-volatile) storage for a computer. These used to be stored in spinning hard drives but now frequently use SSD (solid state drive).</li>
<li><strong>Video card</strong> - the GPU (graphics processing unit) or graphics card, responsible for rendering images to the screen. AMD and NVIDIA are the main brands.</li>
<li><strong>Power Supply</strong> - the PSU (power supply unit) converts power from the source (outlet) into the correct format and voltage. This is what plugs into the wall.</li>
<li><strong>Case</strong> - technically not <em>required</em> (I've seen PC builds that are just a bunch of random parts on the wall) but most people want a body to put it all inside.</li>
</ul>
<p>Okay, that's not too bad. I think all the parts make sense - power, long-term data storage, short-term memory, graphics, processing, and the One Board to connect them all.</p>
<h2 id="my-choices" style="position:relative;"><a href="#my-choices" aria-label="my choices permalink" class="anchor before"><svg aria-hidden="true" focusable="false" height="16" version="1.1" viewBox="0 0 16 16" width="16"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z"></path></svg></a>My choices</h2>

<p>Here are the choices I made and why.</p>
<ul>
<li><strong>CPU</strong> - <a href="https://www.amd.com/en/products/cpu/amd-ryzen-5-3600">AMD Ryzen 5 3600</a> - honestly, I asked a friend whether or not to go with Intel or AMD, and they recommended AMD. I doubt there's much of a different ultimately. This one was highly rated.</li>
<li><strong>Motherboard</strong> - <a href="https://www.asrock.com/MB/AMD/B550%20Phantom%20Gaming%204/index.asp">ASRock B550 Phantom Gaming 4</a> - the motherboard and CPU go together, so you choose based on that compatibility. This one has 8 USB ports. Note that although it has an HDMI port, you will use the HDMI port on the graphics card, as the AMD CPU does not have integrated graphics and instead relies on the graphics card.</li>
<li><strong>Memory</strong> - <a href="https://www.crucial.com/memory/ddr4/bl2k16g36c16u4b">Crucial Ballistix 32GB Kit (2 x 16GB) DDR4-3600</a> - the build I selected 16GB RAM, but I went with 32GB (2 sticks of 16GB). More RAM is always better, why not?</li>
<li><strong>Storage</strong> - <a href="https://www.samsung.com/us/computing/memory-storage/solid-state-drives/ssd-970-evo-nvme-m-2-1tb-mz-v7e1t0bw/">SSD 970 EVO NVMe M.2 1TB</a> - a solid state drive is the only option, and this NVMe M.2 style was supported on the motherboard and extremely convenient to set up.</li>
<li><strong>Video card</strong> - graphics cards are the big part that people often replace when they want an upgrade to their gaming experience. I didn't need anything too intense for my games as I don't play anything very intensive. The initial one I wanted (RTX 2070) was sold out everywhere, along with my second choice (Radeon RX 5700 XT). The one I got was a tier behind, but still more than enough for my needs, and I saved $200+, so that was a win! If you care a lot about the stats, there are plenty of sites that do benchmarking between different graphics cards.</li>
<li><strong>Power supply</strong> - <a href="https://www.evga.com/products/product.aspx?pn=120-GP-0650-X1">EVGA SuperNOVA 650 G+, 80 Plus Gold 650W, Fully Modular</a> - I got a fully modular power supply, meaning you can connect only the parts you need.</li>
<li><strong>Case</strong> - <a href="https://www.coolermaster.com/catalog/cases/mid-tower/masterbox-nr600-without-odd/">MasterBox NR600 without ODD</a> - ODD is optical disk drive (like DVD), which I didn't need to support. I got an inexpensive case that looked tasteful and had nice airflow. I realized it's kind of big and I could have gone with a smaller case, but not really a big deal.</li>
</ul>
<h2 id="putting-it-together" style="position:relative;"><a href="#putting-it-together" aria-label="putting it together permalink" class="anchor before"><svg aria-hidden="true" focusable="false" height="16" version="1.1" viewBox="0 0 16 16" width="16"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z"></path></svg></a>Putting it together</h2>
<p>Of course, I had no idea how to put it all together, so I looked it up. All you need is a regular Phillips head screwdriver. I followed this video: <a href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=2XGgmkiw2tU&#x26;t=3037s">How To Build A PC - FULL Beginners Guide + Benchmarking</a>. I was lucky enough that he was using basically the same CPU, motherboard, and storage type as me, and the rest doesn't matter. I also felt good that the video was only a few months old and using the parts I chose, so I know I got some decent stuff.</p>
<p>The steps were as follows:</p>
<ol>
<li><strong>Put the CPU in the motherboard</strong> - the step entails putting the tiny little CPU chip in the right slot on the motherboard and locking it in.</li>
<li><strong>Attach the fan to the CPU/motherboard</strong> - a fan came with my CPU, and I just had to unscrew four screw and screw in the fan in their place.</li>
<li><strong>Attach the motherboard to the case</strong> - just find where all the ports are facing outwards, put it in the right slot, and screw it in.</li>
<li><strong>Install the RAM</strong> - there are four slots for RAM, and I put it in slots 2 and 4.</li>
<li><strong>Install the SSD</strong> - it goes into a slot and screws in with one tiny screw.</li>
<li><strong>Install the GPU</strong> - I took two segments off the side of the case for the display ports, and the GPU just clicks in to one long slot.</li>
<li><strong>Install the PSU</strong> - find all the cables you need and put them into the right slots - CPU, graphics, motherboard. Then you have to hook them up to the correct pins on the motherboard. One important note is that the video I watched had SATA, and my build did not need to use the SATA at all. Also install the fans into the pins and anything else that needs to be hooked up.</li>
</ol>
<p>The whole thing probably took 2 hours or so, but it was also my first time doing it and I was learning where everything is.</p>
<h2 id="turning-it-on" style="position:relative;"><a href="#turning-it-on" aria-label="turning it on permalink" class="anchor before"><svg aria-hidden="true" focusable="false" height="16" version="1.1" viewBox="0 0 16 16" width="16"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z"></path></svg></a>Turning it on</h2>

    </span></p>
<p>At this point I had little to no confidence that this was going to turn on, as it seemed crazy that this could work on the first try and I didn't plug something into the wrong slot. I connected the keyboard, mouse, ethernet, and monitor, I flipped the power switch, clicked the on button, and it booted up!</p>
<p>But it displayed this message:</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="text"><pre class="language-text"><code class="language-text">Reboot and Select proper Boot device
or Insert Boot Media in selected Boot device and press a key_</code></pre></div>
<p>First of all, what is with the capitalization here? It looks like the constitution. In any case, pressing any key didn't work. I forgot to include Windows before turning it on. I just wanted to see if it worked and did <em>anything</em> first.</p>
<p>I turned it off, inserted the Windows USB, and same message. After looking it up, I found someone suggesting to rapidly press delete 20 times right after turning it on. I did this, and then I was able to go through the Windows installation wizard.</p>

<p>After that was all set up, I was really blown away by how fast it was. Everything worked great, the computer starts up in 3 seconds and is ready to go, and there's no additional start up software. For this reason alone, I'd recommend <em>anyone</em> who uses a PC to build their own for the next one.</p>
<h2 id="peripherals" style="position:relative;"><a href="#peripherals" aria-label="peripherals permalink" class="anchor before"><svg aria-hidden="true" focusable="false" height="16" version="1.1" viewBox="0 0 16 16" width="16"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z"></path></svg></a>Peripherals</h2>
<p>Another aspect to consider is the peripherals - keyboard, monitor, mouse, speakers, mic, webcam, headphones, etc. I didn't know anything about that stuff, as I was using the cheapest stuff Walgreens could offer until now.</p>
<ul>
<li><strong>Monitor</strong> - I got a gaming monitor that was 27" wide, 1440 pixel resolution, and 165Hz frame rate. I didn't really know what any of that meant until I did a bit of research, but I'm happy with the <a href="https://www.asus.com/us/Monitors/TUF-Gaming-VG27AQ/">TUF Gaming VG27AQ Monitor</a> for both work and play.</li>
<li><strong>Keyboard</strong> - I also got the <a href="https://www.keychron.com/products/keychron-k1-wireless-mechanical-keyboard">Keychron K1 Wireless Mechanical Keyboard</a> as I wanted something that would work with the Mac and wasn't too far off from the tiny clearance on the chiclet keyboard I'm used to. I still prefer just using the MacBook Pro keyboard and trackpad for working. It's just so much more convenient than a separate keyboard and mouse - I never have to move my arm back and forth to the mouse.</li>
<li><strong>Microphone</strong> - I already had a <a href="https://www.bluemic.com/en-us/products/yeti/">Blue Yeti</a> mic for the occasional music recording needs and games, instead of a headset. And maybe I'll make an instructional video some day, who knows.</li>
<li><strong>Headphones</strong> - I also already had a <a href="https://www.sony.com/electronics/headband-headphones/wh-1000xm3">Sony WH-1000XM3</a>, high-quality wireless noise-cancelling headphones, which I use for listening to music, recording music, and games.</li>
<li><strong>Mouse</strong> - my mouse needs are not great, but I wanted something a little more decent than the $9 bargain bin mouse, so I got <a href="https://www.logitechg.com/en-us/products/gaming-mice/g203-prodigy-gaming-mouse.html">Logitech G203 Prodigy Programmable RGB Gaming Mouse</a>. I did program it to stay violet-indigoish (I'm not a fan of it rotating between RGB colors).</li>
</ul>
<p>For the first time in my life, I have decent gear and a cool set up. It took me months and months - almost a year - of working from home all day long to realize I should set up an actual office area, get an office chair, get a monitor, etc. It's still a work in progress - I'm planning on building a desk and setting it up nicely as well, so I don't have a cool "battlestation" to show off yet.</p>
