    <span class="token string">'postcss-preset-env'</span><span class="token operator">:</span> <span class="token punctuation">{</span>
      browsers<span class="token operator">:</span> <span class="token string">'last 2 versions'</span><span class="token punctuation">,</span>
    <span class="token punctuation">}</span><span class="token punctuation">,</span>
  <span class="token punctuation">}</span><span class="token punctuation">,</span>
<span class="token punctuation">}</span></code></pre></div>
<p>In order to test out that Sass and PostCSS are working, I'll make a <code class="language-text">src/styles/main.scss</code> with Sass variables and a PostCSS example (<code class="language-text">lch</code>).</p>
<div class="filename">src/styles/main.scss</div>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="scss"><pre class="language-scss"><code class="language-scss"><span class="token property"><span class="token variable">$font-size</span></span><span class="token punctuation">:</span> 1rem<span class="token punctuation">;</span>
<span class="token property"><span class="token variable">$font-color</span></span><span class="token punctuation">:</span> <span class="token function">lch</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span>53 105 40<span class="token punctuation">)</span><span class="token punctuation">;</span>

<span class="token selector">html </span><span class="token punctuation">{</span>
  <span class="token property">font-size</span><span class="token punctuation">:</span> <span class="token variable">$font-size</span><span class="token punctuation">;</span>
  <span class="token property">color</span><span class="token punctuation">:</span> <span class="token variable">$font-color</span><span class="token punctuation">;</span>
<span class="token punctuation">}</span></code></pre></div>
<p>Now import the file in <code class="language-text">index.js</code> and add the four loaders. They compile from last to first, so the last one you'll want in the list is <code class="language-text">sass-loader</code> as that needs to compile, then PostCSS, then CSS, and finally <code class="language-text">style-loader</code>, which will inject the CSS into the DOM.</p>
<div class="filename">src/index.js</div>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="js"><pre class="language-js"><code class="language-js"><span class="token keyword">import</span> <span class="token string">'./styles/main.scss'</span>

<span class="token comment">/* ... */</span></code></pre></div>
<div class="filename">webpack.config.js</div>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="js"><pre class="language-js"><code class="language-js">module<span class="token punctuation">.</span>exports <span class="token operator">=</span> <span class="token punctuation">{</span>
  <span class="token comment">/* ... */</span>
  module<span class="token operator">:</span> <span class="token punctuation">{</span>
    rules<span class="token operator">:</span> <span class="token punctuation">[</span>
<span class="gatsby-highlight-code-line">      <span class="token comment">// CSS, PostCSS, and Sass</span></span><span class="gatsby-highlight-code-line">      <span class="token punctuation">{</span></span><span class="gatsby-highlight-code-line">        test<span class="token operator">:</span> <span class="token regex"><span class="token regex-delimiter">/</span><span class="token regex-source language-regex">\.(scss|css)$</span><span class="token regex-delimiter">/</span></span><span class="token punctuation">,</span></span><span class="gatsby-highlight-code-line">        use<span class="token operator">:</span> <span class="token punctuation">[</span><span class="token string">'style-loader'</span><span class="token punctuation">,</span> <span class="token string">'css-loader'</span><span class="token punctuation">,</span> <span class="token string">'postcss-loader'</span><span class="token punctuation">,</span> <span class="token string">'sass-loader'</span><span class="token punctuation">]</span><span class="token punctuation">,</span></span><span class="gatsby-highlight-code-line">      <span class="token punctuation">}</span><span class="token punctuation">,</span></span>    <span class="token punctuation">]</span><span class="token punctuation">,</span>
  <span class="token punctuation">}</span><span class="token punctuation">,</span>
<span class="token punctuation">}</span></code></pre></div>
<p>Now when you rebuild, you'll notice the Sass and PostCSS has been applied.</p>
<blockquote>
<p><strong>Note</strong>: This is a setup for development. For production, you will use <code class="language-text">MiniCssExtractPlugin</code> instead of <code class="language-text">style-loader</code>, which will export the CSS as a minified file. You can this in the <a href="https://github.com/taniarascia/webpack-boilerplate">webpack 5 boilerplate</a>.</p>
</blockquote>
<h2 id="development" style="position:relative;"><a href="#development" aria-label="development permalink" class="anchor before"><svg aria-hidden="true" focusable="false" height="16" version="1.1" viewBox="0 0 16 16" width="16"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z"></path></svg></a>Development</h2>
<p>Running <code class="language-text">npm run build</code> every single time you make an update is tedious. The bigger your site gets, the longer it will take to build. You'll want to set up two configurations for webpack:</p>
<ul>
<li>a production config, that minifies, optimizes and removes all source maps</li>
<li>a development config, that runs webpack in a server, updates with every change, and has source maps</li>
</ul>
<p>Instead of building to a <code class="language-text">dist</code> file, the development mode will just run everything in memory.</p>
<p>To set up for development, you'll install <code class="language-text">webpack-dev-server</code>.</p>
<ul>
<li><a href="https://github.com/webpack/webpack-dev-server"><code class="language-text">webpack-dev-server</code></a> - Development server for webpack</li>
</ul>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="bash"><pre class="language-bash"><code class="language-bash"><span class="command-line-prompt"><span data-user=root data-host=localhost></span></span><span class="token function">npm</span> i -D webpack-dev-server</code></pre></div>
<p>For demonstrative purposes, we can just add the development config to the current <code class="language-text">webpack.config.js</code> file we're building and test it out. However, you'll want to create two config files: one with <code class="language-text">mode: production</code> and one with <code class="language-text">mode: development</code>. In the <a href="https://github.com/taniarascia/webpack-boilerplate">webpack 5 boilerplate</a>, I demonstrate how to use <code class="language-text">webpack-merge</code> to put all the base webpack config in one file, and any special development or production configs in a <code class="language-text">webpack.prod.js</code> and <code class="language-text">webpack.dev.js</code> files.</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="js"><pre class="language-js"><code class="language-js"><span class="token keyword">const</span> webpack <span class="token operator">=</span> <span class="token function">require</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token string">'webpack'</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span>

module<span class="token punctuation">.</span>exports <span class="token operator">=</span>  <span class="token punctuation">{</span>
  <span class="token comment">/* ... */</span>
  mode<span class="token operator">:</span> <span class="token string">'development'</span><span class="token punctuation">,</span>
  devServer<span class="token operator">:</span> <span class="token punctuation">{</span>
    historyApiFallback<span class="token operator">:</span> <span class="token boolean">true</span><span class="token punctuation">,</span>
    contentBase<span class="token operator">:</span> path<span class="token punctuation">.</span><span class="token function">resolve</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span>__dirname<span class="token punctuation">,</span> <span class="token string">'./dist'</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span><span class="token punctuation">,</span>
    open<span class="token operator">:</span> <span class="token boolean">true</span><span class="token punctuation">,</span>
    compress<span class="token operator">:</span> <span class="token boolean">true</span><span class="token punctuation">,</span>
    hot<span class="token operator">:</span> <span class="token boolean">true</span><span class="token punctuation">,</span>
    port<span class="token operator">:</span> <span class="token number">8080</span><span class="token punctuation">,</span>
  <span class="token punctuation">}</span><span class="token punctuation">,</span>

  plugins<span class="token operator">:</span> <span class="token punctuation">[</span>
    <span class="token comment">/* ... */</span>
    <span class="token comment">// Only update what has changed on hot reload</span>
    <span class="token keyword">new</span> <span class="token class-name">webpack<span class="token punctuation">.</span>HotModuleReplacementPlugin</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span><span class="token punctuation">,</span>
  <span class="token punctuation">]</span><span class="token punctuation">,</span>
<span class="token punctuation">}</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span></code></pre></div>
<p>We're adding <code class="language-text">mode: development</code>, and creating a <code class="language-text">devServer</code> property. I'm setting a few defaults on it - the port will be <code class="language-text">8080</code>, it will automatically open a browser window, and uses <a href="https://webpack.js.org/concepts/hot-module-replacement/">hot-module-replacement</a>, which requires the <code class="language-text">webpack.HotModuleReplacementPlugin</code> plugin. This will allow modules to update without doing a complete reload of the page - so if you update some styles, just those styles will change, and you won't need to reload the entirety of the JavaScript, which speeds up development a lot.</p>
<p>Now you'll use the <code class="language-text">webpack serve</code> command to set up the server.</p>
<div class="filename">package.json</div>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="json"><pre class="language-json"><code class="language-json"><span class="token property">"scripts"</span><span class="token operator">:</span> <span class="token punctuation">{</span>
  <span class="token property">"start"</span><span class="token operator">:</span> <span class="token string">"webpack serve"</span>
<span class="token punctuation">}</span></code></pre></div>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="bash"><pre class="language-bash"><code class="language-bash"><span class="command-line-prompt"><span data-user=root data-host=localhost></span></span><span class="token function">npm</span> start</code></pre></div>
<p>When you run this command, a link to <code class="language-text">localhost:8080</code> will automatically pop up in your browser. Now you can update Sass and JavaScript and watch it update on the fly.</p>
<h2 id="conclusion" style="position:relative;"><a href="#conclusion" aria-label="conclusion permalink" class="anchor before"><svg aria-hidden="true" focusable="false" height="16" version="1.1" viewBox="0 0 16 16" width="16"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z"></path></svg></a>Conclusion</h2>
<p>That should help you get started with webpack. Once again, I've created a production-ready webpack 5 boilerplate, with Babel, Sass, PostCSS, production optimization, and a development server, that has everything from this article but goes into more details. From here, you can easily set up React, Vue, Typescript, or anything else you might want.</p>
<ul>
<li><a href="https://github.com/taniarascia/webpack-boilerplate">webpack 5 boilerplate</a></li>
</ul>
<p>Check it out, play around with it, and enjoy!</p></content:encoded><author>hello@taniarascia.com</author></item><item><title><![CDATA[Understanding the Event Loop, Callbacks, Promises, and Async/Await in JavaScript]]></title><description><![CDATA[This article was originally written for DigitalOcean. Introduction In the early days of the internet, websites often consisted of static…]]></description><link>https://www.taniarascia.com/asynchronous-javascript-event-loop-callbacks-promises-async-await/</link><guid isPermaLink="false">https://www.taniarascia.com/asynchronous-javascript-event-loop-callbacks-promises-async-await/</guid><pubDate>Thu, 10 Sep 2020 00:00:00 GMT</pubDate><content:encoded><p><em>This article was originally written for <a href="https://www.digitalocean.com/community/tutorials/understanding-the-event-loop-callbacks-promises-and-async-await-in-javascript">DigitalOcean</a>.</em></p>
<h3 id="introduction" style="position:relative;"><a href="#introduction" aria-label="introduction permalink" class="anchor before"><svg aria-hidden="true" focusable="false" height="16" version="1.1" viewBox="0 0 16 16" width="16"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z"></path></svg></a>Introduction</h3>
<p>In the early days of the internet, websites often consisted of static data in an <a href="https://www.digitalocean.com/community/tutorial_series/how-to-build-a-website-with-html">HTML page</a>. But now that web applications have become more interactive and dynamic, it has become increasingly necessary to do intensive operations like make external network requests to retrieve <a href="https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Glossary/API">API</a> data. To handle these operations in JavaScript, a developer must use <em>asynchronous programming</em> techniques.</p>
<p>Since JavaScript is a <em>single-threaded</em> programming language with a <em>synchronous</em> execution model that proccesses one operation after another, it can only process one statement at a time. However, an action like requesting data from an API can take an indeterminate amount of time, depending on the size of data being requested, the speed of the network connection, and other factors. If API calls were performed in a synchronous manner, the browser would not be able to handle any user input, like scrolling or clicking a button, until that operation completes. This is known as <em>blocking</em>.</p>
<p>In order to prevent blocking behavior, the browser environment has many Web APIs that JavaScript can access that are <em>asynchronous</em>, meaning they can run in parallel with other operations instead of sequentially. This is useful because it allows the user to continue using the browser normally while the asynchronous operations are being processed.</p>
<p>As a JavaScript developer, you need to know how to work with asynchronous Web APIs and handle the response or error of those operations. In this article, you will learn about the event loop, the original way of dealing with asynchronous behavior through callbacks, the updated <a href="http://www.ecma-international.org/ecma-262/6.0/">ECMAScript 2015</a> addition of promises, and the modern practice of using <code class="language-text">async</code>/<code class="language-text">await</code>.</p>
<blockquote>
<p><strong>Note</strong>: This article is focused on client-side JavaScript in the browser environment. The same concepts are generally true in the <a href="https://nodejs.org/">Node.js</a> environment, however Node.js uses its own <a href="https://nodejs.org/api/">C++ APIs</a> as opposed to the browser's <a href="https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API">Web APIs</a>. For more information on asynchronous programming in Node.js, check out <a href="https://www.digitalocean.com/community/tutorials/how-to-write-asynchronous-code-in-node-js">How To Write Asynchronous Code in Node.js</a>.</p>
</blockquote>
<h3 id="contents" style="position:relative;"><a href="#contents" aria-label="contents permalink" class="anchor before"><svg aria-hidden="true" focusable="false" height="16" version="1.1" viewBox="0 0 16 16" width="16"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z"></path></svg></a>Contents</h3>
<ul>
<li><a href="#the-event-loop">The Event Loop</a></li>
<li><a href="#callback-functions">Callback Functions</a>
<ul>
<li><a href="#nested-callbacks-and-the-pyramid-of-doom">Nested Callbacks and the Pyramid of Doom</a></li>
</ul>
</li>
<li><a href="#nested-callbacks-and-the-pyramid-of-doom">Promises</a></li>
<li><a href="#async-functions-with-asyncawait">Async Functions with <code class="language-text">async</code>/<code class="language-text">await</code></a></li>
</ul>
<h2 id="the-event-loop" style="position:relative;"><a href="#the-event-loop" aria-label="the event loop permalink" class="anchor before"><svg aria-hidden="true" focusable="false" height="16" version="1.1" viewBox="0 0 16 16" width="16"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z"></path></svg></a>The Event Loop</h2>
<p>This section will explain how JavaScript handles asynchronous code with the event loop. It will first run through a demonstration of the event loop at work, and will then explain the two elements of the event loop: the stack and the queue.</p>
<p>JavaScript code that does not use any asynchronous Web APIs will execute in a synchronous manner—one at a time, sequentially. This is demonstrated by this example code that calls three functions that each print a number to the <a href="https://www.digitalocean.com/community/tutorials/how-to-use-the-javascript-developer-console">console</a>:</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="js"><pre class="language-js"><code class="language-js"><span class="token comment">// Define three example functions</span>
<span class="token keyword">function</span> <span class="token function">first</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span> <span class="token punctuation">{</span>
  console<span class="token punctuation">.</span><span class="token function">log</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token number">1</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span>
<span class="token punctuation">}</span>

<span class="token keyword">function</span> <span class="token function">second</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span> <span class="token punctuation">{</span>
  console<span class="token punctuation">.</span><span class="token function">log</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token number">2</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span>
<span class="token punctuation">}</span>

<span class="token keyword">function</span> <span class="token function">third</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span> <span class="token punctuation">{</span>
  console<span class="token punctuation">.</span><span class="token function">log</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token number">3</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span>
<span class="token punctuation">}</span></code></pre></div>
<p>In this code, you define three functions that print numbers with <code class="language-text">console.log()</code>.</p>
<p>Next, write calls to the functions:</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="js"><pre class="language-js"><code class="language-js"><span class="token comment">// Execute the functions</span>
<span class="token function">first</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span>
<span class="token function">second</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span>
<span class="token function">third</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span></code></pre></div>
<p>The output will be based on the order the functions were called: <code class="language-text">first()</code>, <code class="language-text">second()</code>, then <code class="language-text">third()</code>.</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="terminal"><pre class="language-terminal"><code class="language-terminal">1
2
3</code></pre></div>
<p>When an asynchronous Web API is used, the rules become more complicated. A built-in API that you can test this with is <code class="language-text">setTimeout</code>, which sets a timer and performs an action after a specified amount of time. <code class="language-text">setTimeout</code> needs to be asynchronous, otherwise the entire browser would remain frozen during the waiting, which would result in a poor user experience.</p>
<p>Add <code class="language-text">setTimeout</code> to the <code class="language-text">second</code> function to simulate an asynchronous request:</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="js"><pre class="language-js"><code class="language-js"><span class="token comment">// Define three example functions, but one of them contains asynchronous code</span>
<span class="token keyword">function</span> <span class="token function">first</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span> <span class="token punctuation">{</span>
  console<span class="token punctuation">.</span><span class="token function">log</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token number">1</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span>
<span class="token punctuation">}</span>

<span class="token keyword">function</span> <span class="token function">second</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span> <span class="token punctuation">{</span>
  <span class="token function">setTimeout</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span> <span class="token operator">=></span> <span class="token punctuation">{</span>
    console<span class="token punctuation">.</span><span class="token function">log</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token number">2</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span>
  <span class="token punctuation">}</span><span class="token punctuation">,</span> <span class="token number">0</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span>
<span class="token punctuation">}</span>

<span class="token keyword">function</span> <span class="token function">third</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span> <span class="token punctuation">{</span>
  console<span class="token punctuation">.</span><span class="token function">log</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token number">3</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span>
<span class="token punctuation">}</span></code></pre></div>
<p><code class="language-text">setTimeout</code> takes two arguments: the function it will run asynchronously, and the amount of time it will wait before calling that function. In this code you wrapped <code class="language-text">console.log</code> in an anonymous function and passed it to <code class="language-text">setTimeout</code>, then set the function to run after <code class="language-text">0</code> milliseconds.</p>
<p>Now call the functions, as you did before:</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="js"><pre class="language-js"><code class="language-js"><span class="token comment">// Execute the functions</span>
<span class="token function">first</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span>
<span class="token function">second</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span>
<span class="token function">third</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span></code></pre></div>
<p>You might expect with a <code class="language-text">setTimeout</code> set to <code class="language-text">0</code> that running these three functions would still result in the numbers being printed in sequential order. But because it is asynchronous, the function with the timeout will be printed last:</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="terminal"><pre class="language-terminal"><code class="language-terminal">1
3
2</code></pre></div>
<p>Whether you set the timeout to zero seconds or five minutes will make no difference—the <code class="language-text">console.log</code> called by asynchronous code will execute after the synchronous top-level functions. This happens because the JavaScript host environment, in this case the browser, uses a concept called the <em>event loop</em> to handle concurrency, or parallel events. Since JavaScript can only execute one statement at a time, it needs the event loop to be informed of when to execute which specific statement. The event loop handles this with the concepts of a <em>stack</em> and a <em>queue</em>.</p>
<h3 id="stack" style="position:relative;"><a href="#stack" aria-label="stack permalink" class="anchor before"><svg aria-hidden="true" focusable="false" height="16" version="1.1" viewBox="0 0 16 16" width="16"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z"></path></svg></a>Stack</h3>
<p>The <em>stack</em>, or call stack, holds the state of what function is currently running. If you're unfamiliar with the concept of a stack, you can imagine it as an <a href="https://www.digitalocean.com/community/tutorials/understanding-arrays-in-javascript">array</a> with "Last in, first out" (LIFO) properties, meaning you can only add or remove items from the end of the stack. JavaScript will run the current <em>frame</em> (or function call in a specific environment) in the stack, then remove it and move on to the next one.</p>
<p>For the example only containing synchronous code, the browser handles the execution in the following order:</p>
<ul>
<li>Add <code class="language-text">first()</code> to the stack, run <code class="language-text">first()</code> which logs <code class="language-text">1</code> to the console, remove <code class="language-text">first()</code> from the stack.</li>
<li>Add <code class="language-text">second()</code> to the stack, run <code class="language-text">second()</code> which logs <code class="language-text">2</code> to the console, remove <code class="language-text">second()</code> from the stack.</li>
<li>Add <code class="language-text">third()</code> to the stack, run <code class="language-text">third()</code> which logs <code class="language-text">3</code> to the console, remove <code class="language-text">third()</code> from the stack.</li>
</ul>
<p>The second example with <code class="language-text">setTimout</code> looks like this:</p>
<ul>
<li>Add <code class="language-text">first()</code> to the stack, run <code class="language-text">first()</code> which logs <code class="language-text">1</code> to the console, remove <code class="language-text">first()</code> from the stack.</li>
<li>Add <code class="language-text">second()</code> to the stack, run <code class="language-text">second()</code>.
<ul>
<li>Add <code class="language-text">setTimeout()</code> to the stack, run the <code class="language-text">setTimeout()</code> Web API which starts a timer and adds the anonymous function to the <em>queue</em>, remove <code class="language-text">setTimeout()</code> from the stack.</li>
</ul>
</li>
<li>Remove <code class="language-text">second()</code> from the stack.</li>
<li>Add <code class="language-text">third()</code> to the stack, run <code class="language-text">third()</code> which logs <code class="language-text">3</code> to the console, remove <code class="language-text">third()</code> from the stack.</li>
<li>The event loop checks the queue for any pending messages and finds the anonymous function from <code class="language-text">setTimeout()</code>, adds the function to the stack which logs <code class="language-text">2</code> to the console, then removes it from the stack.</li>
</ul>
<p>Using <code class="language-text">setTimeout</code>, an asynchronous Web API, introduces the concept of the <em>queue</em>, which this tutorial will cover next.</p>
<h3 id="queue" style="position:relative;"><a href="#queue" aria-label="queue permalink" class="anchor before"><svg aria-hidden="true" focusable="false" height="16" version="1.1" viewBox="0 0 16 16" width="16"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z"></path></svg></a>Queue</h3>
<p>The <em>queue</em>, also referred to as message queue or task queue, is a waiting area for functions. Whenever the call stack is empty, the event loop will check the queue for any waiting messages, starting from the oldest message. Once it finds one, it will add it to the stack, which will execute the function in the message.</p>
<p>In the <code class="language-text">setTimeout</code> example, the anonymous function runs immediately after the rest of the top-level execution, since the timer was set to <code class="language-text">0</code> seconds. It's important to remember that the timer does not mean that the code will execute in exactly <code class="language-text">0</code> seconds or whatever the specified time is, but that it will add the anonymous function to the queue in that amount of time. This queue system exists because if the timer were to add the anonymous function directly to the stack when the timer finishes, it would interrupt whatever function is currently running, which could have unintended and unpredictable effects.</p>
<blockquote>
<p><strong>Note:</strong> There is also another queue called the <em>job queue</em> or <em>microtask queue</em> that handles promises. Microtasks like promises are handled at a higher priority than macrotasks like <code class="language-text">setTimeout</code>.</p>
</blockquote>
<p>Now you know how the event loop uses the stack and queue to handle the execution order of code. The next task is to figure out how to control the order of execution in your code. To do this, you will first learn about the original way to ensure asynchrnous code is handled correctly by the event loop: callback functions.</p>
<h2 id="callback-functions" style="position:relative;"><a href="#callback-functions" aria-label="callback functions permalink" class="anchor before"><svg aria-hidden="true" focusable="false" height="16" version="1.1" viewBox="0 0 16 16" width="16"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z"></path></svg></a>Callback Functions</h2>
<p>In the <code class="language-text">setTimeout</code> example, the function with the timeout ran after everything in the main top-level execution context. But if you wanted to ensure one of the functions, like the <code class="language-text">third</code> function, ran after the timeout, then you would have to use asynchronous coding methods. The timeout here can represent an asynchronous API call that contains data. You want to work with the data from the API call, but you have to make sure the data is returned first.</p>
<p>The original solution to dealing with this problem is using <em>callback functions</em>. Callback functions do not have special syntax; they are just a function that has been passed as an argument to another function. The function that takes another function as an argument is called a <em>higher-order function</em>. According to this definition, any function can become a callback function if it is passed as an argument. Callbacks are not asynchronous by nature, but can be used for asynchronous purposes.</p>
<p>Here is a syntactic code example of a higher-order function and a callback:</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="js"><pre class="language-js"><code class="language-js"><span class="token comment">// A function</span>
<span class="token keyword">function</span> <span class="token function">fn</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span> <span class="token punctuation">{</span>
  console<span class="token punctuation">.</span><span class="token function">log</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token string">'Just a function'</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span>
<span class="token punctuation">}</span>

<span class="token comment">// A function that takes another function as an argument</span>
<span class="token keyword">function</span> <span class="token function">higherOrderFunction</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token parameter">callback</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span> <span class="token punctuation">{</span>
  <span class="token comment">// When you call a function that is passed as an argument, it is referred to as a callback</span>
  <span class="token function">callback</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span>
<span class="token punctuation">}</span>

<span class="token comment">// Passing a function</span>
<span class="token function">higherOrderFunction</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span>fn<span class="token punctuation">)</span></code></pre></div>
<p>In this code, you define a function <code class="language-text">fn</code>, define a function <code class="language-text">higherOrderFunction</code> that takes a function <code class="language-text">callback</code> as an argument, and pass <code class="language-text">fn</code> as a callback to <code class="language-text">higherOrderFunction</code>.</p>
<p>Running this code will give the following:</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="terminal"><pre class="language-terminal"><code class="language-terminal">Just a function</code></pre></div>
<p>Let's go back to the <code class="language-text">first</code>, <code class="language-text">second</code>, and <code class="language-text">third</code> functions with <code class="language-text">setTimeout</code>. This is what you have so far:</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="js"><pre class="language-js"><code class="language-js"><span class="token keyword">function</span> <span class="token function">first</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span> <span class="token punctuation">{</span>
  console<span class="token punctuation">.</span><span class="token function">log</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token number">1</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span>
<span class="token punctuation">}</span>

<span class="token keyword">function</span> <span class="token function">second</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span> <span class="token punctuation">{</span>
  <span class="token function">setTimeout</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span> <span class="token operator">=></span> <span class="token punctuation">{</span>
    console<span class="token punctuation">.</span><span class="token function">log</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token number">2</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span>
  <span class="token punctuation">}</span><span class="token punctuation">,</span> <span class="token number">0</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span>
<span class="token punctuation">}</span>

<span class="token keyword">function</span> <span class="token function">third</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span> <span class="token punctuation">{</span>
  console<span class="token punctuation">.</span><span class="token function">log</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token number">3</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span>
<span class="token punctuation">}</span></code></pre></div>
<p>The task is to get the <code class="language-text">third</code> function to always delay execution until after the asynchronous action in the <code class="language-text">second</code> function has completed. This is where callbacks come in. Instead of executing <code class="language-text">first</code>, <code class="language-text">second</code>, and <code class="language-text">third</code> at the top-level of execution, you will pass the <code class="language-text">third</code> function as an argument to <code class="language-text">second</code>. The <code class="language-text">second</code> function will execute the callback after the asynchronous action has completed.</p>
<p>Here are the three functions with a callback applied:</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="js"><pre class="language-js"><code class="language-js"><span class="token comment">// Define three functions</span>
<span class="token keyword">function</span> <span class="token function">first</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span> <span class="token punctuation">{</span>
  console<span class="token punctuation">.</span><span class="token function">log</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token number">1</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span>
<span class="token punctuation">}</span>

<span class="gatsby-highlight-code-line"><span class="token keyword">function</span> <span class="token function">second</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token parameter">callback</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span> <span class="token punctuation">{</span></span>  <span class="token function">setTimeout</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span> <span class="token operator">=></span> <span class="token punctuation">{</span>
    console<span class="token punctuation">.</span><span class="token function">log</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token number">2</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span>

    <span class="token comment">// Execute the callback function</span>
<span class="gatsby-highlight-code-line">    <span class="token function">callback</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span></span>  <span class="token punctuation">}</span><span class="token punctuation">,</span> <span class="token number">0</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span>
<span class="token punctuation">}</span>

<span class="token keyword">function</span> <span class="token function">third</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span> <span class="token punctuation">{</span>
  console<span class="token punctuation">.</span><span class="token function">log</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token number">3</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span>
<span class="token punctuation">}</span></code></pre></div>
<p>Now, execute <code class="language-text">first</code> and <code class="language-text">second</code>, then pass <code class="language-text">third</code> as an argument to <code class="language-text">second</code>:</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="js"><pre class="language-js"><code class="language-js"><span class="token function">first</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span>
<span class="token function">second</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span>third<span class="token punctuation">)</span></code></pre></div>
<p>After running this code block, you will receive the following output:</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="terminal"><pre class="language-terminal"><code class="language-terminal">1
2
3</code></pre></div>
<p>First <code class="language-text">1</code> will print, and after the timer completes (in this case, zero seconds, but you can change it to any amount) it will print <code class="language-text">2</code> then <code class="language-text">3</code>. By passing a function as a callback, you've successfully delayed execution of the function until the asynchronous Web API (<code class="language-text">setTimeout</code>) completes.</p>
<p>The key takeaway here is that callback functions are not asynchronous—<code class="language-text">setTimeout</code> is the asynchronous Web API responsible for handling asynchronous tasks. The callback just allows you to be informed of when an asynchronous task has completed and handles the success or failure of the task.</p>
<p>Now that you have learned how to use callbacks to handle asynchronous tasks, the next section explains the problems of nesting too many callbacks and creating a "pyramid of doom."</p>
<h2 id="nested-callbacks-and-the-pyramid-of-doom" style="position:relative;"><a href="#nested-callbacks-and-the-pyramid-of-doom" aria-label="nested callbacks and the pyramid of doom permalink" class="anchor before"><svg aria-hidden="true" focusable="false" height="16" version="1.1" viewBox="0 0 16 16" width="16"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z"></path></svg></a>Nested Callbacks and the Pyramid of Doom</h2>
<p>Callback functions are an effective way to ensure delayed execution of a function until another one completes and returns with data. However, due to the nested nature of callbacks, code can end up getting messy if you have a lot of consecutive asynchronous requests that rely on each other. This was a big frustration for JavaScript developers early on, and as a result code containing nested callbacks is often called the "pyramid of doom" or "callback hell."</p>
<p>Here is a demonstration of nested callbacks:</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="js"><pre class="language-js"><code class="language-js"><span class="token keyword">function</span> <span class="token function">pyramidOfDoom</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span> <span class="token punctuation">{</span>
  <span class="token function">setTimeout</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span> <span class="token operator">=></span> <span class="token punctuation">{</span>
    console<span class="token punctuation">.</span><span class="token function">log</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token number">1</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span>
    <span class="token function">setTimeout</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span> <span class="token operator">=></span> <span class="token punctuation">{</span>
      console<span class="token punctuation">.</span><span class="token function">log</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token number">2</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span>
      <span class="token function">setTimeout</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span> <span class="token operator">=></span> <span class="token punctuation">{</span>
        console<span class="token punctuation">.</span><span class="token function">log</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token number">3</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span>
      <span class="token punctuation">}</span><span class="token punctuation">,</span> <span class="token number">500</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span>
    <span class="token punctuation">}</span><span class="token punctuation">,</span> <span class="token number">2000</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span>
  <span class="token punctuation">}</span><span class="token punctuation">,</span> <span class="token number">1000</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span>
<span class="token punctuation">}</span></code></pre></div>
<p>In this code, each new <code class="language-text">setTimeout</code> is nested inside a higher order function, creating a pyramid shape of deeper and deeper callbacks. Running this code would give the following:</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="terminal"><pre class="language-terminal"><code class="language-terminal">1
2
3</code></pre></div>
<p>In practice, with real world asynchronous code, this can get much more complicated. You will most likely need to do error handling in asynchronous code, and then pass some data from each response onto the next request. Doing this with callbacks will make your code difficult to read and maintain.</p>
<p>Here is a runnable example of a more realistic "pyramid of doom" that you can play around with:</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="js"><pre class="language-js"><code class="language-js"><span class="token comment">// Example asynchronous function</span>
<span class="token keyword">function</span> <span class="token function">asynchronousRequest</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token parameter">args<span class="token punctuation">,</span> callback</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span> <span class="token punctuation">{</span>
  <span class="token comment">// Throw an error if no arguments are passed</span>
  <span class="token keyword">if</span> <span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token operator">!</span>args<span class="token punctuation">)</span> <span class="token punctuation">{</span>
    <span class="token keyword">return</span> <span class="token function">callback</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token keyword">new</span> <span class="token class-name">Error</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token string">'Whoa! Something went wrong.'</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span>
  <span class="token punctuation">}</span> <span class="token keyword">else</span> <span class="token punctuation">{</span>
    <span class="token keyword">return</span> <span class="token function">setTimeout</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span>
      <span class="token comment">// Just adding in a random number so it seems like the contrived asynchronous function</span>
      <span class="token comment">// returned different data</span>
      <span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span> <span class="token operator">=></span> <span class="token function">callback</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token keyword">null</span><span class="token punctuation">,</span> <span class="token punctuation">{</span> body<span class="token operator">:</span> args <span class="token operator">+</span> <span class="token string">' '</span> <span class="token operator">+</span> Math<span class="token punctuation">.</span><span class="token function">floor</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span>Math<span class="token punctuation">.</span><span class="token function">random</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span> <span class="token operator">*</span> <span class="token number">10</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span> <span class="token punctuation">}</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span><span class="token punctuation">,</span>
      <span class="token number">500</span>
    <span class="token punctuation">)</span>
  <span class="token punctuation">}</span>
<span class="token punctuation">}</span>

<span class="token comment">// Nested asynchronous requests</span>
<span class="token keyword">function</span> <span class="token function">callbackHell</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span> <span class="token punctuation">{</span>
  <span class="token function">asynchronousRequest</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token string">'First'</span><span class="token punctuation">,</span> <span class="token keyword">function</span> <span class="token function">first</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token parameter">error<span class="token punctuation">,</span> response</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span> <span class="token punctuation">{</span>
    <span class="token keyword">if</span> <span class="token punctuation">(</span>error<span class="token punctuation">)</span> <span class="token punctuation">{</span>
      console<span class="token punctuation">.</span><span class="token function">log</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span>error<span class="token punctuation">)</span>
      <span class="token keyword">return</span>
    <span class="token punctuation">}</span>
    console<span class="token punctuation">.</span><span class="token function">log</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span>response<span class="token punctuation">.</span>body<span class="token punctuation">)</span>
    <span class="token function">asynchronousRequest</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token string">'Second'</span><span class="token punctuation">,</span> <span class="token keyword">function</span> <span class="token function">second</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token parameter">error<span class="token punctuation">,</span> response</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span> <span class="token punctuation">{</span>
      <span class="token keyword">if</span> <span class="token punctuation">(</span>error<span class="token punctuation">)</span> <span class="token punctuation">{</span>
        console<span class="token punctuation">.</span><span class="token function">log</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span>error<span class="token punctuation">)</span>
        <span class="token keyword">return</span>
      <span class="token punctuation">}</span>
      console<span class="token punctuation">.</span><span class="token function">log</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span>response<span class="token punctuation">.</span>body<span class="token punctuation">)</span>
      <span class="token function">asynchronousRequest</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token keyword">null</span><span class="token punctuation">,</span> <span class="token keyword">function</span> <span class="token function">third</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token parameter">error<span class="token punctuation">,</span> response</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span> <span class="token punctuation">{</span>
        <span class="token keyword">if</span> <span class="token punctuation">(</span>error<span class="token punctuation">)</span> <span class="token punctuation">{</span>
          console<span class="token punctuation">.</span><span class="token function">log</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span>error<span class="token punctuation">)</span>
          <span class="token keyword">return</span>
        <span class="token punctuation">}</span>
        console<span class="token punctuation">.</span><span class="token function">log</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span>response<span class="token punctuation">.</span>body<span class="token punctuation">)</span>
      <span class="token punctuation">}</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span>
    <span class="token punctuation">}</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span>
  <span class="token punctuation">}</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span>
<span class="token punctuation">}</span>

<span class="token comment">// Execute</span>
<span class="token function">callbackHell</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span></code></pre></div>
<p>In this code, you must make every function account for a possible <code class="language-text">response</code> and a possible <code class="language-text">error</code>, making the function <code class="language-text">callbackHell</code> visually confusing.</p>
<p>Running this code will give you the following:</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="terminal"><pre class="language-terminal"><code class="language-terminal">First 9
Second 3
Error: Whoa! Something went wrong.
    at asynchronousRequest (&lt;anonymous&gt;:4:21)
    at second (&lt;anonymous&gt;:29:7)
    at &lt;anonymous&gt;:9:13</code></pre></div>
<p>This way of handling asynchronous code is difficult to follow. As a result, the concept of <em>promises</em> was introduced in ES6. This is the focus of the next section.</p>
<h2 id="promises" style="position:relative;"><a href="#promises" aria-label="promises permalink" class="anchor before"><svg aria-hidden="true" focusable="false" height="16" version="1.1" viewBox="0 0 16 16" width="16"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z"></path></svg></a>Promises</h2>
<p>A <em>promise</em> represents the completion of an asynchronous function. It is an object that might return a value in the future. It accomplishes the same basic goal as a callback function, but with many additional features and a more readable syntax. As a JavaScript developer, you will likely spend more time consuming promises than creating them, as it is usually asynchronous Web APIs that return a promise for the developer to consume. This tutorial will show you how to do both.</p>
<h3 id="creating-a-promise" style="position:relative;"><a href="#creating-a-promise" aria-label="creating a promise permalink" class="anchor before"><svg aria-hidden="true" focusable="false" height="16" version="1.1" viewBox="0 0 16 16" width="16"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z"></path></svg></a>Creating a Promise</h3>
<p>You can initialize a promise with the <code class="language-text">new Promise</code> syntax, and you must initialize it with a function. The function that gets passed to a promise has <code class="language-text">resolve</code> and <code class="language-text">reject</code> parameters. The <code class="language-text">resolve</code> and <code class="language-text">reject</code> functions handle the success and failure of an operation, respectively.</p>
<p>Write the following line to declare a promise:</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="js"><pre class="language-js"><code class="language-js"><span class="token comment">// Initialize a promise</span>
<span class="token keyword">const</span> promise <span class="token operator">=</span> <span class="token keyword">new</span> <span class="token class-name">Promise</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token parameter">resolve<span class="token punctuation">,</span> reject</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span> <span class="token operator">=></span> <span class="token punctuation">{</span><span class="token punctuation">}</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span></code></pre></div>
<p>If you inspect the initialized promise in this state with your web browser's console, you will find it has a <code class="language-text">pending</code> status and <code class="language-text">undefined</code> value:</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="terminal"><pre class="language-terminal"><code class="language-terminal">__proto__: Promise
[[PromiseStatus]]: &quot;pending&quot;
[[PromiseValue]]: undefined</code></pre></div>
<p>So far, nothing has been set up for the promise, so it's going to sit there in a <code class="language-text">pending</code> state forever. The first thing you can do to test out a promise is fulfill the promise by resolving it with a value:</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="js"><pre class="language-js"><code class="language-js"><span class="token keyword">const</span> promise <span class="token operator">=</span> <span class="token keyword">new</span> <span class="token class-name">Promise</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token parameter">resolve<span class="token punctuation">,</span> reject</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span> <span class="token operator">=></span> <span class="token punctuation">{</span>
<span class="gatsby-highlight-code-line">  <span class="token function">resolve</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token string">'We did it!'</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span></span><span class="token punctuation">}</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span></code></pre></div>
<p>Now, upon inspecting the promise, you'll find that it has a status of <code class="language-text">fulfilled</code>, and a <code class="language-text">value</code> set to the value you passed to <code class="language-text">resolve</code>:</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="terminal"><pre class="language-terminal"><code class="language-terminal">__proto__: Promise
[[PromiseStatus]]: &quot;fulfilled&quot;
[[PromiseValue]]: &quot;We did it!&quot;</code></pre></div>
<p>As stated in the beginning of this section, a promise is an object that may return a value. After being successfully fulfilled, the <code class="language-text">value</code> goes from <code class="language-text">undefined</code> to being populated with data.</p>
<p>A promise can have three possible states: pending, fulfilled, and rejected.</p>
<ul>
<li><strong>Pending</strong> - Initial state before being resolved or rejected</li>
<li><strong>Fulfilled</strong> - Successful operation, promise has resolved</li>
<li><strong>Rejected</strong> - Failed operation, promise has rejected</li>
</ul>
<p>After being fulfilled or rejected, a promise is settled.</p>
<p>Now that you have an idea of how promises are created, let's look at how a developer may consume these promises.</p>
<h3 id="consuming-a-promise" style="position:relative;"><a href="#consuming-a-promise" aria-label="consuming a promise permalink" class="anchor before"><svg aria-hidden="true" focusable="false" height="16" version="1.1" viewBox="0 0 16 16" width="16"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z"></path></svg></a>Consuming a Promise</h3>
<p>The promise in the last section has fulfilled with a value, but you also want to be able to access the value. Promises have a method called <code class="language-text">then</code> that will run after a promise reaches <code class="language-text">resolve</code> in the code. <code class="language-text">then</code> will return the promise's value as a parameter.</p>
<p>This is how you would return and log the <code class="language-text">value</code> of the example promise:</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="js"><pre class="language-js"><code class="language-js">promise<span class="token punctuation">.</span><span class="token function">then</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token parameter">response</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span> <span class="token operator">=></span> <span class="token punctuation">{</span>
  console<span class="token punctuation">.</span><span class="token function">log</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span>response<span class="token punctuation">)</span>
<span class="token punctuation">}</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span></code></pre></div>
<p>The promise you created had a <code class="language-text">[[PromiseValue]]</code> of <code class="language-text">We did it!</code>. This value is what will be passed into the anonymous function as <code class="language-text">response</code>:</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="terminal"><pre class="language-terminal"><code class="language-terminal">We did it!</code></pre></div>
<p>So far, the example you created did not involve an asynchronous Web API—it only explained how to create, resolve, and consume a native JavaScript promise. Using <code class="language-text">setTimeout</code>, you can test out an asynchronous request.</p>
<p>The following code simulates data returned from an asynchronous request as a promise:</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="js"><pre class="language-js"><code class="language-js"><span class="token keyword">const</span> promise <span class="token operator">=</span> <span class="token keyword">new</span> <span class="token class-name">Promise</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token parameter">resolve<span class="token punctuation">,</span> reject</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span> <span class="token operator">=></span> <span class="token punctuation">{</span>
  <span class="token function">setTimeout</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span> <span class="token operator">=></span> <span class="token function">resolve</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token string">'Resolving an asynchronous request!'</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span><span class="token punctuation">,</span> <span class="token number">2000</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span>
<span class="token punctuation">}</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span>

<span class="token comment">// Log the result</span>
promise<span class="token punctuation">.</span><span class="token function">then</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token parameter">response</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span> <span class="token operator">=></span> <span class="token punctuation">{</span>
  console<span class="token punctuation">.</span><span class="token function">log</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span>response<span class="token punctuation">)</span>
<span class="token punctuation">}</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span></code></pre></div>
<p>Using the <code class="language-text">then</code> syntax ensures that the <code class="language-text">response</code> will be logged only when the <code class="language-text">setTimeout</code> operation is completed after <code class="language-text">2000</code> milliseconds. All this is done without nesting callbacks.</p>
<p>Now after two seconds, it will resolve the promise value and it will get logged in <code class="language-text">then</code>:</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="terminal"><pre class="language-terminal"><code class="language-terminal">Resolving an asynchronous request!</code></pre></div>
<p>Promises can also be chained to pass along data to more than one asynchronous operation. If a value is returned in <code class="language-text">then</code>, another <code class="language-text">then</code> can be added that will fulfill with the return value of the previous <code class="language-text">then</code>:</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="js"><pre class="language-js"><code class="language-js"><span class="token comment">// Chain a promise</span>
promise
  <span class="token punctuation">.</span><span class="token function">then</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token parameter">firstResponse</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span> <span class="token operator">=></span> <span class="token punctuation">{</span>
    <span class="token comment">// Return a new value for the next then</span>
    <span class="token keyword">return</span> firstResponse <span class="token operator">+</span> <span class="token string">' And chaining!'</span>
  <span class="token punctuation">}</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span>
  <span class="token punctuation">.</span><span class="token function">then</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token parameter">secondResponse</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span> <span class="token operator">=></span> <span class="token punctuation">{</span>
    console<span class="token punctuation">.</span><span class="token function">log</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span>secondResponse<span class="token punctuation">)</span>
  <span class="token punctuation">}</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span></code></pre></div>
<p>The fulfilled response in the second <code class="language-text">then</code> will log the return value:</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="terminal"><pre class="language-terminal"><code class="language-terminal">Resolving an asynchronous request! And chaining!</code></pre></div>
<p>Since <code class="language-text">then</code> can be chained, it allows the consumption of promises to appear more synchronous than callbacks, as they do not need to be nested. This will allow for more readable code that can be maintained and verified easier.</p>
<h3 id="error-handling" style="position:relative;"><a href="#error-handling" aria-label="error handling permalink" class="anchor before"><svg aria-hidden="true" focusable="false" height="16" version="1.1" viewBox="0 0 16 16" width="16"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z"></path></svg></a>Error Handling</h3>
<p>So far, you have only handled a promise with a successful <code class="language-text">resolve</code>, which puts the promise in a <code class="language-text">fulfilled</code> state. But frequently with an asynchronous request you also have to handle an error—if the API is down, or a malformed or unauthorized request is sent. A promise should be able to handle both cases. In this section, you will create a function to test out both the success and error case of creating and consuming a promise.</p>
<p>This <code class="language-text">getUsers</code> function will pass a flag to a promise, and return the promise.</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="js"><pre class="language-js"><code class="language-js"><span class="token keyword">function</span> <span class="token function">getUsers</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token parameter">onSuccess</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span> <span class="token punctuation">{</span>
  <span class="token keyword">return</span> <span class="token keyword">new</span> <span class="token class-name">Promise</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token parameter">resolve<span class="token punctuation">,</span> reject</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span> <span class="token operator">=></span> <span class="token punctuation">{</span>
    <span class="token function">setTimeout</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span> <span class="token operator">=></span> <span class="token punctuation">{</span>
      <span class="token comment">// Handle resolve and reject in the asynchronous API</span>
    <span class="token punctuation">}</span><span class="token punctuation">,</span> <span class="token number">1000</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span>
  <span class="token punctuation">}</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span>
<span class="token punctuation">}</span></code></pre></div>
<p>Set up the code so that if <code class="language-text">onSuccess</code> is <code class="language-text">true</code>, the timeout will fulfill with some data. If <code class="language-text">false</code>, the function will reject with an error.</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="js"><pre class="language-js"><code class="language-js"><span class="token keyword">function</span> <span class="token function">getUsers</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token parameter">onSuccess</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span> <span class="token punctuation">{</span>
  <span class="token keyword">return</span> <span class="token keyword">new</span> <span class="token class-name">Promise</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token parameter">resolve<span class="token punctuation">,</span> reject</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span> <span class="token operator">=></span> <span class="token punctuation">{</span>
    <span class="token function">setTimeout</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span> <span class="token operator">=></span> <span class="token punctuation">{</span>
      <span class="token comment">// Handle resolve and reject in the asynchronous API</span>
<span class="gatsby-highlight-code-line">      <span class="token keyword">if</span> <span class="token punctuation">(</span>onSuccess<span class="token punctuation">)</span> <span class="token punctuation">{</span></span><span class="gatsby-highlight-code-line">        <span class="token function">resolve</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token punctuation">[</span></span><span class="gatsby-highlight-code-line">          <span class="token punctuation">{</span> id<span class="token operator">:</span> <span class="token number">1</span><span class="token punctuation">,</span> name<span class="token operator">:</span> <span class="token string">'Jerry'</span> <span class="token punctuation">}</span><span class="token punctuation">,</span></span><span class="gatsby-highlight-code-line">          <span class="token punctuation">{</span> id<span class="token operator">:</span> <span class="token number">2</span><span class="token punctuation">,</span> name<span class="token operator">:</span> <span class="token string">'Elaine'</span> <span class="token punctuation">}</span><span class="token punctuation">,</span></span><span class="gatsby-highlight-code-line">          <span class="token punctuation">{</span> id<span class="token operator">:</span> <span class="token number">3</span><span class="token punctuation">,</span> name<span class="token operator">:</span> <span class="token string">'George'</span> <span class="token punctuation">}</span><span class="token punctuation">,</span></span><span class="gatsby-highlight-code-line">        <span class="token punctuation">]</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span></span><span class="gatsby-highlight-code-line">      <span class="token punctuation">}</span> <span class="token keyword">else</span> <span class="token punctuation">{</span></span><span class="gatsby-highlight-code-line">        <span class="token function">reject</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token string">'Failed to fetch data!'</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span></span><span class="gatsby-highlight-code-line">      <span class="token punctuation">}</span></span><span class="gatsby-highlight-code-line">    <span class="token punctuation">}</span><span class="token punctuation">,</span> <span class="token number">1000</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span></span>  <span class="token punctuation">}</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span>
<span class="token punctuation">}</span></code></pre></div>
<p>For the successful result, you return <a href="https://www.digitalocean.com/community/tutorials/understanding-objects-in-javascript">JavaScript objects</a> that represent sample user data.</p>
<p>In order to handle the error, you will use the <code class="language-text">catch</code> instance method. This will give you a failure callback with the <code class="language-text">error</code> as a parameter.</p>
<p>Run the <code class="language-text">getUser</code> command with <code class="language-text">onSuccess</code> set to <code class="language-text">false</code>, using the <code class="language-text">then</code> method for the success case and the <code class="language-text">catch</code> method for the error:</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="js"><pre class="language-js"><code class="language-js"><span class="token comment">// Run the getUsers function with the false flag to trigger an error</span>
<span class="token function">getUsers</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token boolean">false</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span>
  <span class="token punctuation">.</span><span class="token function">then</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token parameter">response</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span> <span class="token operator">=></span> <span class="token punctuation">{</span>
    console<span class="token punctuation">.</span><span class="token function">log</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span>response<span class="token punctuation">)</span>
  <span class="token punctuation">}</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span>
  <span class="token punctuation">.</span><span class="token function">catch</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token parameter">error</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span> <span class="token operator">=></span> <span class="token punctuation">{</span>
    console<span class="token punctuation">.</span><span class="token function">error</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span>error<span class="token punctuation">)</span>
  <span class="token punctuation">}</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span></code></pre></div>
<p>Since the error was triggered, the <code class="language-text">then</code> will be skipped and the <code class="language-text">catch</code> will handle the error:</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="terminal"><pre class="language-terminal"><code class="language-terminal">Failed to fetch data!</code></pre></div>
<p>If you switch the flag and <code class="language-text">resolve</code> instead, the <code class="language-text">catch</code> will be ignored, and the data will return instead.</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="js"><pre class="language-js"><code class="language-js"><span class="token comment">// Run the getUsers function with the true flag to resolve successfully</span>
<span class="token function">getUsers</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token boolean">true</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span>
  <span class="token punctuation">.</span><span class="token function">then</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token parameter">response</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span> <span class="token operator">=></span> <span class="token punctuation">{</span>
    console<span class="token punctuation">.</span><span class="token function">log</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span>response<span class="token punctuation">)</span>
  <span class="token punctuation">}</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span>
  <span class="token punctuation">.</span><span class="token function">catch</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token parameter">error</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span> <span class="token operator">=></span> <span class="token punctuation">{</span>
    console<span class="token punctuation">.</span><span class="token function">error</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span>error<span class="token punctuation">)</span>
  <span class="token punctuation">}</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span></code></pre></div>
<p>This will yield the user data:</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="terminal"><pre class="language-terminal"><code class="language-terminal">(3) [{…}, {…}, {…}]
0: {id: 1, name: &quot;Jerry&quot;}
1: {id: 2, name: &quot;Elaine&quot;}
3: {id: 3, name: &quot;George&quot;}</code></pre></div>
<p>For reference, here is a table with the handler methods on <code class="language-text">Promise</code> objects:</p>
<table>
<thead>
<tr>
<th>Method</th>
<th>Description</th>
</tr>
</thead>
<tbody>
<tr>
