<td><code class="language-text">then()</code></td>
<td>Handles a <code class="language-text">resolve</code>. Returns a promise, and calls <code class="language-text">onFulfilled</code> function asynchronously</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td><code class="language-text">catch()</code></td>
<td>Handles a <code class="language-text">reject</code>. Returns a promise, and calls <code class="language-text">onRejected</code> function asynchronously</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td><code class="language-text">finally()</code></td>
<td>Called when a promise is settled. Returns a promise, and calls <code class="language-text">onFinally</code> function asynchronously</td>
</tr>
</tbody>
</table>
<p>Promises can be confusing, both for new developers and experienced programmers that have never worked in an asynchronous environment before. However as mentioned, it is much more common to consume promises than create them. Usually, a browser's Web API or third party library will be providing the promise, and you only need to consume it.</p>
<p>In the final promise section, this tutorial will cite a common use case of a Web API that returns promises: <a href="https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Fetch_API">the Fetch API</a>.</p>
<h3 id="using-the-fetch-api-with-promises" style="position:relative;"><a href="#using-the-fetch-api-with-promises" aria-label="using the fetch api with promises permalink" class="anchor before"><svg aria-hidden="true" focusable="false" height="16" version="1.1" viewBox="0 0 16 16" width="16"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z"></path></svg></a>Using the Fetch API with Promises</h3>
<p>One of the most useful and frequently used Web APIs that returns a promise is the Fetch API, which allows you to make an asynchronous resource request over a network. <code class="language-text">fetch</code> is a two-part process, and therefore requires chaining <code class="language-text">then</code>. This example demonstrates hitting the GitHub API to fetch a user's data, while also handling any potential error:</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="js"><pre class="language-js"><code class="language-js"><span class="token comment">// Fetch a user from the GitHub API</span>
<span class="token function">fetch</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token string">'https://api.github.com/users/octocat'</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span>
  <span class="token punctuation">.</span><span class="token function">then</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token parameter">response</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span> <span class="token operator">=></span> <span class="token punctuation">{</span>
    <span class="token keyword">return</span> response<span class="token punctuation">.</span><span class="token function">json</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span>
  <span class="token punctuation">}</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span>
  <span class="token punctuation">.</span><span class="token function">then</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token parameter">data</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span> <span class="token operator">=></span> <span class="token punctuation">{</span>
    console<span class="token punctuation">.</span><span class="token function">log</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span>data<span class="token punctuation">)</span>
  <span class="token punctuation">}</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span>
  <span class="token punctuation">.</span><span class="token function">catch</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token parameter">error</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span> <span class="token operator">=></span> <span class="token punctuation">{</span>
    console<span class="token punctuation">.</span><span class="token function">error</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span>error<span class="token punctuation">)</span>
  <span class="token punctuation">}</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span></code></pre></div>
<p>The <code class="language-text">fetch</code> request is sent to the <code class="language-text">https://api.github.com/users/octocat</code> URL, which asynchronously waits for a response. The first <code class="language-text">then</code> passes the response to an anonymous function that formats the response as <a href="https://www.digitalocean.com/community/tutorials/how-to-work-with-json-in-javascript">JSON data</a>, then passes the JSON to a second <code class="language-text">then</code> that logs the data to the console. The <code class="language-text">catch</code> statement logs any error to the console.</p>
<p>Running this code will yield the following:</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="terminal"><pre class="language-terminal"><code class="language-terminal">login: &quot;octocat&quot;,
id: 583231,
avatar_url: &quot;https://avatars3.githubusercontent.com/u/583231?v=4&quot;
blog: &quot;https://github.blog&quot;
company: &quot;@github&quot;
followers: 3203
...</code></pre></div>
<p>This is the data requested from <code class="language-text">https://api.github.com/users/octocat</code>, rendered in JSON format.</p>
<p>This section of the tutorial showed that promises incorporate a lot of improvements for dealing with asynchronous code. But, while using <code class="language-text">then</code> to handle asynchronous actions is easier to follow than the pyramid of callbacks, some developers still prefer a synchronous format of writing asynchronous code. To address this need, <a href="https://www.ecma-international.org/ecma-262/7.0/index.html">ECMAScript 2016 (ES7)</a> introduced <code class="language-text">async</code> functions and the <code class="language-text">await</code> keyword to make working with promises easier.</p>
<h2 id="async-functions-with-asyncawait" style="position:relative;"><a href="#async-functions-with-asyncawait" aria-label="async functions with asyncawait permalink" class="anchor before"><svg aria-hidden="true" focusable="false" height="16" version="1.1" viewBox="0 0 16 16" width="16"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z"></path></svg></a>Async Functions with <code class="language-text">async</code>/<code class="language-text">await</code></h2>
<p>An <em><code class="language-text">async</code> function</em> allows you to handle asynchronous code in a manner that appears synchronous. <code class="language-text">async</code> functions still use promises under the hood, but have a more traditional JavaScript syntax. In this section, you will try out examples of this syntax.</p>
<p>You can create an <code class="language-text">async</code> function by adding the <code class="language-text">async</code> keyword before a function:</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="js"><pre class="language-js"><code class="language-js"><span class="token comment">// Create an async function</span>
<span class="token keyword">async</span> <span class="token keyword">function</span> <span class="token function">getUser</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span> <span class="token punctuation">{</span>
  <span class="token keyword">return</span> <span class="token punctuation">{</span><span class="token punctuation">}</span>
<span class="token punctuation">}</span></code></pre></div>
<p>Although this function is not handling anything asynchronous yet, it behaves differently than a traditional function. If you execute the function, you'll find that it returns a promise with a <code class="language-text">[[PromiseStatus]]</code> and <code class="language-text">[[PromiseValue]]</code> instead of a return value.</p>
<p>Try this out by logging a call to the <code class="language-text">getUser</code> function:</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="js"><pre class="language-js"><code class="language-js">console<span class="token punctuation">.</span><span class="token function">log</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token function">getUser</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span></code></pre></div>
<p>This will give the following:</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="terminal"><pre class="language-terminal"><code class="language-terminal">__proto__: Promise
[[PromiseStatus]]: &quot;fulfilled&quot;
[[PromiseValue]]: Object</code></pre></div>
<p>This means you can handle an <code class="language-text">async</code> function with <code class="language-text">then</code> in the same way you could handle a promise. Try this out with the following code:</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="js"><pre class="language-js"><code class="language-js"><span class="token function">getUser</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span><span class="token punctuation">.</span><span class="token function">then</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token parameter">response</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span> <span class="token operator">=></span> console<span class="token punctuation">.</span><span class="token function">log</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span>response<span class="token punctuation">)</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span></code></pre></div>
<p>This call to <code class="language-text">getUser</code> passes the return value to an anonymous function that logs the value to the console.</p>
<p>You will receive the following when you run this program:</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="terminal"><pre class="language-terminal"><code class="language-terminal">{}</code></pre></div>
<p>An <code class="language-text">async</code> function can handle a promise called within it using the <code class="language-text">await</code> operator. <code class="language-text">await</code> can be used within an <code class="language-text">async</code> function and will wait until a promise settles before executing the designated code.</p>
<p>With this knowledge, you can rewrite the Fetch request from the last section using <code class="language-text">async</code>/<code class="language-text">await</code> as follows:</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="js"><pre class="language-js"><code class="language-js"><span class="token comment">// Handle fetch with async/await</span>
<span class="token keyword">async</span> <span class="token keyword">function</span> <span class="token function">getUser</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span> <span class="token punctuation">{</span>
  <span class="token keyword">const</span> response <span class="token operator">=</span> <span class="token keyword">await</span> <span class="token function">fetch</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token string">'https://api.github.com/users/octocat'</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span>
  <span class="token keyword">const</span> data <span class="token operator">=</span> <span class="token keyword">await</span> response<span class="token punctuation">.</span><span class="token function">json</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span>

  console<span class="token punctuation">.</span><span class="token function">log</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span>data<span class="token punctuation">)</span>
<span class="token punctuation">}</span>

<span class="token comment">// Execute async function</span>
<span class="token function">getUser</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span></code></pre></div>
<p>The <code class="language-text">await</code> operators here ensure that the <code class="language-text">data</code> is not logged before the request has populated it with data.</p>
<p>Now the final <code class="language-text">data</code> can be handled inside the <code class="language-text">getUser</code> function, without any need for using <code class="language-text">then</code>. This is the output of logging <code class="language-text">data</code>:</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="terminal"><pre class="language-terminal"><code class="language-terminal">login: &quot;octocat&quot;,
id: 583231,
avatar_url: &quot;https://avatars3.githubusercontent.com/u/583231?v=4&quot;
blog: &quot;https://github.blog&quot;
company: &quot;@github&quot;
followers: 3203
...</code></pre></div>
<blockquote>
<p><strong>Note</strong>: In many environments, <code class="language-text">async</code> is necessary to use <code class="language-text">await</code>—however, some new versions of browsers and Node allow using top-level <code class="language-text">await</code>, which allows you to bypass creating an async function to wrap the <code class="language-text">await</code> in.</p>
</blockquote>
<p>Finally, since you are handling the fulfilled promise within the asynchronous function, you can also handle the error within the function. Instead of using the <code class="language-text">catch</code> method with <code class="language-text">then</code>, you will use the <a href="https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Statements/try...catch"><code class="language-text">try</code>/<code class="language-text">catch</code></a> pattern to handle the exception.</p>
<p>Add the following highlighted code:</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="js"><pre class="language-js"><code class="language-js"><span class="token comment">// Handling success and errors with async/await</span>
<span class="token keyword">async</span> <span class="token keyword">function</span> <span class="token function">getUser</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span> <span class="token punctuation">{</span>
<span class="gatsby-highlight-code-line">  <span class="token keyword">try</span> <span class="token punctuation">{</span></span><span class="gatsby-highlight-code-line">    <span class="token comment">// Handle success in try</span></span>    <span class="token keyword">const</span> response <span class="token operator">=</span> <span class="token keyword">await</span> <span class="token function">fetch</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token string">'https://api.github.com/users/octocat'</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span>
    <span class="token keyword">const</span> data <span class="token operator">=</span> <span class="token keyword">await</span> response<span class="token punctuation">.</span><span class="token function">json</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span>

    console<span class="token punctuation">.</span><span class="token function">log</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span>data<span class="token punctuation">)</span>
<span class="gatsby-highlight-code-line">  <span class="token punctuation">}</span> <span class="token keyword">catch</span> <span class="token punctuation">(</span>error<span class="token punctuation">)</span> <span class="token punctuation">{</span></span><span class="gatsby-highlight-code-line">    <span class="token comment">// Handle error in catch</span></span><span class="gatsby-highlight-code-line">    console<span class="token punctuation">.</span><span class="token function">error</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span>error<span class="token punctuation">)</span></span><span class="gatsby-highlight-code-line">  <span class="token punctuation">}</span></span><span class="token punctuation">}</span></code></pre></div>
<p>The program will now skip to the <code class="language-text">catch</code> block if it receives an error and log that error to the console.</p>
<p>Modern asynchronous JavaScript code is most often handled with <code class="language-text">async</code>/<code class="language-text">await</code> syntax, but it is important to have a working knowledge of how promises work, especially as promises are capable of additional features that cannot be handled with <code class="language-text">async</code>/<code class="language-text">await</code>, like combining promises with <a href="https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Global_Objects/Promise/all"><code class="language-text">Promise.all()</code></a>.</p>
<blockquote>
<p><strong>Note:</strong> <code class="language-text">async</code>/<code class="language-text">await</code> can be reproduced by using <a href="https://www.digitalocean.com/community/tutorials/understanding-generators-in-javascript#asyncawait-with-generators">generators combined with promises</a> to add more flexibility to your code. To learn more, check out our <a href="https://www.digitalocean.com/community/tutorials/understanding-generators-in-javascript">Understanding Generators in JavaScript</a> tutorial.</p>
</blockquote>
<h2 id="conclusion" style="position:relative;"><a href="#conclusion" aria-label="conclusion permalink" class="anchor before"><svg aria-hidden="true" focusable="false" height="16" version="1.1" viewBox="0 0 16 16" width="16"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z"></path></svg></a>Conclusion</h2>
<p>Because Web APIs often provide data asynchronously, learning how to handle the result of asynchronous actions is an essential part of being a JavaScript developer. In this article, you learned how the host environment uses the event loop to handle the order of execution of code with the <em>stack</em> and <em>queue</em>. You also tried out examples of three ways to handle the success or failure of an asynchronous event, with callbacks, promises, and <code class="language-text">async</code>/<code class="language-text">await</code> syntax. Finally, you used the Fetch Web API to handle asynchronous actions.</p>
<p>For more information about how the browser handles parallel events, read <a href="https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/EventLoop">Concurrency model and the event loop</a> on the Mozilla Developer Network. If you'd like to learn more about JavaScript, return to our <a href="https://www.digitalocean.com/community/tutorial_series/how-to-code-in-javascript">How To Code in JavaScript</a> series.</p></content:encoded><author>hello@taniarascia.com</author></item><item><title><![CDATA[REST API: Sorting, Filtering, and Pagination]]></title><description><![CDATA[Web applications often have tables of data, whether it's the list of items for sale on Amazon, or notes in Evernote, and so on. Usually…]]></description><link>https://www.taniarascia.com/rest-api-sorting-filtering-pagination/</link><guid isPermaLink="false">https://www.taniarascia.com/rest-api-sorting-filtering-pagination/</guid><pubDate>Wed, 09 Sep 2020 00:00:00 GMT</pubDate><content:encoded><p>Web applications often have tables of data, whether it's the list of items for sale on Amazon, or notes in Evernote, and so on. Usually, users of the application are going to want to filter the results or sort through that data in some way.</p>
<p>If the dataset is pretty small, maybe a few hundred results, the API can return all the data at once and the front end will handle all the filtering, and no more API calls are required. Most of the time, however, the data could consist of tens of thousands to millions of rows, and it's better to just get the data you need from smaller API calls as opposed to trying to request a million results every time the page loads.</p>
<p>Recently, I made a backend API for some list endpoints, and implemented <strong>filtering, sorting, and pagination</strong>. There's not really a set standard for creating these types of endpoints, and almost every one I've come across is different in some way. I made a few notes on what made sense to me, so this resource could be helpful for someone who is working on designing an API.</p>
<h4 id="goals" style="position:relative;"><a href="#goals" aria-label="goals permalink" class="anchor before"><svg aria-hidden="true" focusable="false" height="16" version="1.1" viewBox="0 0 16 16" width="16"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z"></path></svg></a>Goals</h4>
<p>In this article I'll make an example <strong>API endpoint</strong> and <strong>SQL query</strong> for various sort, paginate, and filter APIs, with <code class="language-text">users</code> as the table for all examples.</p>
<h4 id="contents" style="position:relative;"><a href="#contents" aria-label="contents permalink" class="anchor before"><svg aria-hidden="true" focusable="false" height="16" version="1.1" viewBox="0 0 16 16" width="16"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z"></path></svg></a>Contents</h4>
<ul>
<li><a href="#response">Response</a></li>
<li><a href="#pagination">Pagination</a></li>
<li><a href="#sorting">Sorting</a>
<ul>
<li><a href="#ascending-vs-descending">Ascending vs. Descending</a></li>
<li><a href="#single-column">Single column</a></li>
<li><a href="#multiple-columns">Multiple columns</a></li>
</ul>
</li>
<li><a href="#filtering">Filtering</a>
<ul>
<li><a href="#string-exact">String (exact)</a></li>
<li><a href="#string-exact-multiple">String (exact, multiple)</a></li>
<li><a href="#string-partial">String (partial)</a></li>
<li><a href="#number-exact">Number (exact)</a></li>
<li><a href="#number-greater-than">Number (greater than)</a></li>
<li><a href="#number-less-than">Number (less than)</a></li>
<li><a href="#number-range">Number (range)</a></li>
<li><a href="#date-range">Date (range)</a></li>
</ul>
</li>
</ul>
<h2 id="response" style="position:relative;"><a href="#response" aria-label="response permalink" class="anchor before"><svg aria-hidden="true" focusable="false" height="16" version="1.1" viewBox="0 0 16 16" width="16"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z"></path></svg></a>Response</h2>
<p>When using any pagination or filtering in an API, you're going to want to know how many results you have, how many results there are total, and what page you're on.</p>
<div class="filename">API Response</div>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="js"><pre class="language-js"><code class="language-js"><span class="token punctuation">{</span>
  content<span class="token operator">:</span> <span class="token punctuation">[</span><span class="token punctuation">]</span><span class="token punctuation">,</span> <span class="token comment">// all the response items will go in this array</span>
  page<span class="token operator">:</span> <span class="token number">1</span><span class="token punctuation">,</span> <span class="token comment">// current page</span>
  results_per_page<span class="token operator">:</span> <span class="token number">5</span><span class="token punctuation">,</span> <span class="token comment">// how many items available in "content"</span>
  total_results<span class="token operator">:</span> <span class="token number">100</span> <span class="token comment">// total number of items</span>
<span class="token punctuation">}</span></code></pre></div>
<p>From there, you can discern that there are 20 pages with <code class="language-text">total_results / results_per_page</code> and anything else you might need for the front end.</p>
<h2 id="pagination" style="position:relative;"><a href="#pagination" aria-label="pagination permalink" class="anchor before"><svg aria-hidden="true" focusable="false" height="16" version="1.1" viewBox="0 0 16 16" width="16"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z"></path></svg></a>Pagination</h2>
<p>Pagination is how you move between the pages when you don't want to retrieve all the results at once.</p>
<ul>
<li><strong>Page</strong> and <strong>results per page</strong> are required inputs</li>
<li>For the SQL query, <code class="language-text">offset</code> is equal to <code class="language-text">(page - 1) * results_per_page</code></li>
</ul>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="text"><pre class="language-text"><code class="language-text">GET /users?page=3&amp;results_per_page=20</code></pre></div>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="sql"><pre class="language-sql"><code class="language-sql"><span class="token keyword">SELECT</span> <span class="token operator">*</span> <span class="token keyword">FROM</span> users
<span class="token keyword">LIMIT</span> <span class="token number">20</span>
<span class="token keyword">OFFSET</span> <span class="token number">40</span></code></pre></div>
<h2 id="sorting" style="position:relative;"><a href="#sorting" aria-label="sorting permalink" class="anchor before"><svg aria-hidden="true" focusable="false" height="16" version="1.1" viewBox="0 0 16 16" width="16"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z"></path></svg></a>Sorting</h2>
<p>Sorting allows you to order the results by any field, in ascending or descending order.</p>
<h3 id="ascending-vs-descending" style="position:relative;"><a href="#ascending-vs-descending" aria-label="ascending vs descending permalink" class="anchor before"><svg aria-hidden="true" focusable="false" height="16" version="1.1" viewBox="0 0 16 16" width="16"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z"></path></svg></a>Ascending vs. Descending</h3>
<p>I always forget what ascending and descending mean for alphabetical, numerical, and date-based responses, so I wrote this up for reference.</p>
<table>
<thead>
<tr>
<th>Type</th>
<th>Order</th>
<th>Example</th>
<th>Description</th>
</tr>
</thead>
<tbody>
<tr>
<td>Alphabetical</td>
<td>Ascending</td>
<td><code class="language-text">A - Z</code></td>
<td>First to last</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>Alphabetical</td>
<td>Descending</td>
<td><code class="language-text">Z - A</code></td>
<td>Last to first</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>Numerical</td>
<td>Ascending</td>
<td><code class="language-text">1 - 9</code></td>
<td>Lowest to highest</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>Numerical</td>
<td>Descending</td>
<td><code class="language-text">9 - 1</code></td>
<td>Highest to lowest</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>Date</td>
<td>Ascending</td>
<td><code class="language-text">01-01-1970 - Today</code></td>
<td>Oldest to newest</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>Date</td>
<td>Descending</td>
<td><code class="language-text">Today - 01-01-1970</code></td>
<td>Newest to oldest</td>
</tr>
</tbody>
</table>
<h3 id="single-column" style="position:relative;"><a href="#single-column" aria-label="single column permalink" class="anchor before"><svg aria-hidden="true" focusable="false" height="16" version="1.1" viewBox="0 0 16 16" width="16"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z"></path></svg></a>Single column</h3>
<p>If you only need to sort one column at a time, you could put the column name in <code class="language-text">sort_by</code> and the sort direction in <code class="language-text">order</code>.</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="text"><pre class="language-text"><code class="language-text">GET /users?sort_by=first_name&amp;order=asc</code></pre></div>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="sql"><pre class="language-sql"><code class="language-sql"><span class="token keyword">SELECT</span> <span class="token operator">*</span> <span class="token keyword">FROM</span> users
<span class="token keyword">ORDER</span> <span class="token keyword">BY</span> first_name <span class="token keyword">ASC</span></code></pre></div>
<h3 id="multiple-columns" style="position:relative;"><a href="#multiple-columns" aria-label="multiple columns permalink" class="anchor before"><svg aria-hidden="true" focusable="false" height="16" version="1.1" viewBox="0 0 16 16" width="16"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z"></path></svg></a>Multiple columns</h3>
<p>If the ability to sort multiple columns is required, you could comma-separate each <code class="language-text">column:order</code> pair and put it in one <code class="language-text">sort</code> parameter. This could also be used for a single column if you prefer the syntax.</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="text"><pre class="language-text"><code class="language-text">GET /users?sort=first_name:asc,age:desc</code></pre></div>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="sql"><pre class="language-sql"><code class="language-sql"><span class="token keyword">SELECT</span> <span class="token operator">*</span> <span class="token keyword">FROM</span> users
<span class="token keyword">ORDER</span> <span class="token keyword">BY</span> first_name <span class="token keyword">ASC</span><span class="token punctuation">,</span> age <span class="token keyword">DESC</span></code></pre></div>
<h2 id="filtering" style="position:relative;"><a href="#filtering" aria-label="filtering permalink" class="anchor before"><svg aria-hidden="true" focusable="false" height="16" version="1.1" viewBox="0 0 16 16" width="16"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z"></path></svg></a>Filtering</h2>
<p>Filtering is by far the most complex of the three. There are several ways to handle it. Some APIs will use a <code class="language-text">POST</code> and pass all the data in the body of the request for searching. This might be necessary for advanced searching in some situations, but a <code class="language-text">GET</code> is preferable.</p>
<p>Some API will attempt to put everything on a single <code class="language-text">filter</code> parameter, like this:</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="text"><pre class="language-text"><code class="language-text">GET users?filter={"first_name":["Tania","Joe"],"age":[30,31,32]}</code></pre></div>
<p>However, this will have to be URI encoded.</p>
<p>I've opted for treating each parameter as a column in the database.</p>
<h3 id="string-exact" style="position:relative;"><a href="#string-exact" aria-label="string exact permalink" class="anchor before"><svg aria-hidden="true" focusable="false" height="16" version="1.1" viewBox="0 0 16 16" width="16"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z"></path></svg></a>String (exact)</h3>
<p>Exact search by a single column.</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="text"><pre class="language-text"><code class="language-text">GET /users?first_name=Tania</code></pre></div>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="sql"><pre class="language-sql"><code class="language-sql"><span class="token keyword">SELECT</span> <span class="token operator">*</span> <span class="token keyword">FROM</span> users
<span class="token keyword">WHERE</span> first_name <span class="token operator">=</span> <span class="token string">'Tania'</span></code></pre></div>
<h3 id="string-exact-multiple" style="position:relative;"><a href="#string-exact-multiple" aria-label="string exact multiple permalink" class="anchor before"><svg aria-hidden="true" focusable="false" height="16" version="1.1" viewBox="0 0 16 16" width="16"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z"></path></svg></a>String (exact, multiple)</h3>
<p>Depending on how you want to handle the API, multiple options for a single column can be handled <a href="https://stackoverflow.com/questions/24059773/correct-way-to-pass-multiple-values-for-same-parameter-name-in-get-request">in different ways</a>. If splitting by comma isn't an issue, it might be the easiest. You might also just want to repeat the parameter name or use a custom delimiter.</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="text"><pre class="language-text"><code class="language-text">GET /users?first_name=Tania,Joe
GET /users?first_name=Tania&amp;first_name=Joe
GET /users?first_name[]=Tania&amp;first_name[]=Joe</code></pre></div>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="sql"><pre class="language-sql"><code class="language-sql"><span class="token keyword">SELECT</span> <span class="token operator">*</span> <span class="token keyword">FROM</span> users
<span class="token keyword">WHERE</span> first_name <span class="token operator">IN</span> <span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token string">'Tania'</span><span class="token punctuation">,</span> <span class="token string">'Joe'</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span></code></pre></div>
<blockquote>
<p>Some systems might require using <code class="language-text">[]</code> for multiple parameters of the same name, and some might now allow <code class="language-text">[]</code>, so I provided both options.</p>
</blockquote>
<h3 id="string-partial" style="position:relative;"><a href="#string-partial" aria-label="string partial permalink" class="anchor before"><svg aria-hidden="true" focusable="false" height="16" version="1.1" viewBox="0 0 16 16" width="16"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z"></path></svg></a>String (partial)</h3>
<p>Often, searches are expected to be partial, so that when I look for "Tan" it will show me "Tania" and "Tanner". The solution I liked was using <code class="language-text">like:Tan</code> as value as opposed to modifying the parameter (such as <code class="language-text">first_name[like]=Tan</code>).</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="text"><pre class="language-text"><code class="language-text">GET /users?first_name=like:Tan</code></pre></div>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="sql"><pre class="language-sql"><code class="language-sql"><span class="token keyword">SELECT</span> <span class="token operator">*</span> <span class="token keyword">FROM</span> users
<span class="token keyword">WHERE</span> first_name <span class="token operator">LIKE</span> <span class="token string">'%Tan%'</span></code></pre></div>
<h3 id="number-exact" style="position:relative;"><a href="#number-exact" aria-label="number exact permalink" class="anchor before"><svg aria-hidden="true" focusable="false" height="16" version="1.1" viewBox="0 0 16 16" width="16"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z"></path></svg></a>Number (exact)</h3>
<p>Exact number search on a column.</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="text"><pre class="language-text"><code class="language-text">GET /users?age=30</code></pre></div>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="sql"><pre class="language-sql"><code class="language-sql"><span class="token keyword">SELECT</span> <span class="token operator">*</span> <span class="token keyword">FROM</span> users
<span class="token keyword">WHERE</span> age <span class="token operator">=</span> <span class="token number">31</span></code></pre></div>
<h3 id="number-greater-than" style="position:relative;"><a href="#number-greater-than" aria-label="number greater than permalink" class="anchor before"><svg aria-hidden="true" focusable="false" height="16" version="1.1" viewBox="0 0 16 16" width="16"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z"></path></svg></a>Number (greater than)</h3>
<p>Similar to <code class="language-text">like:</code>, you can use <code class="language-text">gt:</code> to handle greater than. Adding the option for <code class="language-text">gte:</code> (greater than or equal) is also an option.</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="text"><pre class="language-text"><code class="language-text">GET /users?age=gt:21</code></pre></div>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="sql"><pre class="language-sql"><code class="language-sql"><span class="token keyword">SELECT</span> <span class="token operator">*</span> <span class="token keyword">FROM</span> users
<span class="token keyword">WHERE</span> age <span class="token operator">></span> <span class="token number">21</span></code></pre></div>
<h3 id="number-less-than" style="position:relative;"><a href="#number-less-than" aria-label="number less than permalink" class="anchor before"><svg aria-hidden="true" focusable="false" height="16" version="1.1" viewBox="0 0 16 16" width="16"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z"></path></svg></a>Number (less than)</h3>
<p>Same with <code class="language-text">lt:</code> for less than <code class="language-text">lte:</code> for less than or equal.</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="text"><pre class="language-text"><code class="language-text">GET /users?age=lt:21</code></pre></div>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="sql"><pre class="language-sql"><code class="language-sql"><span class="token keyword">SELECT</span> <span class="token operator">*</span> <span class="token keyword">FROM</span> users
<span class="token keyword">WHERE</span> age <span class="token operator">&lt;</span> <span class="token number">21</span></code></pre></div>
<h3 id="number-range" style="position:relative;"><a href="#number-range" aria-label="number range permalink" class="anchor before"><svg aria-hidden="true" focusable="false" height="16" version="1.1" viewBox="0 0 16 16" width="16"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z"></path></svg></a>Number (range)</h3>
<p>If you need a range between two number values, using <code class="language-text">[and]</code> in between them could be one option. This one could get complicated, depending on if you want to allow both greater than and greater than or equal, or other options.</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="text"><pre class="language-text"><code class="language-text">GET /users?age=gt:12[and]lt:20</code></pre></div>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="sql"><pre class="language-sql"><code class="language-sql"><span class="token keyword">SELECT</span> <span class="token operator">*</span> <span class="token keyword">FROM</span> users
<span class="token keyword">WHERE</span> age <span class="token operator">></span> <span class="token number">12</span> <span class="token operator">AND</span> age <span class="token operator">&lt;</span> <span class="token number">20</span></code></pre></div>
<h3 id="date-range" style="position:relative;"><a href="#date-range" aria-label="date range permalink" class="anchor before"><svg aria-hidden="true" focusable="false" height="16" version="1.1" viewBox="0 0 16 16" width="16"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z"></path></svg></a>Date (range)</h3>
<p>If you need a range between two dates, you can use <code class="language-text">start</code> and <code class="language-text">end</code>, or <code class="language-text">since</code> and <code class="language-text">to</code>.</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="text"><pre class="language-text"><code class="language-text">GET /users?start=01-01-1970&amp;end=09-09-2020</code></pre></div>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="sql"><pre class="language-sql"><code class="language-sql"><span class="token keyword">SELECT</span> <span class="token operator">*</span> <span class="token keyword">FROM</span> users
<span class="token keyword">WHERE</span> created_at <span class="token operator">BETWEEN</span> <span class="token string">'01-01-1970'</span> <span class="token operator">AND</span> <span class="token string">'09-09-2020'</span></code></pre></div>
<h2 id="conclusion" style="position:relative;"><a href="#conclusion" aria-label="conclusion permalink" class="anchor before"><svg aria-hidden="true" focusable="false" height="16" version="1.1" viewBox="0 0 16 16" width="16"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z"></path></svg></a>Conclusion</h2>
<p>These examples are pretty simple and cover basic use cases. If your API is very complicated, you might need to change it up to add more options, particularly with ranges, and various combinations of "and" and "or". Hopefully this will be a helpful starting point!</p></content:encoded><author>hello@taniarascia.com</author></item><item><title><![CDATA[Adding Comments to My Blog (via Utterances)]]></title><description><![CDATA[I've gone back and forth about whether or not to have comments on the site. Most of all, I've liked having absolutely no server or external…]]></description><link>https://www.taniarascia.com/adding-comments-to-my-blog/</link><guid isPermaLink="false">https://www.taniarascia.com/adding-comments-to-my-blog/</guid><pubDate>Tue, 04 Aug 2020 00:00:00 GMT</pubDate><content:encoded><p>I've gone back and forth about whether or not to have comments on the site. Most of all, I've liked having absolutely no server or external scripts on the site, and not having to moderate comments that are publicly facing on the site.</p>
<p>A bit ago, I implemented my own comments REST API server with Node and <a href="https://www.taniarascia.com/add-comments-to-static-site/">wrote about it here</a>, which was awesome, but I didn't implement any user system or authentication, so the barrier to posting was just too low.</p>
<p>I couldn't keep ignoring how awesome <a href="https://utteranc.es/">Utterances</a> looks, an <a href="https://github.com/utterance/utterances">open source project</a> by <a href="https://github.com/jdanyow">Jeremy Danyow</a>. Not only does it look absolutely fantastic, but it took me about 15 minutes to set up completely on my Gatsby site.</p>
<p>I made a <a href="https://github.com/taniarascia/comments">comments</a> repo to host all the issues and responses. Connecting to the Utterances GitHub app is required to leave a comment through the site, though you can also comment directly through GitHub if the issue exists. I imagine spam and obnoxious comments will be much more rare through this system, and people will actually be able to participate in discussions and leave helpful comments once again.</p></content:encoded><author>hello@taniarascia.com</author></item><item><title><![CDATA[Understanding Arrow Functions in JavaScript]]></title><description><![CDATA[This article was originally written for DigitalOcean. Introduction The 2015 edition of the ECMAScript specification (ES6) added arrow…]]></description><link>https://www.taniarascia.com/understanding-arrow-functions-in-javascript/</link><guid isPermaLink="false">https://www.taniarascia.com/understanding-arrow-functions-in-javascript/</guid><pubDate>Sat, 01 Aug 2020 00:00:00 GMT</pubDate><content:encoded><p><em>This article was originally written for <a href="https://www.digitalocean.com/community/tutorials/understanding-arrow-functions-in-javascript">DigitalOcean</a>.</em></p>
<h3 id="introduction" style="position:relative;"><a href="#introduction" aria-label="introduction permalink" class="anchor before"><svg aria-hidden="true" focusable="false" height="16" version="1.1" viewBox="0 0 16 16" width="16"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z"></path></svg></a>Introduction</h3>
<p>The <a href="http://www.ecma-international.org/ecma-262/6.0/">2015 edition of the ECMAScript specification (ES6)</a> added <em>arrow function expressions</em> to the <a href="https://www.digitalocean.com/community/tutorial_series/how-to-code-in-javascript">JavaScript</a> language. Arrow functions are a new way to write anonymous function expressions, and are similar to <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Anonymous_function">lambda functions</a> in some other programming languages, such as <a href="https://www.digitalocean.com/community/tutorial_series/how-to-code-in-python-3">Python</a>.</p>
<p>Arrow functions differ from traditional functions in a number of ways, including the way their scope is determined and how their syntax is expressed. Because of this, arrow functions are particularly useful when passing a function as a parameter to a higher-order function, such as when you are looping over an <a href="https://www.digitalocean.com/community/tutorials/understanding-arrays-in-javascript">array</a> with <a href="https://www.digitalocean.com/community/tutorials/how-to-use-array-methods-in-javascript-iteration-methods">built-in iterator methods</a>. Their syntactic abbreviation can also allow you to improve the readability of your code.</p>
<p>In this article, you will review function declarations and expressions, learn about the differences between traditional function expressions and arrow function expressions, learn about lexical scope as it pertains to arrow functions, and explore some of the syntactic shorthand permitted with arrow functions.</p>
<h2 id="defining-functions" style="position:relative;"><a href="#defining-functions" aria-label="defining functions permalink" class="anchor before"><svg aria-hidden="true" focusable="false" height="16" version="1.1" viewBox="0 0 16 16" width="16"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z"></path></svg></a>Defining Functions</h2>
<p>Before delving into the specifics of arrow function expressions, this tutorial will briefly review traditional JavaScript functions in order to better show the unique aspects of arrow functions later on.</p>
<p>The <a href="https://www.digitalocean.com/community/tutorials/how-to-define-functions-in-javascript">How To Define Functions in JavaScript</a> tutorial earlier in this series introduced the concept of <em>function declarations</em> and <em>function expressions</em>. A function declaration is a named function written with the <code class="language-text">function</code> keyword. Function declarations load into the execution context before any code runs. This is known as <em>hoisting</em>, meaning you can use the function before you declare it.</p>
<p>Here is an example of a <code class="language-text">sum</code> function that returns the sum of two parameters:</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="js"><pre class="language-js"><code class="language-js"><span class="token keyword">function</span> <span class="token function">sum</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token parameter">a<span class="token punctuation">,</span> b</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span> <span class="token punctuation">{</span>
  <span class="token keyword">return</span> a <span class="token operator">+</span> b
<span class="token punctuation">}</span></code></pre></div>
<p>You can execute the <code class="language-text">sum</code> function before declaring the function due to hoisting:</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="js"><pre class="language-js"><code class="language-js"><span class="token function">sum</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token number">1</span><span class="token punctuation">,</span> <span class="token number">2</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span>

<span class="token keyword">function</span> <span class="token function">sum</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token parameter">a<span class="token punctuation">,</span> b</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span> <span class="token punctuation">{</span>
  <span class="token keyword">return</span> a <span class="token operator">+</span> b
<span class="token punctuation">}</span></code></pre></div>
<p>Running this code would give the following output:</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="terminal"><pre class="language-terminal"><code class="language-terminal">3</code></pre></div>
<p>You can find the name of the function by logging the function itself:</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="js"><pre class="language-js"><code class="language-js">console<span class="token punctuation">.</span><span class="token function">log</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span>sum<span class="token punctuation">)</span></code></pre></div>
<p>This will return the function, along with its name:</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="terminal"><pre class="language-terminal"><code class="language-terminal">ƒ sum(a, b) {
  return a + b
}</code></pre></div>
<p>A function expression is a function that is not pre-loaded into the execution context, and only runs when the code encounters it. Function expressions are usually assigned to a variable, and can be <em>anonymous</em>, meaning the function has no name.</p>
<p>In this example, write the same <code class="language-text">sum</code> function as an anonymous function expression:</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="js"><pre class="language-js"><code class="language-js"><span class="token keyword">const</span> <span class="token function-variable function">sum</span> <span class="token operator">=</span> <span class="token keyword">function</span> <span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token parameter">a<span class="token punctuation">,</span> b</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span> <span class="token punctuation">{</span>
  <span class="token keyword">return</span> a <span class="token operator">+</span> b
<span class="token punctuation">}</span></code></pre></div>
<p>You've now assigned the anonymous function to the <code class="language-text">sum</code> constant. Attempting to execute the function before it is declared will result in an error:</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="js"><pre class="language-js"><code class="language-js"><span class="token function">sum</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token number">1</span><span class="token punctuation">,</span> <span class="token number">2</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span>

<span class="token keyword">const</span> <span class="token function-variable function">sum</span> <span class="token operator">=</span> <span class="token keyword">function</span> <span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token parameter">a<span class="token punctuation">,</span> b</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span> <span class="token punctuation">{</span>
  <span class="token keyword">return</span> a <span class="token operator">+</span> b
<span class="token punctuation">}</span></code></pre></div>
<p>Running this will give:</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="terminal"><pre class="language-terminal"><code class="language-terminal">Uncaught ReferenceError: Cannot access &#39;sum&#39; before initialization</code></pre></div>
<p>Also, note that the function does not have a named identifier. To illustrate this, write the same anonymous function assigned to <code class="language-text">sum</code>, then log <code class="language-text">sum</code> to the console:</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="js"><pre class="language-js"><code class="language-js"><span class="token keyword">const</span> <span class="token function-variable function">sum</span> <span class="token operator">=</span> <span class="token keyword">function</span> <span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token parameter">a<span class="token punctuation">,</span> b</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span> <span class="token punctuation">{</span>
  <span class="token keyword">return</span> a <span class="token operator">+</span> b
<span class="token punctuation">}</span>

console<span class="token punctuation">.</span><span class="token function">log</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span>sum<span class="token punctuation">)</span></code></pre></div>
<p>This will show you the following:</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="terminal"><pre class="language-terminal"><code class="language-terminal">ƒ (a, b) {
  return a + b
}</code></pre></div>
<p>The value of <code class="language-text">sum</code> is an anonymous function, not a named function.</p>
<p>You can name function expressions written with the <code class="language-text">function</code> keyword, but this is not popular in practice. One reason you might want to name a function expression is to make error stack traces easier to debug.</p>
<p>Consider the following function, which uses an <a href="https://www.digitalocean.com/community/tutorials/how-to-write-conditional-statements-in-javascript"><code class="language-text">if</code> statement</a> to throw an error if the function parameters are missing:</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="js"><pre class="language-js"><code class="language-js"><span class="token keyword">const</span> <span class="token function-variable function">sum</span> <span class="token operator">=</span> <span class="token keyword">function</span> <span class="token function">namedSumFunction</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token parameter">a<span class="token punctuation">,</span> b</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span> <span class="token punctuation">{</span>
  <span class="token keyword">if</span> <span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token operator">!</span>a <span class="token operator">||</span> <span class="token operator">!</span>b<span class="token punctuation">)</span> <span class="token keyword">throw</span> <span class="token keyword">new</span> <span class="token class-name">Error</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token string">'Parameters are required.'</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span>

  <span class="token keyword">return</span> a <span class="token operator">+</span> b
<span class="token punctuation">}</span>

<span class="token function">sum</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span></code></pre></div>
<p>The highlighted section gives the function a name, and then the function uses the <strong>or</strong> <code class="language-text">||</code> operator to throw an error <a href="https://www.digitalocean.com/community/tutorials/understanding-objects-in-javascript">object</a> if either of the parameters is missing.</p>
<p>Running this code will give you the following:</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="terminal"><pre class="language-terminal"><code class="language-terminal">Uncaught Error: Parameters are required.
    at namedSumFunction (&lt;anonymous&gt;:3:23)
    at &lt;anonymous&gt;:1:1</code></pre></div>
<p>In this case, naming the function gives you a quick idea of where the error is.</p>
<p>An <a href="https://www.digitalocean.com/community/tutorials/how-to-define-functions-in-javascript#arrow-functions"><em>arrow function expression</em></a> is an anonymous function expression written with the "fat arrow" syntax (<code class="language-text">=></code>).</p>
<p>Rewrite the <code class="language-text">sum</code> function with arrow function syntax:</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="js"><pre class="language-js"><code class="language-js"><span class="token keyword">const</span> <span class="token function-variable function">sum</span> <span class="token operator">=</span> <span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token parameter">a<span class="token punctuation">,</span> b</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span> <span class="token operator">=></span> <span class="token punctuation">{</span>
  <span class="token keyword">return</span> a <span class="token operator">+</span> b
<span class="token punctuation">}</span></code></pre></div>
<p>Like traditional function expressions, arrow functions are not hoisted, and so you cannnot call them before you declare them. They are also always anonymous—there is no way to name an arrow function. In the next section, you will explore more of the syntactical and practical differences between arrow functions and traditional functions.</p>
<h2 id="arrow-functions" style="position:relative;"><a href="#arrow-functions" aria-label="arrow functions permalink" class="anchor before"><svg aria-hidden="true" focusable="false" height="16" version="1.1" viewBox="0 0 16 16" width="16"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z"></path></svg></a>Arrow Functions</h2>
<p>Arrow functions have a few important distinctions in how they work that distinguish them from traditional functions, as well as a few syntactic enhancements. The biggest functional differences are that arrow functions do not have their own <code class="language-text">this</code> binding or prototype and cannot be used as a constructor. Arrow functions can also be written as a more compact alternative to traditional functions, as they grant the ability to omit parentheses around parameters and add the concept of a concise function body with implicit return.</p>
<p>In this section, you will go through examples that illustrate each of these cases.</p>
<h3 id="lexical-this" style="position:relative;"><a href="#lexical-this" aria-label="lexical this permalink" class="anchor before"><svg aria-hidden="true" focusable="false" height="16" version="1.1" viewBox="0 0 16 16" width="16"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z"></path></svg></a>Lexical <code class="language-text">this</code></h3>
<p>The keyword <code class="language-text">this</code> is often considered a tricky topic in JavaScript. The article <a href="https://www.digitalocean.com/community/conceptual_articles/understanding-this-bind-call-and-apply-in-javascript">Understanding This, Bind, Call, and Apply in JavaScript</a> explains how <code class="language-text">this</code> works, and how <code class="language-text">this</code> can be implicitly inferred based on whether the program uses it in the global context, as a method within an object, as a constructor on a function or class, or as a <a href="https://www.digitalocean.com/community/tutorial_series/understanding-the-dom-document-object-model">DOM</a> event handler.</p>
<p>Arrow functions have <em>lexical <code class="language-text">this</code></em>, meaning the value of <code class="language-text">this</code> is determined by the surrounding scope (the lexical environment).</p>
<p>The next example will demonstrate the difference between how traditional and arrow functions handle <code class="language-text">this</code>. In the following <code class="language-text">printNumbers</code> object, there are two properties: <code class="language-text">phrase</code> and <code class="language-text">numbers</code>. There is also a method on the object, <code class="language-text">loop</code>, which should print the <code class="language-text">phrase</code> string and the current value in <code class="language-text">numbers</code>:</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="js"><pre class="language-js"><code class="language-js"><span class="token keyword">const</span> printNumbers <span class="token operator">=</span> <span class="token punctuation">{</span>
  phrase<span class="token operator">:</span> <span class="token string">'The current value is:'</span><span class="token punctuation">,</span>
  numbers<span class="token operator">:</span> <span class="token punctuation">[</span><span class="token number">1</span><span class="token punctuation">,</span> <span class="token number">2</span><span class="token punctuation">,</span> <span class="token number">3</span><span class="token punctuation">,</span> <span class="token number">4</span><span class="token punctuation">]</span><span class="token punctuation">,</span>

  <span class="token function">loop</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span> <span class="token punctuation">{</span>
    <span class="token keyword">this</span><span class="token punctuation">.</span>numbers<span class="token punctuation">.</span><span class="token function">forEach</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token keyword">function</span> <span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token parameter">number</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span> <span class="token punctuation">{</span>
      console<span class="token punctuation">.</span><span class="token function">log</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token keyword">this</span><span class="token punctuation">.</span>phrase<span class="token punctuation">,</span> number<span class="token punctuation">)</span>
    <span class="token punctuation">}</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span>
  <span class="token punctuation">}</span><span class="token punctuation">,</span>
<span class="token punctuation">}</span></code></pre></div>
<p>One might expect the <code class="language-text">loop</code> function to print the string and current number in the loop on each iteraton. However, in the result of running the function the <code class="language-text">phrase</code> is actually <code class="language-text">undefined</code>:</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="js"><pre class="language-js"><code class="language-js">printNumbers<span class="token punctuation">.</span><span class="token function">loop</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span></code></pre></div>
<p>This will give the following:</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="terminal"><pre class="language-terminal"><code class="language-terminal">undefined 1
undefined 2
undefined 3
undefined 4</code></pre></div>
<p>As this shows, <code class="language-text">this.phrase</code> is undefined, indicating that <code class="language-text">this</code> within the anonymous function passed into the <a href="https://www.digitalocean.com/community/tutorials/how-to-use-array-methods-in-javascript-iteration-methods#foreach()"><code class="language-text">forEach</code> method</a> does not refer to the <code class="language-text">printNumbers</code> object. This is because a traditional function will not determine its <code class="language-text">this</code> value from the scope of the environment, which is the <code class="language-text">printNumbers</code> object.</p>
<p>In older versions of JavaScript, you would have had to use the <code class="language-text">bind</code> method, which explicitly sets <code class="language-text">this</code>. This pattern can be found often in some earlier versions of frameworks, like <a href="https://reactjs.org/">React</a>, before the advent of ES6.</p>
<p>Use <code class="language-text">bind</code> to fix the function:</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="js"><pre class="language-js"><code class="language-js"><span class="token keyword">const</span> printNumbers <span class="token operator">=</span> <span class="token punctuation">{</span>
  phrase<span class="token operator">:</span> <span class="token string">'The current value is:'</span><span class="token punctuation">,</span>
  numbers<span class="token operator">:</span> <span class="token punctuation">[</span><span class="token number">1</span><span class="token punctuation">,</span> <span class="token number">2</span><span class="token punctuation">,</span> <span class="token number">3</span><span class="token punctuation">,</span> <span class="token number">4</span><span class="token punctuation">]</span><span class="token punctuation">,</span>

  <span class="token function">loop</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span> <span class="token punctuation">{</span>
    <span class="token comment">// Bind the `this` from printNumbers to the inner forEach function</span>
    <span class="token keyword">this</span><span class="token punctuation">.</span>numbers<span class="token punctuation">.</span><span class="token function">forEach</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span>
      <span class="token keyword">function</span> <span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token parameter">number</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span> <span class="token punctuation">{</span>
        console<span class="token punctuation">.</span><span class="token function">log</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token keyword">this</span><span class="token punctuation">.</span>phrase<span class="token punctuation">,</span> number<span class="token punctuation">)</span>
      <span class="token punctuation">}</span><span class="token punctuation">.</span><span class="token function">bind</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token keyword">this</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span><span class="token punctuation">,</span>
    <span class="token punctuation">)</span>
  <span class="token punctuation">}</span><span class="token punctuation">,</span>
<span class="token punctuation">}</span>

printNumbers<span class="token punctuation">.</span><span class="token function">loop</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span></code></pre></div>
<p>This will give the expected result:</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="terminal"><pre class="language-terminal"><code class="language-terminal">The current value is: 1
The current value is: 2
The current value is: 3
The current value is: 4</code></pre></div>
<p>Arrow functions can give a more direct way of dealing with this. Since their <code class="language-text">this</code> value is determined based on the lexical scope, the inner function called in <code class="language-text">forEach</code> can now access the properties of the outer <code class="language-text">printNumbers</code> object, as demonstrated:</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="js"><pre class="language-js"><code class="language-js"><span class="token keyword">const</span> printNumbers <span class="token operator">=</span> <span class="token punctuation">{</span>
  phrase<span class="token operator">:</span> <span class="token string">'The current value is:'</span><span class="token punctuation">,</span>
  numbers<span class="token operator">:</span> <span class="token punctuation">[</span><span class="token number">1</span><span class="token punctuation">,</span> <span class="token number">2</span><span class="token punctuation">,</span> <span class="token number">3</span><span class="token punctuation">,</span> <span class="token number">4</span><span class="token punctuation">]</span><span class="token punctuation">,</span>

  <span class="token function">loop</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span> <span class="token punctuation">{</span>
    <span class="token keyword">this</span><span class="token punctuation">.</span>numbers<span class="token punctuation">.</span><span class="token function">forEach</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token parameter">number</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span> <span class="token operator">=></span> <span class="token punctuation">{</span>
      console<span class="token punctuation">.</span><span class="token function">log</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token keyword">this</span><span class="token punctuation">.</span>phrase<span class="token punctuation">,</span> number<span class="token punctuation">)</span>
    <span class="token punctuation">}</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span>
  <span class="token punctuation">}</span><span class="token punctuation">,</span>
<span class="token punctuation">}</span>

printNumbers<span class="token punctuation">.</span><span class="token function">loop</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span></code></pre></div>
<p>This will give the expected result:</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="terminal"><pre class="language-terminal"><code class="language-terminal">The current value is: 1
The current value is: 2
The current value is: 3
The current value is: 4</code></pre></div>
<p>These examples establish that using arrow functions in built-in array methods like <a href="https://www.digitalocean.com/community/tutorials/how-to-use-array-methods-in-javascript-iteration-methods#foreach()"><code class="language-text">forEach</code></a>, <a href="https://www.digitalocean.com/community/tutorials/how-to-use-array-methods-in-javascript-iteration-methods#map()"><code class="language-text">map</code></a>, <a href="https://www.digitalocean.com/community/tutorials/how-to-use-array-methods-in-javascript-iteration-methods#filter()"><code class="language-text">filter</code></a>, and <a href="https://www.digitalocean.com/community/tutorials/how-to-use-array-methods-in-javascript-iteration-methods#reduce()"><code class="language-text">reduce</code></a> can be more intuitive and easier to read, making this strategy more likely to fulfill expectations.</p>
<h3 id="arrow-functions-as-object-methods" style="position:relative;"><a href="#arrow-functions-as-object-methods" aria-label="arrow functions as object methods permalink" class="anchor before"><svg aria-hidden="true" focusable="false" height="16" version="1.1" viewBox="0 0 16 16" width="16"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z"></path></svg></a>Arrow Functions as Object Methods</h3>
<p>While arrow functions are excellent as parameter functions passed into array methods, they are not effective as object methods because of the way they use lexical scoping for <code class="language-text">this</code>. Using the same example as before, take the <code class="language-text">loop</code> method and turn it into an arrow function to discover how it will execute:</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="js"><pre class="language-js"><code class="language-js"><span class="token keyword">const</span> printNumbers <span class="token operator">=</span> <span class="token punctuation">{</span>
  phrase<span class="token operator">:</span> <span class="token string">'The current value is:'</span><span class="token punctuation">,</span>
  numbers<span class="token operator">:</span> <span class="token punctuation">[</span><span class="token number">1</span><span class="token punctuation">,</span> <span class="token number">2</span><span class="token punctuation">,</span> <span class="token number">3</span><span class="token punctuation">,</span> <span class="token number">4</span><span class="token punctuation">]</span><span class="token punctuation">,</span>

  <span class="token function-variable function">loop</span><span class="token operator">:</span> <span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span> <span class="token operator">=></span> <span class="token punctuation">{</span>
    <span class="token keyword">this</span><span class="token punctuation">.</span>numbers<span class="token punctuation">.</span><span class="token function">forEach</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token parameter">number</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span> <span class="token operator">=></span> <span class="token punctuation">{</span>
      console<span class="token punctuation">.</span><span class="token function">log</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token keyword">this</span><span class="token punctuation">.</span>phrase<span class="token punctuation">,</span> number<span class="token punctuation">)</span>
    <span class="token punctuation">}</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span>
  <span class="token punctuation">}</span><span class="token punctuation">,</span>
<span class="token punctuation">}</span></code></pre></div>
<p>In this case of an object method, <code class="language-text">this</code> should refer to properties and methods of the <code class="language-text">printNumbers</code> object. However, since an object does not create a new lexical scope, an arrow function will look beyond the object for the value of <code class="language-text">this</code>.</p>
<p>Call the <code class="language-text">loop()</code> method:</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="js"><pre class="language-js"><code class="language-js">printNumbers<span class="token punctuation">.</span><span class="token function">loop</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span></code></pre></div>
<p>This will give the following:</p>
