<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="terminal"><pre class="language-terminal"><code class="language-terminal">Uncaught TypeError: Cannot read property &#39;forEach&#39; of undefined</code></pre></div>
<p>Since the object does not create a lexical scope, the arrow function method looks for <code class="language-text">this</code> in the outer scope–<a href="https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Window"><code class="language-text">Window</code></a> in this example. Since the <code class="language-text">numbers</code> property does not exist on the <code class="language-text">Window</code> object, it throws an error. As a general rule, it is safer to use traditional functions as object methods by default.</p>
<h3 id="arrow-functions-have-no-constructor-or-prototype" style="position:relative;"><a href="#arrow-functions-have-no-constructor-or-prototype" aria-label="arrow functions have no constructor or prototype permalink" class="anchor before"><svg aria-hidden="true" focusable="false" height="16" version="1.1" viewBox="0 0 16 16" width="16"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z"></path></svg></a>Arrow Functions Have No <code class="language-text">constructor</code> or <code class="language-text">prototype</code></h3>
<p>The <a href="https://www.digitalocean.com/community/tutorials/understanding-prototypes-and-inheritance-in-javascript">Understanding Prototypes and Inheritance in JavaScript</a> tutorial earlier in this series explained that functions and classes have a <code class="language-text">prototype</code> property, which is what JavaScript uses as a blueprint for cloning and inheritance.</p>
<p>To illustrate this, create a function and log the automatically assigned <code class="language-text">prototype</code> property:</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="js"><pre class="language-js"><code class="language-js"><span class="token keyword">function</span> <span class="token function">myFunction</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span> <span class="token punctuation">{</span>
  <span class="token keyword">this</span><span class="token punctuation">.</span>value <span class="token operator">=</span> <span class="token number">5</span>
<span class="token punctuation">}</span>

<span class="token comment">// Log the prototype property of myFunction</span>
console<span class="token punctuation">.</span><span class="token function">log</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span>myFunction<span class="token punctuation">.</span>prototype<span class="token punctuation">)</span></code></pre></div>
<p>This will print the following to the console:</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="terminal"><pre class="language-terminal"><code class="language-terminal">{constructor: ƒ}</code></pre></div>
<p>This shows that in the <code class="language-text">prototype</code> property there is an object with a <code class="language-text">constructor</code>. This allows you to use the <code class="language-text">new</code> keyword to create an instance of the function:</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="js"><pre class="language-js"><code class="language-js"><span class="token keyword">const</span> instance <span class="token operator">=</span> <span class="token keyword">new</span> <span class="token class-name">myFunction</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span>

console<span class="token punctuation">.</span><span class="token function">log</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span>instance<span class="token punctuation">.</span>value<span class="token punctuation">)</span></code></pre></div>
<p>This will yield the value of the <code class="language-text">value</code> property that you defined when you first declared the function:</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="terminal"><pre class="language-terminal"><code class="language-terminal">5</code></pre></div>
<p>In contrast, arrow functions do not have a <code class="language-text">prototype</code> property. Create a new arrow function and try to log its prototype:</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="js"><pre class="language-js"><code class="language-js"><span class="token keyword">const</span> <span class="token function-variable function">myArrowFunction</span> <span class="token operator">=</span> <span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span> <span class="token operator">=></span> <span class="token punctuation">{</span><span class="token punctuation">}</span>

<span class="token comment">// Attempt to log the prototype property of myArrowFunction</span>
console<span class="token punctuation">.</span><span class="token function">log</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span>myArrowFunction<span class="token punctuation">.</span>prototype<span class="token punctuation">)</span></code></pre></div>
<p>This will give the following:</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="terminal"><pre class="language-terminal"><code class="language-terminal">undefined</code></pre></div>
<p>As a result of the missing <code class="language-text">prototype</code> property, the <code class="language-text">new</code> keyword is not available and you cannot construct an instance from the arrow function:</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="js"><pre class="language-js"><code class="language-js"><span class="token keyword">const</span> arrowInstance <span class="token operator">=</span> <span class="token keyword">new</span> <span class="token class-name">myArrowFunction</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span>

console<span class="token punctuation">.</span><span class="token function">log</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span>arrowInstance<span class="token punctuation">)</span></code></pre></div>
<p>This will give the following error:</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="terminal"><pre class="language-terminal"><code class="language-terminal">Uncaught TypeError: myArrowFunction is not a constructor</code></pre></div>
<p>This is consistent with our earlier example: Since arrow functions do not have their own <code class="language-text">this</code> value, it follows that you would be unable to use an arrow function as a constructor.</p>
<p>As shown here, arrow functions have a lot of subtle changes that make them operate differently from traditional functions in ES5 and earlier. There have also been a few optional syntactical changes that make writing arrow functions quicker and less verbose. The next section will show examples of these syntax changes.</p>
<h3 id="implicit-return" style="position:relative;"><a href="#implicit-return" aria-label="implicit return permalink" class="anchor before"><svg aria-hidden="true" focusable="false" height="16" version="1.1" viewBox="0 0 16 16" width="16"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z"></path></svg></a>Implicit Return</h3>
<p>The body of a traditional function is contained within a block using curly brackets (<code class="language-text">{}</code>) and ends when the code encounters a <code class="language-text">return</code> keyword. The following is what this implementation looks like as an arrow function:</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="js"><pre class="language-js"><code class="language-js"><span class="token keyword">const</span> <span class="token function-variable function">sum</span> <span class="token operator">=</span> <span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token parameter">a<span class="token punctuation">,</span> b</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span> <span class="token operator">=></span> <span class="token punctuation">{</span>
  <span class="token keyword">return</span> a <span class="token operator">+</span> b
<span class="token punctuation">}</span></code></pre></div>
<p>Arrow functions introduce <em>concise body syntax</em>, or <em>implicit return</em>. This allows the omission of the curly brackets and the <code class="language-text">return</code> keyword.</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="js"><pre class="language-js"><code class="language-js"><span class="token keyword">const</span> <span class="token function-variable function">sum</span> <span class="token operator">=</span> <span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token parameter">a<span class="token punctuation">,</span> b</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span> <span class="token operator">=></span> a <span class="token operator">+</span> b</code></pre></div>
<p>Implicit return is useful for creating succinct one-line operations in <code class="language-text">map</code>, <code class="language-text">filter</code>, and other common array methods. Note that both the brackets and the <code class="language-text">return</code> keyword must be omitted. If you cannot write the body as a one-line return statement, then you will have to use the normal block body syntax.</p>
<p>In the case of returning an object, syntax requires that you wrap the object literal in parentheses. Otherwise, the brackets will be treated as a function body and will not compute a <code class="language-text">return</code> value.</p>
<p>To illustrate this, find the following example:</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="js"><pre class="language-js"><code class="language-js"><span class="token keyword">const</span> <span class="token function-variable function">sum</span> <span class="token operator">=</span> <span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token parameter">a<span class="token punctuation">,</span> b</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span> <span class="token operator">=></span> <span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token punctuation">{</span>result<span class="token operator">:</span> a <span class="token operator">+</span> b<span class="token punctuation">}</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span>

<span class="token function">sum</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token number">1</span><span class="token punctuation">,</span> <span class="token number">2</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span></code></pre></div>
<p>This will give the following output:</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="terminal"><pre class="language-terminal"><code class="language-terminal">{result: 3}</code></pre></div>
<h3 id="omitting-parentheses-around-a-single-parameter" style="position:relative;"><a href="#omitting-parentheses-around-a-single-parameter" aria-label="omitting parentheses around a single parameter permalink" class="anchor before"><svg aria-hidden="true" focusable="false" height="16" version="1.1" viewBox="0 0 16 16" width="16"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z"></path></svg></a>Omitting Parentheses Around a Single Parameter</h3>
<p>Another useful syntactic enhancement is the ability to remove parentheses from around a single parameter in a function. In the following example, the <code class="language-text">square</code> function only operates on one parameter, <code class="language-text">x</code>:</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="js"><pre class="language-js"><code class="language-js"><span class="token keyword">const</span> <span class="token function-variable function">square</span> <span class="token operator">=</span> <span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token parameter">x</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span> <span class="token operator">=></span> x <span class="token operator">*</span> x</code></pre></div>
<p>As a result, you can omit the parentheses around the parameter, and it will work just the same:</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="js"><pre class="language-js"><code class="language-js"><span class="token keyword">const</span> <span class="token function-variable function">square</span> <span class="token operator">=</span> <span class="token parameter">x</span> <span class="token operator">=></span> x <span class="token operator">*</span> x

<span class="token function">square</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token number">10</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span></code></pre></div>
<p>This will give the following:</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="terminal"><pre class="language-terminal"><code class="language-terminal">100</code></pre></div>
<p>Note that if a function takes no parameters, parentheses will be required:</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="js"><pre class="language-js"><code class="language-js"><span class="token keyword">const</span> <span class="token function-variable function">greet</span> <span class="token operator">=</span> <span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span> <span class="token operator">=></span> <span class="token string">'Hello!'</span>

<span class="token function">greet</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span></code></pre></div>
<p>Calling <code class="language-text">greet()</code> will work as follows:</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="terminal"><pre class="language-terminal"><code class="language-terminal">&#39;Hello!&#39;</code></pre></div>
<p>Some codebases choose to omit parentheses wherever possible, and others choose to always keep parentheses around parameters no matter what, particularly in codebases that use <a href="https://www.typescriptlang.org/">TypeScript</a> and require more information about each variable and parameter. When deciding how to write your arrow functions, check the style guide of the project to which you are contributing.</p>
<h2 id="conclusion" style="position:relative;"><a href="#conclusion" aria-label="conclusion permalink" class="anchor before"><svg aria-hidden="true" focusable="false" height="16" version="1.1" viewBox="0 0 16 16" width="16"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z"></path></svg></a>Conclusion</h2>
<p>In this article, you reviewed traditional functions and the difference between function declarations and function expressions. You learned that arrow functions are always anonymous, do not have a <code class="language-text">prototype</code> or <code class="language-text">constructor</code>, cannot be used with the <code class="language-text">new</code> keyword, and determine the value of <code class="language-text">this</code> through lexical scope. Finally, you explored the new syntactic enhancements available to arrow functions, such as implicit return and parentheses omission for single parameter functions.</p>
<p>For a review of basic functions, read <a href="https://www.digitalocean.com/community/tutorials/how-to-define-functions-in-javascript">How To Define Functions in JavaScript</a>. To read more about the concept of scope and hoisting in JavaScript, read <a href="https://www.digitalocean.com/community/tutorials/understanding-variables-scope-hoisting-in-javascript">Understanding Variables, Scope, and Hoisting in JavaScript</a>.</p></content:encoded><author>hello@taniarascia.com</author></item><item><title><![CDATA[Using Git Submodules for Private Content]]></title><description><![CDATA[My website has been open source for as long as it has existed. Originally, it was a WordPress site, but only the layout was out there for…]]></description><link>https://www.taniarascia.com/git-submodules-private-content/</link><guid isPermaLink="false">https://www.taniarascia.com/git-submodules-private-content/</guid><pubDate>Wed, 01 Jul 2020 00:00:00 GMT</pubDate><content:encoded><p>My website has been open source for as long as it has existed. Originally, it was a WordPress site, but only the layout was out there for everyone to see since the data was saved in a database. Once I moved to Gatsby, I kept all the images and posts in a <code class="language-text">content</code> directory. This was way better, as my content is all conveniently stored in one easy-to-save folder and the posts are all in beautiful markdown.</p>
<p>However, people often like my layout and want to use it, so they clone and deploy this site. Sometimes they will just leave up all the posts and images and update the name and image. Although I subscribe to the <a href="https://zenhabits.net/uncopyright/">Zenhabits Uncopyright</a> philosophy towards content - my content is out there for the world to see and do what they want with it, and it doesn't bother me - I don't think I should make it <em>quite</em> so easy to just clone everything I've written in a moment. If you're going to plagiarize, you should at least have to do a bit of work.</p>
<p>So I decided to store my content in a private <strong>git submodule</strong>. If you go to the <a href="https://github.com/taniarascia/taniarascia.com">repo</a> for this site now, you'll see a folder that looks like <code class="language-text">content @ &lt;hash></code>. If you click on it, you'll be taken to a 404 page. If I click on it, I'll be taken to a separate, private repo that contains all my images and posts.</p>
<p><span
      class="gatsby-resp-image-wrapper"
      style="position: relative; display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; max-width: 800px; "
    >
      <a
    class="gatsby-resp-image-link"
    href="/static/3a292e9aa32c06ded8fb122e42bdaf88/0e0c4/submodule.png"
    style="display: block"
    target="_blank"
    rel="noopener"
  >
    <span
    class="gatsby-resp-image-background-image"
    style="padding-bottom: 30%; position: relative; bottom: 0; left: 0; background-image: url('data:image/png;base64,'); background-size: cover; display: block;"
  ></span>
  <img
        class="gatsby-resp-image-image"
        alt="submodule"
        title="submodule"
        src="/static/3a292e9aa32c06ded8fb122e42bdaf88/5a190/submodule.png"
        srcset="/static/3a292e9aa32c06ded8fb122e42bdaf88/772e8/submodule.png 200w,
/static/3a292e9aa32c06ded8fb122e42bdaf88/e17e5/submodule.png 400w,
/static/3a292e9aa32c06ded8fb122e42bdaf88/5a190/submodule.png 800w,
/static/3a292e9aa32c06ded8fb122e42bdaf88/c1b63/submodule.png 1200w,
/static/3a292e9aa32c06ded8fb122e42bdaf88/29007/submodule.png 1600w,
/static/3a292e9aa32c06ded8fb122e42bdaf88/0e0c4/submodule.png 1884w"
        sizes="(max-width: 800px) 100vw, 800px"
        style="width:100%;height:100%;margin:0;vertical-align:middle;position:absolute;top:0;left:0;"
        loading="lazy"
        decoding="async"
      />
  </a>
    </span></p>
<p>A lot of people have asked me how to use private git submodules, so I'll go over it here. Note that this is not a deep-dive into submodules, but just the basics of adding, updating, and cloning a repo with submodules.</p>
<h2 id="git-submodules" style="position:relative;"><a href="#git-submodules" aria-label="git submodules permalink" class="anchor before"><svg aria-hidden="true" focusable="false" height="16" version="1.1" viewBox="0 0 16 16" width="16"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z"></path></svg></a>Git Submodules</h2>
<p><a href="https://git-scm.com/book/en/v2/Git-Tools-Submodules">Git submodules</a> allow you to keep a git repository as a subdirectory of another git repository.</p>
<p>This could be useful if you have a lot of projects within a project. One example of this is the <a href="https://github.com/dracula/dracula-theme">Dracula code theme</a> repo. Every folder is a git submodule. This allows people to add a new theme for a new program by creating their own repo, and the owner of the parent repository only needs to reference the child repos. You can tell they're all submodules because of the <code class="language-text">@ &lt;hash></code> after each subdirectory name.</p>
<p>Before doing anything with submodules, I would recommend running this command to update the config and set <a href="https://git-scm.com/docs/git-config#Documentation/git-config.txt-submodulerecurse">submodule.recurse</a> to <code class="language-text">true</code>, which allows <code class="language-text">git clone</code> and <code class="language-text">git pull</code> to automatically update submodules.</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="shell"><pre class="language-shell"><code class="language-shell"><span class="command-line-prompt"><span data-user=root data-host=localhost></span></span><span class="token function">git</span> config --global submodule.recurse <span class="token boolean">true</span></code></pre></div>
<table>
<thead>
<tr>
<th>Command</th>
<th>Description</th>
</tr>
</thead>
<tbody>
<tr>
<td><code class="language-text">git submodule add &lt;repo></code></td>
<td>Add a submodule within a repository</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td><code class="language-text">git submodule update</code></td>
<td>Update existing submodules within a repository (add <code class="language-text">--remote</code> to pull from a remote location)</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td><code class="language-text">git submodule init</code></td>
<td>Initialize local submodules file (only necessary if repo not cloned with <code class="language-text">--recurse-submodules</code>)</td>
</tr>
</tbody>
</table>
<h3 id="adding-a-submodule" style="position:relative;"><a href="#adding-a-submodule" aria-label="adding a submodule permalink" class="anchor before"><svg aria-hidden="true" focusable="false" height="16" version="1.1" viewBox="0 0 16 16" width="16"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z"></path></svg></a>Adding a submodule</h3>
<p>Let's imagine that you want a public blog, located on the <code class="language-text">blog</code> repo, to contain a submodule with all the posts, located in the <code class="language-text">posts</code> repo. So it will look like:</p>
<ul>
<li>A public repo at <code class="language-text">github.com/you/blog</code></li>
<li>A private repo at <code class="language-text">github.com/you/posts</code></li>
</ul>
<blockquote>
<p>I'm just using GitHub as an example, it doesn't matter where the repo is hosted. Also, git submodules can also be used for both private and public repos.</p>
</blockquote>
<p>First you can <code class="language-text">add</code> the submodule. From the root of <code class="language-text">blog</code>, you would run this command.</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="shell"><pre class="language-shell"><code class="language-shell"><span class="command-line-prompt"><span data-user=root data-host=localhost></span></span><span class="token function">git</span> submodule <span class="token function">add</span> https://github.com/you/posts</code></pre></div>
<p>This would clone the <code class="language-text">posts</code> repo into a folder in <code class="language-text">blog</code>.</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="terminal"><pre class="language-terminal"><code class="language-terminal">Cloning into &#39;/Users/you/blog/posts&#39;...</code></pre></div>
<p>You will now have two new entries into the <code class="language-text">blog</code> repo, a <code class="language-text">.gitmodules</code> file, and the new <code class="language-text">posts</code> subdirectory.</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="shell"><pre class="language-shell"><code class="language-shell"><span class="command-line-prompt"><span data-user=root data-host=localhost></span></span><span class="token function">git</span> status</code></pre></div>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="terminal"><pre class="language-terminal"><code class="language-terminal">Changes to be committed:
  (use &quot;git rm --cached &lt;file&gt;...&quot; to unstage)
	new file:   .gitmodules
	new file:   posts</code></pre></div>
<p><code class="language-text">.gitmodules</code> will look like this:</p>
<div class="filename">.gitmodules</div>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="bash"><pre class="language-bash"><code class="language-bash"><span class="command-line-prompt"><span data-user=root data-host=localhost></span><span data-user=root data-host=localhost></span><span data-user=root data-host=localhost></span></span><span class="token punctuation">[</span>submodule <span class="token string">"posts"</span><span class="token punctuation">]</span>
	path <span class="token operator">=</span> posts
	url <span class="token operator">=</span> https://github.com/you/posts</code></pre></div>
<p>At this point, you have a reference to the <code class="language-text">posts</code> repo as a submodule, so the directory structure will look like this:</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="text"><pre class="language-text"><code class="language-text">.git
.gitmodules
posts/</code></pre></div>
<blockquote>
<p>As a note, if you <code class="language-text">cd</code> into <code class="language-text">.git</code>, you'll see a <code class="language-text">modules</code> directory. This will contain a folder called <code class="language-text">posts</code>, and this is where git is storing references and other data about your submodules.</p>
</blockquote>
<h3 id="updating-a-submodule" style="position:relative;"><a href="#updating-a-submodule" aria-label="updating a submodule permalink" class="anchor before"><svg aria-hidden="true" focusable="false" height="16" version="1.1" viewBox="0 0 16 16" width="16"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z"></path></svg></a>Updating a submodule</h3>
<p>To update submodule content, you'll pull in any changes made to the remote submodule repo with the <code class="language-text">update</code> command. Since you would be updating content from a remote location, you'll add the <code class="language-text">--remote</code> flag. From the root of the <code class="language-text">blog</code> repo, you would run the command:</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="shell"><pre class="language-shell"><code class="language-shell"><span class="command-line-prompt"><span data-user=root data-host=localhost></span></span><span class="token function">git</span> submodule update --remote</code></pre></div>
<p>It's important to note that when working with submodules, you shouldn't work on or commit your local version of the submodule repo. If you made any changes locally, your version would now be out-of-sync with the submodule repo.</p>
<blockquote>
<p>You just want to treat a submodule as an entirely separate repo, but linked. This is much like code found in <code class="language-text">node_modules</code> for an node project, where the references to the projects are listed in <code class="language-text">package.json</code> and you know any local changes you make to a dependency in <code class="language-text">node_modules</code> will not be persisted.</p>
</blockquote>
<h4 id="modified-content" style="position:relative;"><a href="#modified-content" aria-label="modified content permalink" class="anchor before"><svg aria-hidden="true" focusable="false" height="16" version="1.1" viewBox="0 0 16 16" width="16"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z"></path></svg></a>Modified content</h4>
<p>If you make changes locally and run a git status, you will see <strong>modified content</strong> next to the modified submodule.</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="terminal"><pre class="language-terminal"><code class="language-terminal">Changes not staged for commit:
  (use &quot;git add &lt;file&gt;...&quot; to update what will be committed)
  (use &quot;git restore &lt;file&gt;...&quot; to discard changes in working directory)
  (commit or discard the untracked or modified content in submodules)
	modified:   posts (modified content)</code></pre></div>
<h4 id="new-commits" style="position:relative;"><a href="#new-commits" aria-label="new commits permalink" class="anchor before"><svg aria-hidden="true" focusable="false" height="16" version="1.1" viewBox="0 0 16 16" width="16"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z"></path></svg></a>New commits</h4>
<p>If you make changes to the submodule and bring those commits in properly and run a git status, you will see <strong>new commits</strong> next to the modified submodule.</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="terminal"><pre class="language-terminal"><code class="language-terminal">Changes not staged for commit:
  (use &quot;git add &lt;file&gt;...&quot; to update what will be committed)
  (use &quot;git restore &lt;file&gt;...&quot; to discard changes in working directory)
	modified:   posts (new commits)</code></pre></div>
<p>If you see <code class="language-text">(new commits)</code>, you can commit those changes on the parent repo. You can also check this by viewing the diff.</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="shell"><pre class="language-shell"><code class="language-shell"><span class="command-line-prompt"><span data-user=root data-host=localhost></span></span><span class="token function">git</span> <span class="token function">diff</span></code></pre></div>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="terminal"><pre class="language-terminal"><code class="language-terminal">diff --git a/posts b/posts
index abc..def 160000
--- a/posts
+++ b/posts
@@ -1 +1 @@
-Subproject commit abc...
+Subproject commit def...</code></pre></div>
<h3 id="cloning-a-repo-with-submodules" style="position:relative;"><a href="#cloning-a-repo-with-submodules" aria-label="cloning a repo with submodules permalink" class="anchor before"><svg aria-hidden="true" focusable="false" height="16" version="1.1" viewBox="0 0 16 16" width="16"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z"></path></svg></a>Cloning a repo with submodules</h3>
<p>If you clone an existing repository and it has submodules within it, you'll have to <code class="language-text">init</code> and <code class="language-text">update</code> to pull in all the submodule content.</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="shell"><pre class="language-shell"><code class="language-shell"><span class="command-line-prompt"><span data-user=root data-host=localhost></span></span><span class="token function">git</span> clone https://github.com/you/posts</code></pre></div>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="shell"><pre class="language-shell"><code class="language-shell"><span class="command-line-prompt"><span data-user=root data-host=localhost></span></span><span class="token builtin class-name">cd</span> posts <span class="token operator">&amp;&amp;</span> <span class="token function">git</span> submodule init <span class="token operator">&amp;&amp;</span> <span class="token function">git</span> submodule update</code></pre></div>
<p>You can bypass this by either having the <code class="language-text">submodules.recurse</code> setting set, or by using the <code class="language-text">--recurse-submodules</code> flag.</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="shell"><pre class="language-shell"><code class="language-shell"><span class="command-line-prompt"><span data-user=root data-host=localhost></span></span><span class="token function">git</span> clone --recurse-submodules https://github.com/you/posts</code></pre></div>
<p>This will clone the directory along with all submodule content.</p>
<h2 id="deployment" style="position:relative;"><a href="#deployment" aria-label="deployment permalink" class="anchor before"><svg aria-hidden="true" focusable="false" height="16" version="1.1" viewBox="0 0 16 16" width="16"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z"></path></svg></a>Deployment</h2>
<p>For my site, I've made the <code class="language-text">content</code> submodule private. If you have a Netlify site and want to know what to do to allow Netlify to pull from the private repo, <a href="https://community.netlify.com/t/support-guide-how-do-i-access-private-repositories-in-the-build-environment/723">here is an overview of the steps</a>.</p>
<ul>
<li><a href="https://docs.netlify.com/configure-builds/repo-permissions-linking/#deploy-keys">Generate a deploy key</a> from Netlify.</li>
<li>Add the key as a read-only deploy key on the settings for your private repo (found at <code class="language-text">github.com/you/repo/settings/keys</code>).</li>
<li>Netlify will now have permissions to fetch the submodules that it reads from your <code class="language-text">.gitmodules</code> file.</li>
</ul>
<h2 id="summary" style="position:relative;"><a href="#summary" aria-label="summary permalink" class="anchor before"><svg aria-hidden="true" focusable="false" height="16" version="1.1" viewBox="0 0 16 16" width="16"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z"></path></svg></a>Summary</h2>
<p>Here are the main points from the article:</p>
<ul>
<li>Submodules are used when a subdirectory in a repo should consist of all the data from another repo.</li>
<li>You can add a submodule to a project with <code class="language-text">git add submodule &lt;submodule-repo></code>.</li>
<li>You can update submodules within a project with <code class="language-text">git update submodule --remote</code>.</li>
<li>You should clone a project that has submodules with <code class="language-text">--recurse-submodules</code> or set <code class="language-text">submodule.recurse</code> in your config to do this by default.</li>
<li>You should not work on any submodule files directly within the parent repo. The submodule directory should be treated only as a reference to another existing repo.</li>
</ul>
<p>My current process for updating the site looks like:</p>
<ul>
<li>Make changes to <code class="language-text">content</code> repo.</li>
<li>Commit changes to <code class="language-text">content</code> and push to private submodule hosted on GitHub: <code class="language-text">git commit &amp;&amp; git push</code>.</li>
<li>Pull new updates into local <code class="language-text">taniarascia.com</code> repo: <code class="language-text">git submodule update --remote</code>.</li>
<li>Commit the new submodule changes and push to public GitHub repo: <code class="language-text">git commit &amp;&amp; git push</code>.</li>
<li>Netlify deploys the new site.</li>
</ul></content:encoded><author>hello@taniarascia.com</author></item><item><title><![CDATA[Understanding Template Literals in JavaScript]]></title><description><![CDATA[This article was originally written for DigitalOcean. Introduction The 2015 edition of the ECMAScript specification (ES6) added template…]]></description><link>https://www.taniarascia.com/understanding-template-literals/</link><guid isPermaLink="false">https://www.taniarascia.com/understanding-template-literals/</guid><pubDate>Tue, 30 Jun 2020 00:00:00 GMT</pubDate><content:encoded><p><em>This article was originally written for <a href="https://www.digitalocean.com/community/tutorials/understanding-template-literals-in-javascript">DigitalOcean</a>.</em></p>
<h3 id="introduction" style="position:relative;"><a href="#introduction" aria-label="introduction permalink" class="anchor before"><svg aria-hidden="true" focusable="false" height="16" version="1.1" viewBox="0 0 16 16" width="16"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z"></path></svg></a>Introduction</h3>
<p>The <a href="http://www.ecma-international.org/ecma-262/6.0/">2015 edition of the ECMAScript specification (ES6)</a> added <em>template literals</em> to the JavaScript language. Template literals are a new form of making <a href="https://www.digitalocean.com/community/tutorials/how-to-work-with-strings-in-javascript">strings in JavaScript</a> that add a lot of powerful new capabilities, such as creating multi-line strings more easily and using placeholders to embed expressions in a string. In addition, an advanced feature called <em>tagged template literals</em> allows you to perform operations on the expressions within a string. All of these capabilities increase your options for string manipulation as a developer, letting you more easily generate dynamic strings that could be used for <a href="https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Learn/Common_questions/What_is_a_URL">URLs</a> or functions that customize <a href="https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/HTML">HTML elements</a>.</p>
<p>In this article, you will go over the differences between single/double-quoted strings and template literals, running through the various ways to declare strings of different shape, including multi-line strings and dynamic strings that change depending on the value of a variable or expression. You will then learn about tagged templates and see some real-world examples of projects using them.</p>
<h2 id="declaring-strings" style="position:relative;"><a href="#declaring-strings" aria-label="declaring strings permalink" class="anchor before"><svg aria-hidden="true" focusable="false" height="16" version="1.1" viewBox="0 0 16 16" width="16"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z"></path></svg></a>Declaring Strings</h2>
<p>This section will review how to declare strings with single quotes and double quotes, and will then show how to do the same with template literals.</p>
<p>In JavaScript, a string can be written with single quotes (<code class="language-text">' '</code>):</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="js"><pre class="language-js"><code class="language-js"><span class="token keyword">const</span> single <span class="token operator">=</span> <span class="token string">'Every day is a good day when you paint.'</span></code></pre></div>
<p>A string can also be written with double quotes (<code class="language-text">" "</code>):</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="js"><pre class="language-js"><code class="language-js"><span class="token keyword">const</span> double <span class="token operator">=</span> <span class="token string">"Be so very light. Be a gentle whisper."</span></code></pre></div>
<p>There is no major difference in JavaScript between single- or double-quoted strings, unlike other languages that might allow <em>interpolation</em> in one type of string but not the other. In this context, interpolation refers to the evaluation of a placeholder as a dynamic part of a string.</p>
<p>The use of single- or double-quoted strings mostly comes down to personal preference and convention, but used in conjunction, each type of string only needs to <a href="https://www.digitalocean.com/community/tutorials/how-to-work-with-strings-in-javascript#escaping-quotes-and-apostrophes-in-strings">escape</a> its own type of quote:</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="js"><pre class="language-js"><code class="language-js"><span class="token comment">// Escaping a single quote in a single-quoted string</span>
<span class="token keyword">const</span> single <span class="token operator">=</span> <span class="token string">'"We don\'t make mistakes. We just have happy accidents." - Bob Ross'</span>

<span class="token comment">// Escaping a double quote in a double-quoted string</span>
<span class="token keyword">const</span> double <span class="token operator">=</span> <span class="token string">"\"We don't make mistakes. We just have happy accidents.\" - Bob Ross"</span>

console<span class="token punctuation">.</span><span class="token function">log</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span>single<span class="token punctuation">)</span>
console<span class="token punctuation">.</span><span class="token function">log</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span>double<span class="token punctuation">)</span></code></pre></div>
<p>The result of the <code class="language-text">log()</code> method here will print the same two strings to the <a href="https://www.digitalocean.com/community/tutorials/how-to-use-the-javascript-developer-console">console</a>:</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="terminal"><pre class="language-terminal"><code class="language-terminal">&quot;We don&#39;t make mistakes. We just have happy accidents.&quot; - Bob Ross
&quot;We don&#39;t make mistakes. We just have happy accidents.&quot; - Bob Ross</code></pre></div>
<p>Template literals, on the other hand, are written by surrounding the string with the backtick character, or grave accent (<code class="language-text">`</code>):</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="js"><pre class="language-js"><code class="language-js"><span class="token keyword">const</span> template <span class="token operator">=</span> <span class="token template-string"><span class="token template-punctuation string">`</span><span class="token string">Find freedom on this canvas.</span><span class="token template-punctuation string">`</span></span></code></pre></div>
<p>They do not need to escape single or double quotes:</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="js"><pre class="language-js"><code class="language-js"><span class="token keyword">const</span> template <span class="token operator">=</span> <span class="token template-string"><span class="token template-punctuation string">`</span><span class="token string">"We don't make mistakes. We just have happy accidents." - Bob Ross</span><span class="token template-punctuation string">`</span></span></code></pre></div>
<p>However, they do still need to escape backticks:</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="js"><pre class="language-js"><code class="language-js"><span class="token keyword">const</span> template <span class="token operator">=</span> <span class="token template-string"><span class="token template-punctuation string">`</span><span class="token string">Template literals use the \` character.</span><span class="token template-punctuation string">`</span></span></code></pre></div>
<p>Template literals can do everything that regular strings can, so you could possibly replace all strings in your project with them and have the same functionality. However, the most common convention in codebases is to only use template literals when using the additional capabilities of template literals, and consistently using the single or double quotes for all other simple strings. Following this standard will make your code easier to read if examined by another developer.</p>
<p>Now that you've seen how to declare strings with single quotes, double quotes, and backticks, you can move on to the first advantage of template literals: writing multi-line strings.</p>
<h2 id="multi-line-strings" style="position:relative;"><a href="#multi-line-strings" aria-label="multi line strings permalink" class="anchor before"><svg aria-hidden="true" focusable="false" height="16" version="1.1" viewBox="0 0 16 16" width="16"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z"></path></svg></a>Multi-line Strings</h2>
<p>In this section, you will first run through the way strings with multiple lines were declared before ES6, then see how template literals make this easier.</p>
<p>Originally, if you wanted to write a string that spans multiple lines in your text editor, you would use the <a href="https://www.digitalocean.com/community/tutorials/how-to-work-with-strings-in-javascript#string-concatenation">concatenation operator</a>. However, this was not always a straight-forward process. The following string concatenation seemed to run over multiple lines:</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="js"><pre class="language-js"><code class="language-js"><span class="token keyword">const</span> address <span class="token operator">=</span> <span class="token string">'Homer J. Simpson'</span> <span class="token operator">+</span> <span class="token string">'742 Evergreen Terrace'</span> <span class="token operator">+</span> <span class="token string">'Springfield'</span></code></pre></div>
<p>This might allow you to break up the string into smaller lines and include it over multiple lines in the text editor, but it has no effect on the output of the string. In this case, the strings will all be on one line and not separated by newlines or spaces. If you logged <code class="language-text">address</code> to the console, you would get the following:</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="terminal"><pre class="language-terminal"><code class="language-terminal">Homer J. Simpson742 Evergreen TerraceSpringfield</code></pre></div>
<p>The backslash character (<code class="language-text">\</code>) can be used to continue the string onto multiple lines:</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="js"><pre class="language-js"><code class="language-js"><span class="token keyword">const</span> address <span class="token operator">=</span>
  <span class="token string">'Homer J. Simpson\
  742 Evergreen Terrace\
  Springfield'</span></code></pre></div>
<p>This will retain any indentation as whitespace, but the string will still be on one line in the output:</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="terminal"><pre class="language-terminal"><code class="language-terminal">Homer J. Simpson  742 Evergreen Terrace  Springfield</code></pre></div>
<p>Using the newline character (<code class="language-text">\n</code>), you can create a true multi-line string:</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="js"><pre class="language-js"><code class="language-js"><span class="token keyword">const</span> address <span class="token operator">=</span> <span class="token string">'Homer J. Simpson\n'</span> <span class="token operator">+</span> <span class="token string">'742 Evergreen Terrace\n'</span> <span class="token operator">+</span> <span class="token string">'Springfield'</span></code></pre></div>
<p>When logged to the console, this will display the following:</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="terminal"><pre class="language-terminal"><code class="language-terminal">Homer J. Simpson
742 Evergreen Terrace
Springfield</code></pre></div>
<p>Using newline characters to designate multi-line strings can be counterintuitive, however. In contrast, creating a multi-line string with template literals can be much more straight-forward. There is no need to concatenate, use newline characters, or use backslashes. Just pressing enter and writing the string across multiple lines works by default:</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="js"><pre class="language-js"><code class="language-js"><span class="token keyword">const</span> address <span class="token operator">=</span> <span class="token template-string"><span class="token template-punctuation string">`</span><span class="token string">Homer J. Simpson
742 Evergreen Terrace
Springfield</span><span class="token template-punctuation string">`</span></span></code></pre></div>
<p>The output of logging this to the console is the same as the input:</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="terminal"><pre class="language-terminal"><code class="language-terminal">Homer J. Simpson
742 Evergreen Terrace
Springfield</code></pre></div>
<p>Any indentation will be preserved, so it's important not to indent any additional lines in the string if that is not desired. For example, consider the following:</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="js"><pre class="language-js"><code class="language-js"><span class="token keyword">const</span> address <span class="token operator">=</span> <span class="token template-string"><span class="token template-punctuation string">`</span><span class="token string">Homer J. Simpson
                 742 Evergreen Terrace
                 Springfield</span><span class="token template-punctuation string">`</span></span></code></pre></div>
<p>Although this style of writing the line might make the code more human readable, the output will not be:</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="terminal"><pre class="language-terminal"><code class="language-terminal">Homer J. Simpson
                 742 Evergreen Terrace
                 Springfield</code></pre></div>
<p>With multi-line strings now covered, the next section will deal with how expressions are interpolated into their values with the different string declarations.</p>
<h2 id="expression-interpolation" style="position:relative;"><a href="#expression-interpolation" aria-label="expression interpolation permalink" class="anchor before"><svg aria-hidden="true" focusable="false" height="16" version="1.1" viewBox="0 0 16 16" width="16"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z"></path></svg></a>Expression Interpolation</h2>
<p>In strings before ES6, concatenation was used to create a dynamic string with variables or expressions:</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="js"><pre class="language-js"><code class="language-js"><span class="token keyword">const</span> method <span class="token operator">=</span> <span class="token string">'concatenation'</span>
<span class="token keyword">const</span> dynamicString <span class="token operator">=</span> <span class="token string">'This string is using '</span> <span class="token operator">+</span> method <span class="token operator">+</span> <span class="token string">'.'</span></code></pre></div>
<p>When logged to the console, this will yield the following:</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="terminal"><pre class="language-terminal"><code class="language-terminal">This string is using concatenation.</code></pre></div>
<p>With template literals, an expression can be embedded in a <em>placeholder</em>. A placeholder is represented by <code class="language-text">${}</code>, with anything within the curly brackets treated as JavaScript and anything outside the brackets treated as a string:</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="js"><pre class="language-js"><code class="language-js"><span class="token keyword">const</span> method <span class="token operator">=</span> <span class="token string">'interpolation'</span>
<span class="token keyword">const</span> dynamicString <span class="token operator">=</span> <span class="token template-string"><span class="token template-punctuation string">`</span><span class="token string">This string is using </span><span class="token interpolation"><span class="token interpolation-punctuation punctuation">${</span>method<span class="token interpolation-punctuation punctuation">}</span></span><span class="token string">.</span><span class="token template-punctuation string">`</span></span></code></pre></div>
<p>When <code class="language-text">dynamicString</code> is logged to the console, the console will show the following:</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="terminal"><pre class="language-terminal"><code class="language-terminal">This string is using interpolation.</code></pre></div>
<p>One common example of embedding values in a string might be for creating dynamic URLs. With concatenation, this can be cumbersome. For example, the following declares a <a href="https://www.digitalocean.com/community/tutorials/how-to-define-functions-in-javascript">function</a> to generate an <a href="https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc6749">OAuth</a> access string:</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="js"><pre class="language-js"><code class="language-js"><span class="token keyword">function</span> <span class="token function">createOAuthString</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token parameter">host<span class="token punctuation">,</span> clientId<span class="token punctuation">,</span> scope</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span> <span class="token punctuation">{</span>
  <span class="token keyword">return</span> host <span class="token operator">+</span> <span class="token string">'/login/oauth/authorize?client_id='</span> <span class="token operator">+</span> clientId <span class="token operator">+</span> <span class="token string">'&amp;scope='</span> <span class="token operator">+</span> scope
<span class="token punctuation">}</span>

<span class="token function">createOAuthString</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token string">'https://github.com'</span><span class="token punctuation">,</span> <span class="token string">'abc123'</span><span class="token punctuation">,</span> <span class="token string">'repo,user'</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span></code></pre></div>
<p>Logging this function will yield the following URL to the console:</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="terminal"><pre class="language-terminal"><code class="language-terminal">https://github.com/login/oauth/authorize?client_id=abc123&amp;scope=repo,user</code></pre></div>
<p>Using string interpolation, you no longer have to keep track of opening and closing strings and concatenation operator placement. Here is the same example with template literals:</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="js"><pre class="language-js"><code class="language-js"><span class="token keyword">function</span> <span class="token function">createOAuthString</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token parameter">host<span class="token punctuation">,</span> clientId<span class="token punctuation">,</span> scope</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span> <span class="token punctuation">{</span>
  <span class="token keyword">return</span> <span class="token template-string"><span class="token template-punctuation string">`</span><span class="token interpolation"><span class="token interpolation-punctuation punctuation">${</span>host<span class="token interpolation-punctuation punctuation">}</span></span><span class="token string">/login/oauth/authorize?client_id=</span><span class="token interpolation"><span class="token interpolation-punctuation punctuation">${</span>clientId<span class="token interpolation-punctuation punctuation">}</span></span><span class="token string">&amp;scope=</span><span class="token interpolation"><span class="token interpolation-punctuation punctuation">${</span>scope<span class="token interpolation-punctuation punctuation">}</span></span><span class="token template-punctuation string">`</span></span>
<span class="token punctuation">}</span>

<span class="token function">createOAuthString</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token string">'https://github.com'</span><span class="token punctuation">,</span> <span class="token string">'abc123'</span><span class="token punctuation">,</span> <span class="token string">'repo,user'</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span></code></pre></div>
<p>This will have the same output as the concatenation example:</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="terminal"><pre class="language-terminal"><code class="language-terminal">https://github.com/login/oauth/authorize?client_id=abc123&amp;scope=repo,user</code></pre></div>
<p>The <a href="https://www.digitalocean.com/community/tutorials/how-to-index-split-and-manipulate-strings-in-javascript#trimming-whitespace"><code class="language-text">trim()</code> method</a> can also be used on a template literal to remove any whitespace at the beginning or end of the string. For example, the following uses an <a href="https://www.digitalocean.com/community/tutorials/how-to-define-functions-in-javascript#arrow-functions">arrow function</a> to create an HTML <a href="https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/HTML/Element/li"><code class="language-text">&lt;li></code> element</a> with a customized link:</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="js"><pre class="language-js"><code class="language-js"><span class="token keyword">const</span> <span class="token function-variable function">menuItem</span> <span class="token operator">=</span> <span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token parameter">url<span class="token punctuation">,</span> link</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span> <span class="token operator">=></span>
  <span class="token template-string"><span class="token template-punctuation string">`</span><span class="token string">
&lt;li>
  &lt;a href="</span><span class="token interpolation"><span class="token interpolation-punctuation punctuation">${</span>url<span class="token interpolation-punctuation punctuation">}</span></span><span class="token string">"></span><span class="token interpolation"><span class="token interpolation-punctuation punctuation">${</span>link<span class="token interpolation-punctuation punctuation">}</span></span><span class="token string">&lt;/a>
&lt;/li>
</span><span class="token template-punctuation string">`</span></span><span class="token punctuation">.</span><span class="token function">trim</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span>

<span class="token function">menuItem</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token string">'https://google.com'</span><span class="token punctuation">,</span> <span class="token string">'Google'</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span></code></pre></div>
<p>The result will be trimmed of all the whitespace, ensuring that the element will be rendered correctly:</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="terminal"><pre class="language-terminal"><code class="language-terminal">&lt;li&gt;
  &lt;a href=&quot;https://google.com&quot;&gt;Google&lt;/a&gt;
&lt;/li&gt;</code></pre></div>
<p>Entire expressions can be interpolated, not just variables, such as in this example of the sum of two numbers:</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="js"><pre class="language-js"><code class="language-js"><span class="token keyword">const</span> <span class="token function-variable function">sum</span> <span class="token operator">=</span> <span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token parameter">x<span class="token punctuation">,</span> y</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span> <span class="token operator">=></span> x <span class="token operator">+</span> y
<span class="token keyword">const</span> x <span class="token operator">=</span> <span class="token number">5</span>
<span class="token keyword">const</span> y <span class="token operator">=</span> <span class="token number">100</span>
<span class="token keyword">const</span> string <span class="token operator">=</span> <span class="token template-string"><span class="token template-punctuation string">`</span><span class="token string">The sum of </span><span class="token interpolation"><span class="token interpolation-punctuation punctuation">${</span>x<span class="token interpolation-punctuation punctuation">}</span></span><span class="token string"> and </span><span class="token interpolation"><span class="token interpolation-punctuation punctuation">${</span>y<span class="token interpolation-punctuation punctuation">}</span></span><span class="token string"> is </span><span class="token interpolation"><span class="token interpolation-punctuation punctuation">${</span><span class="token function">sum</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span>x<span class="token punctuation">,</span> y<span class="token punctuation">)</span><span class="token interpolation-punctuation punctuation">}</span></span><span class="token string">.</span><span class="token template-punctuation string">`</span></span>

console<span class="token punctuation">.</span><span class="token function">log</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span>string<span class="token punctuation">)</span></code></pre></div>
<p>This code defines the <code class="language-text">sum</code> function and the variables <code class="language-text">x</code> and <code class="language-text">y</code>, then uses both the function and the variables in a string. The logged result will show the following:</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="terminal"><pre class="language-terminal"><code class="language-terminal">The sum of 5 and 100 is 105.</code></pre></div>
<p>This can be particularly useful with <a href="https://www.digitalocean.com/community/tutorials/how-to-write-conditional-statements-in-javascript#ternary-operator">ternary operators</a>, which allow conditionals within a string:</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="js"><pre class="language-js"><code class="language-js"><span class="token keyword">const</span> age <span class="token operator">=</span> <span class="token number">19</span>
<span class="token keyword">const</span> message <span class="token operator">=</span> <span class="token template-string"><span class="token template-punctuation string">`</span><span class="token string">You can </span><span class="token interpolation"><span class="token interpolation-punctuation punctuation">${</span>age <span class="token operator">&lt;</span> <span class="token number">21</span> <span class="token operator">?</span> <span class="token string">'not'</span> <span class="token operator">:</span> <span class="token string">''</span><span class="token interpolation-punctuation punctuation">}</span></span><span class="token string"> view this page</span><span class="token template-punctuation string">`</span></span>
console<span class="token punctuation">.</span><span class="token function">log</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span>message<span class="token punctuation">)</span></code></pre></div>
<p>The logged message here will change depnding on whether the value of <code class="language-text">age</code> is over or under <code class="language-text">21</code>. Since it is <code class="language-text">19</code> in this example, the following output will be logged:</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="terminal"><pre class="language-terminal"><code class="language-terminal">You can not view this page</code></pre></div>
<p>Now you have an idea of how template literals can be useful when used to interpolate expressions. The next section will take this a step further by examining tagged template literals to work with the expressions passed into placeholders.</p>
<h2 id="tagged-template-literals" style="position:relative;"><a href="#tagged-template-literals" aria-label="tagged template literals permalink" class="anchor before"><svg aria-hidden="true" focusable="false" height="16" version="1.1" viewBox="0 0 16 16" width="16"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z"></path></svg></a>Tagged Template Literals</h2>
<p>An advanced feature of template literals is the use of <em>tagged template literals</em>, sometimes referred to as <em>template tags</em>. A tagged template starts with a <em>tag function</em> that parses a template literal, allowing you more control over manipulating and returning a dynamic string.</p>
<p>In this example, you'll create a <code class="language-text">tag</code> function to use as the function operating on a tagged template. The string literals are the first parameter of the function, named <code class="language-text">strings</code> here, and any expressions interpolated into the string are packed into the second parameter using <a href="https://www.digitalocean.com/community/tutorials/understanding-destructuring-rest-parameters-and-spread-syntax-in-javascript">rest parameters</a>. You can console out the parameter to see what they will contain:</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="js"><pre class="language-js"><code class="language-js"><span class="token keyword">function</span> <span class="token function">tag</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token parameter">strings<span class="token punctuation">,</span> <span class="token operator">...</span>expressions</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span> <span class="token punctuation">{</span>
  console<span class="token punctuation">.</span><span class="token function">log</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span>strings<span class="token punctuation">)</span>
  console<span class="token punctuation">.</span><span class="token function">log</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span>expressions<span class="token punctuation">)</span>
<span class="token punctuation">}</span></code></pre></div>
<p>Use the <code class="language-text">tag</code> function as the tagged template function and parse the string as follows:</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="js"><pre class="language-js"><code class="language-js"><span class="token keyword">const</span> string <span class="token operator">=</span> tag<span class="token template-string"><span class="token template-punctuation string">`</span><span class="token string">This is a string with </span><span class="token interpolation"><span class="token interpolation-punctuation punctuation">${</span><span class="token boolean">true</span><span class="token interpolation-punctuation punctuation">}</span></span><span class="token string"> and </span><span class="token interpolation"><span class="token interpolation-punctuation punctuation">${</span><span class="token boolean">false</span><span class="token interpolation-punctuation punctuation">}</span></span><span class="token string"> and </span><span class="token interpolation"><span class="token interpolation-punctuation punctuation">${</span><span class="token number">100</span><span class="token interpolation-punctuation punctuation">}</span></span><span class="token string"> interpolated inside.</span><span class="token template-punctuation string">`</span></span></code></pre></div>
<p>Since you're console logging <code class="language-text">strings</code> and <code class="language-text">expressions</code>, this will be the output:</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="terminal"><pre class="language-terminal"><code class="language-terminal">(4) [&quot;This is a string with &quot;, &quot; and &quot;, &quot; and &quot;, &quot; interpolated inside.&quot;
(3) [true, false, 100]</code></pre></div>
<p>The first parameter, <code class="language-text">strings</code>, is an <a href="https://www.digitalocean.com/community/tutorials/understanding-arrays-in-javascript">array</a> containing all the string literals:</p>
<ul>
<li><code class="language-text">"This is a string with "</code></li>
<li><code class="language-text">" and "</code></li>
<li><code class="language-text">" and "</code></li>
<li><code class="language-text">" interpolated inside."</code></li>
</ul>
<p>There is also a <code class="language-text">raw</code> property available on this argument at <code class="language-text">strings.raw</code>, which contains the strings without any escape sequences being processed. For example, <code class="language-text">/n</code> would just be the character <code class="language-text">/n</code> and not be escaped into a newline.</p>
<p>The second parameter, <code class="language-text">...expressions</code>, is a rest parameter array consisting of all the expressions:</p>
<ul>
<li><code class="language-text">true</code></li>
<li><code class="language-text">false</code></li>
<li><code class="language-text">100</code></li>
</ul>
<p>The string literals and expressions are passed as parameters to the tagged template function <code class="language-text">tag</code>. Note that the tagged template does not need to return a string; it can operate on those values and return any type of value. For example, we can have the function ignore everything and return <code class="language-text">null</code>, as in this <code class="language-text">returnsNull</code> function:</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="js"><pre class="language-js"><code class="language-js"><span class="token keyword">function</span> <span class="token function">returnsNull</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token parameter">strings<span class="token punctuation">,</span> <span class="token operator">...</span>expressions</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span> <span class="token punctuation">{</span>
  <span class="token keyword">return</span> <span class="token keyword">null</span>
<span class="token punctuation">}</span>

<span class="token keyword">const</span> string <span class="token operator">=</span> returnsNull<span class="token template-string"><span class="token template-punctuation string">`</span><span class="token string">Does this work?</span><span class="token template-punctuation string">`</span></span>
console<span class="token punctuation">.</span><span class="token function">log</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span>string<span class="token punctuation">)</span></code></pre></div>
<p>Logging the <code class="language-text">string</code> variable will return:</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="terminal"><pre class="language-terminal"><code class="language-terminal">null</code></pre></div>
<p>An example of an action that can be performed in tagged templates is applying some change to both sides of each expression, such as if you wanted to wrap each expression in an HTML tag. Create a <code class="language-text">bold</code> function that will add <code class="language-text">&lt;strong></code> and <code class="language-text">&lt;/strong></code> to each expression:</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="js"><pre class="language-js"><code class="language-js"><span class="token keyword">function</span> <span class="token function">bold</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token parameter">strings<span class="token punctuation">,</span> <span class="token operator">...</span>expressions</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span> <span class="token punctuation">{</span>
  <span class="token keyword">let</span> finalString <span class="token operator">=</span> <span class="token string">''</span>

  <span class="token comment">// Loop through all expressions</span>
  expressions<span class="token punctuation">.</span><span class="token function">forEach</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token parameter">value<span class="token punctuation">,</span> i</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span> <span class="token operator">=></span> <span class="token punctuation">{</span>
    finalString <span class="token operator">+=</span> <span class="token template-string"><span class="token template-punctuation string">`</span><span class="token interpolation"><span class="token interpolation-punctuation punctuation">${</span>strings<span class="token punctuation">[</span>i<span class="token punctuation">]</span><span class="token interpolation-punctuation punctuation">}</span></span><span class="token string">&lt;strong></span><span class="token interpolation"><span class="token interpolation-punctuation punctuation">${</span>value<span class="token interpolation-punctuation punctuation">}</span></span><span class="token string">&lt;/strong></span><span class="token template-punctuation string">`</span></span>
  <span class="token punctuation">}</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span>

  <span class="token comment">// Add the last string literal</span>
  finalString <span class="token operator">+=</span> strings<span class="token punctuation">[</span>strings<span class="token punctuation">.</span>length <span class="token operator">-</span> <span class="token number">1</span><span class="token punctuation">]</span>

  <span class="token keyword">return</span> finalString
<span class="token punctuation">}</span>

<span class="token keyword">const</span> string <span class="token operator">=</span> bold<span class="token template-string"><span class="token template-punctuation string">`</span><span class="token string">This is a string with </span><span class="token interpolation"><span class="token interpolation-punctuation punctuation">${</span><span class="token boolean">true</span><span class="token interpolation-punctuation punctuation">}</span></span><span class="token string"> and </span><span class="token interpolation"><span class="token interpolation-punctuation punctuation">${</span><span class="token boolean">false</span><span class="token interpolation-punctuation punctuation">}</span></span><span class="token string"> and </span><span class="token interpolation"><span class="token interpolation-punctuation punctuation">${</span><span class="token number">100</span><span class="token interpolation-punctuation punctuation">}</span></span><span class="token string"> interpolated inside.</span><span class="token template-punctuation string">`</span></span>

console<span class="token punctuation">.</span><span class="token function">log</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span>string<span class="token punctuation">)</span></code></pre></div>
<p>This code uses the <a href="https://www.digitalocean.com/community/tutorials/how-to-use-array-methods-in-javascript-iteration-methods#foreach()"><code class="language-text">forEach</code> method</a> to loop over the <code class="language-text">expressions</code> array and add the bolding element:</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="terminal"><pre class="language-terminal"><code class="language-terminal">This is a string with &lt;strong&gt;true&lt;/strong&gt; and &lt;strong&gt;false&lt;/strong&gt; and &lt;strong&gt;100&lt;/strong&gt; interpolated inside.</code></pre></div>
<p>There are a few examples of tagged template literals in popular JavaScript libraries. The <a href="https://github.com/apollographql/graphql-tag"><code class="language-text">graphql-tag</code></a> library uses the <code class="language-text">gql</code> tagged template to parse <a href="https://graphql.org/">GraphQL</a> query strings into the abstract syntax tree (AST) that GraphQL understands:</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="js"><pre class="language-js"><code class="language-js"><span class="token keyword">import</span> gql <span class="token keyword">from</span> <span class="token string">'graphql-tag'</span>

<span class="token comment">// A query to retrieve the first and last name from user 5</span>
<span class="token keyword">const</span> query <span class="token operator">=</span> gql<span class="token template-string"><span class="token template-punctuation string">`</span><span class="token string">
  {
    user(id: 5) {
      firstName
      lastName
    }
  }
</span><span class="token template-punctuation string">`</span></span></code></pre></div>
<p>Another library that uses tagged template functions is <a href="https://github.com/styled-components/styled-components"><code class="language-text">styled-components</code></a>, which allows you to create new <a href="https://www.digitalocean.com/community/tutorials/how-to-create-custom-components-in-react">React components</a> from regular <a href="https://www.digitalocean.com/community/tutorials/introduction-to-the-dom">DOM</a> elements and apply additional <a href="https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS">CSS styles</a> to them:</p>
