Introduction Many new features for working with arrays and objects have been made…]]></description><link>https://www.taniarascia.com/understanding-destructuring-rest-spread/</link><guid isPermaLink="false">https://www.taniarascia.com/understanding-destructuring-rest-spread/</guid><pubDate>Thu, 14 May 2020 00:00:00 GMT</pubDate><content:encoded><p><em>This article was originally written for <a href="https://www.digitalocean.com/community/tutorials/understanding-destructuring-rest-parameters-and-spread-syntax-in-javascript">DigitalOcean</a>.</em></p>
<h3 id="introduction" style="position:relative;"><a href="#introduction" aria-label="introduction permalink" class="anchor before"><svg aria-hidden="true" focusable="false" height="16" version="1.1" viewBox="0 0 16 16" width="16"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z"></path></svg></a>Introduction</h3>
<p>Many new features for working with <a href="https://www.digitalocean.com/community/tutorials/understanding-arrays-in-javascript">arrays</a> and <a href="https://www.digitalocean.com/community/tutorials/understanding-objects-in-javascript">objects</a> have been made available to the <a href="https://www.digitalocean.com/community/tutorial_series/how-to-code-in-javascript">JavaScript</a> language since the <a href="http://www.ecma-international.org/ecma-262/6.0/">2015 Edition</a> of the ECMAScript specification. A few of the notable ones that you will learn in this article are <em>destructuring</em>, <em>rest parameters</em>, and <em>spread</em> syntax. These features provide more direct ways of accessing the members of an array or an object, and can make working with these data structures quicker and more succinct.</p>
<p>Many other languages do not have corresponding syntax for destructuring, rest parameters, and spread, so these features may have a learning curve both for new JavaScript developers and those coming from another language. In this article, you will learn how to destructure objects and arrays, how to use the spread operator to unpack objects and arrays, and how to use rest parameters in function calls.</p>
<h2 id="destructuring" style="position:relative;"><a href="#destructuring" aria-label="destructuring permalink" class="anchor before"><svg aria-hidden="true" focusable="false" height="16" version="1.1" viewBox="0 0 16 16" width="16"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z"></path></svg></a>Destructuring</h2>
<p><em>Destructuring assignment</em> is a syntax that allows you to assign object properties or array items as variables. This can greatly reduce the lines of code necessary to manipulate data in these structures. There are two types of destructuring: Object destructuring and Array destructuring.</p>
<h3 id="object-destructuring" style="position:relative;"><a href="#object-destructuring" aria-label="object destructuring permalink" class="anchor before"><svg aria-hidden="true" focusable="false" height="16" version="1.1" viewBox="0 0 16 16" width="16"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z"></path></svg></a>Object Destructuring</h3>
<p>Object destructuring allows you to create new <a href="https://www.digitalocean.com/community/tutorials/understanding-variables-scope-hoisting-in-javascript#understanding-variables">variables</a> using an object property as the value.</p>
<p>Consider this example, an object that represents a note with an <code class="language-text">id</code>, <code class="language-text">title</code>, and <code class="language-text">date</code>:</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="js"><pre class="language-js"><code class="language-js"><span class="token keyword">const</span> note <span class="token operator">=</span> <span class="token punctuation">{</span>
  id<span class="token operator">:</span> <span class="token number">1</span><span class="token punctuation">,</span>
  title<span class="token operator">:</span> <span class="token string">'My first note'</span><span class="token punctuation">,</span>
  date<span class="token operator">:</span> <span class="token string">'01/01/1970'</span><span class="token punctuation">,</span>
<span class="token punctuation">}</span></code></pre></div>
<p>Traditionally, if you wanted to create a new variable for each property, you would have to assign each variable individually, with a lot of repetition:</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="js"><pre class="language-js"><code class="language-js"><span class="token comment">// Create variables from the Object properties</span>
<span class="token keyword">const</span> id <span class="token operator">=</span> note<span class="token punctuation">.</span>id
<span class="token keyword">const</span> title <span class="token operator">=</span> note<span class="token punctuation">.</span>title
<span class="token keyword">const</span> date <span class="token operator">=</span> note<span class="token punctuation">.</span>date</code></pre></div>
<p>With object destructuring, this can all be done in one line. By surrounding each variable in curly brackets <code class="language-text">{}</code>, JavaScript will create new variables from each property with the same name:</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="js"><pre class="language-js"><code class="language-js"><span class="token comment">// Destructure properties into variables</span>
<span class="token keyword">const</span> <span class="token punctuation">{</span>id<span class="token punctuation">,</span> title<span class="token punctuation">,</span> date<span class="token punctuation">}</span> <span class="token operator">=</span> note</code></pre></div>
<p>Now, <a href="https://www.digitalocean.com/community/tutorials/how-to-use-the-javascript-developer-console#working-in-the-console"><code class="language-text">console.log()</code></a> the new variables:</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="js"><pre class="language-js"><code class="language-js">console<span class="token punctuation">.</span><span class="token function">log</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span>id<span class="token punctuation">)</span>
console<span class="token punctuation">.</span><span class="token function">log</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span>title<span class="token punctuation">)</span>
console<span class="token punctuation">.</span><span class="token function">log</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span>date<span class="token punctuation">)</span></code></pre></div>
<p>You will get the original property values as output:</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="terminal"><pre class="language-terminal"><code class="language-terminal">1
My first note
01/01/1970</code></pre></div>
<blockquote>
<p><strong>Note:</strong> Destructuring an object does not modify the original object. You could still call the original <code class="language-text">note</code> with all its entries intact.</p>
</blockquote>
<p>The default assignment for object destructuring creates new variables with the same name as the object property. If you do not want the new variable to have the same name as the property name, you also have the option of renaming the new variable by using a colon (<code class="language-text">:</code>) to decide a new name, as seen with <code class="language-text">noteId</code> in the following:</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="js"><pre class="language-js"><code class="language-js"><span class="token comment">// Assign a custom name to a destructured value</span>
<span class="token keyword">const</span> <span class="token punctuation">{</span>id<span class="token operator">:</span> noteId<span class="token punctuation">,</span> title<span class="token punctuation">,</span> date<span class="token punctuation">}</span> <span class="token operator">=</span> note</code></pre></div>
<p>Log the new variable <code class="language-text">noteId</code> to the console:</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="js"><pre class="language-js"><code class="language-js">console<span class="token punctuation">.</span><span class="token function">log</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span>noteId<span class="token punctuation">)</span></code></pre></div>
<p>You will receive the following output:</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="terminal"><pre class="language-terminal"><code class="language-terminal">1</code></pre></div>
<p>You can also destructure nested object values. For example, update the <code class="language-text">note</code> object to have a nested <code class="language-text">author</code> object:</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="js"><pre class="language-js"><code class="language-js"><span class="token keyword">const</span> note <span class="token operator">=</span> <span class="token punctuation">{</span>
  id<span class="token operator">:</span> <span class="token number">1</span><span class="token punctuation">,</span>
  title<span class="token operator">:</span> <span class="token string">'My first note'</span><span class="token punctuation">,</span>
  date<span class="token operator">:</span> <span class="token string">'01/01/1970'</span><span class="token punctuation">,</span>
  author<span class="token operator">:</span> <span class="token punctuation">{</span>
    firstName<span class="token operator">:</span> <span class="token string">'Sherlock'</span><span class="token punctuation">,</span>
    lastName<span class="token operator">:</span> <span class="token string">'Holmes'</span><span class="token punctuation">,</span>
  <span class="token punctuation">}</span><span class="token punctuation">,</span>
<span class="token punctuation">}</span></code></pre></div>
<p>Now you can destructure <code class="language-text">note</code>, then destructure once again to create variables from the <code class="language-text">author</code> properties:</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="js"><pre class="language-js"><code class="language-js"><span class="token comment">// Destructure nested properties</span>
<span class="token keyword">const</span> <span class="token punctuation">{</span>
  id<span class="token punctuation">,</span>
  title<span class="token punctuation">,</span>
  date<span class="token punctuation">,</span>
  author<span class="token operator">:</span> <span class="token punctuation">{</span>firstName<span class="token punctuation">,</span> lastName<span class="token punctuation">}</span><span class="token punctuation">,</span>
<span class="token punctuation">}</span> <span class="token operator">=</span> note</code></pre></div>
<p>Next, log the new variables <code class="language-text">firstName</code> and <code class="language-text">lastName</code> using <a href="https://www.digitalocean.com/community/tutorials/how-to-work-with-strings-in-javascript#string-concatenation">template literals</a>:</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="js"><pre class="language-js"><code class="language-js">console<span class="token punctuation">.</span><span class="token function">log</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token template-string"><span class="token template-punctuation string">`</span><span class="token interpolation"><span class="token interpolation-punctuation punctuation">${</span>firstName<span class="token interpolation-punctuation punctuation">}</span></span><span class="token string"> </span><span class="token interpolation"><span class="token interpolation-punctuation punctuation">${</span>lastName<span class="token interpolation-punctuation punctuation">}</span></span><span class="token template-punctuation string">`</span></span><span class="token punctuation">)</span></code></pre></div>
<p>This will give the following output:</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="terminal"><pre class="language-terminal"><code class="language-terminal">Sherlock Holmes</code></pre></div>
<p>Note that in this example, though you have access to the contents of the <code class="language-text">author</code> object, the <code class="language-text">author</code> object itself is not accessible. In order to access an object as well as its nested values, you would have to declare them separately:</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="js"><pre class="language-js"><code class="language-js"><span class="token comment">// Access object and nested values</span>
<span class="token keyword">const</span> <span class="token punctuation">{</span>
  author<span class="token punctuation">,</span>
  author<span class="token operator">:</span> <span class="token punctuation">{</span>firstName<span class="token punctuation">,</span> lastName<span class="token punctuation">}</span><span class="token punctuation">,</span>
<span class="token punctuation">}</span> <span class="token operator">=</span> note

console<span class="token punctuation">.</span><span class="token function">log</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span>author<span class="token punctuation">)</span></code></pre></div>
<p>This code will output the <code class="language-text">author</code> object:</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="terminal"><pre class="language-terminal"><code class="language-terminal">{firstName: &quot;Sherlock&quot;, lastName: &quot;Holmes&quot;}</code></pre></div>
<p>Because of this property, destructuring an object is not only useful for reducing the amount of code that you have to write; it also allows you to target your access to the properties you care about.</p>
<p>Finally, destructuring can be used to access the object properties of primitive values. For example, <a href="https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Global_Objects/String">String</a> is a global object for strings, and has a <code class="language-text">length</code> property:</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="js"><pre class="language-js"><code class="language-js"><span class="token keyword">const</span> <span class="token punctuation">{</span>length<span class="token punctuation">}</span> <span class="token operator">=</span> <span class="token string">'A string'</span></code></pre></div>
<p>This will find the inherent length property of a string and set it equal to the <code class="language-text">length</code> variable. Log <code class="language-text">length</code> to see if this worked:</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="js"><pre class="language-js"><code class="language-js">console<span class="token punctuation">.</span><span class="token function">log</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span>length<span class="token punctuation">)</span></code></pre></div>
<p>You will get the following output:</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="terminal"><pre class="language-terminal"><code class="language-terminal">8</code></pre></div>
<p>The string <code class="language-text">A string</code> was implicitly converted into an object here to retrieve the <code class="language-text">length</code> property.</p>
<h3 id="array-destructuring" style="position:relative;"><a href="#array-destructuring" aria-label="array destructuring permalink" class="anchor before"><svg aria-hidden="true" focusable="false" height="16" version="1.1" viewBox="0 0 16 16" width="16"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z"></path></svg></a>Array Destructuring</h3>
<p>Array destructuring allows you to create new variables using an array item as a value. Consider this example, an array with the various parts of a date:</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="js"><pre class="language-js"><code class="language-js"><span class="token keyword">const</span> date <span class="token operator">=</span> <span class="token punctuation">[</span><span class="token string">'1970'</span><span class="token punctuation">,</span> <span class="token string">'12'</span><span class="token punctuation">,</span> <span class="token string">'01'</span><span class="token punctuation">]</span></code></pre></div>
<p>Arrays in JavaScript are guaranteed to preserve their order, so in this case the first index will always be a year, the second will be the month, and so on. Knowing this, you can create variables from the items in the array:</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="js"><pre class="language-js"><code class="language-js"><span class="token comment">// Create variables from the Array items</span>
<span class="token keyword">const</span> year <span class="token operator">=</span> date<span class="token punctuation">[</span><span class="token number">0</span><span class="token punctuation">]</span>
<span class="token keyword">const</span> month <span class="token operator">=</span> date<span class="token punctuation">[</span><span class="token number">1</span><span class="token punctuation">]</span>
<span class="token keyword">const</span> day <span class="token operator">=</span> date<span class="token punctuation">[</span><span class="token number">2</span><span class="token punctuation">]</span></code></pre></div>
<p>But doing this manually can take up a lot of space in your code. With array destructuring, you can unpack the values from the array in order and assign them to their own variables, like so:</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="js"><pre class="language-js"><code class="language-js"><span class="token comment">// Destructure Array values into variables</span>
<span class="token keyword">const</span> <span class="token punctuation">[</span>year<span class="token punctuation">,</span> month<span class="token punctuation">,</span> day<span class="token punctuation">]</span> <span class="token operator">=</span> date</code></pre></div>
<p>Now log the new variables:</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="js"><pre class="language-js"><code class="language-js">console<span class="token punctuation">.</span><span class="token function">log</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span>year<span class="token punctuation">)</span>
console<span class="token punctuation">.</span><span class="token function">log</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span>month<span class="token punctuation">)</span>
console<span class="token punctuation">.</span><span class="token function">log</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span>day<span class="token punctuation">)</span></code></pre></div>
<p>You will get the following output:</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="terminal"><pre class="language-terminal"><code class="language-terminal">1970
12
01</code></pre></div>
<p>Values can be skipped by leaving the destructuring syntax blank between commas:</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="js"><pre class="language-js"><code class="language-js"><span class="token comment">// Skip the second item in the array</span>
<span class="token keyword">const</span> <span class="token punctuation">[</span>year<span class="token punctuation">,</span> <span class="token punctuation">,</span> day<span class="token punctuation">]</span> <span class="token operator">=</span> date

console<span class="token punctuation">.</span><span class="token function">log</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span>year<span class="token punctuation">)</span>
console<span class="token punctuation">.</span><span class="token function">log</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span>day<span class="token punctuation">)</span></code></pre></div>
<p>Running this will give the value of <code class="language-text">year</code> and <code class="language-text">day</code>:</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="terminal"><pre class="language-terminal"><code class="language-terminal">1970
01</code></pre></div>
<p>Nested arrays can also be destructured. First, create a nested array:</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="js"><pre class="language-js"><code class="language-js"><span class="token comment">// Create a nested array</span>
<span class="token keyword">const</span> nestedArray <span class="token operator">=</span> <span class="token punctuation">[</span><span class="token number">1</span><span class="token punctuation">,</span> <span class="token number">2</span><span class="token punctuation">,</span> <span class="token punctuation">[</span><span class="token number">3</span><span class="token punctuation">,</span> <span class="token number">4</span><span class="token punctuation">]</span><span class="token punctuation">,</span> <span class="token number">5</span><span class="token punctuation">]</span></code></pre></div>
<p>Then destructure that array and log the new variables:</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="js"><pre class="language-js"><code class="language-js"><span class="token comment">// Destructure nested items</span>
<span class="token keyword">const</span> <span class="token punctuation">[</span>one<span class="token punctuation">,</span> two<span class="token punctuation">,</span> <span class="token punctuation">[</span>three<span class="token punctuation">,</span> four<span class="token punctuation">]</span><span class="token punctuation">,</span> five<span class="token punctuation">]</span> <span class="token operator">=</span> nestedArray

console<span class="token punctuation">.</span><span class="token function">log</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span>one<span class="token punctuation">,</span> two<span class="token punctuation">,</span> three<span class="token punctuation">,</span> four<span class="token punctuation">,</span> five<span class="token punctuation">)</span></code></pre></div>
<p>You will receive the following output:</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="terminal"><pre class="language-terminal"><code class="language-terminal">1 2 3 4 5</code></pre></div>
<p>Destructuring syntax can be applied to destructure the parameters in a function. To test this out, you will destructure the <code class="language-text">keys</code> and <code class="language-text">values</code> out of <a href="https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Global_Objects/Object/entries"><code class="language-text">Object.entries()</code></a>.</p>
<p>First, declare the <code class="language-text">note</code> object:</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="js"><pre class="language-js"><code class="language-js"><span class="token keyword">const</span> note <span class="token operator">=</span> <span class="token punctuation">{</span>
  id<span class="token operator">:</span> <span class="token number">1</span><span class="token punctuation">,</span>
  title<span class="token operator">:</span> <span class="token string">'My first note'</span><span class="token punctuation">,</span>
  date<span class="token operator">:</span> <span class="token string">'01/01/1970'</span><span class="token punctuation">,</span>
<span class="token punctuation">}</span></code></pre></div>
<p>Given this object, you could list the key-value pairs by destructuring arguments as they are passed to the <a href="https://www.digitalocean.com/community/tutorials/how-to-use-array-methods-in-javascript-iteration-methods#foreach()"><code class="language-text">forEach()</code> method</a>:</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="js"><pre class="language-js"><code class="language-js"><span class="token comment">// Using forEach</span>
Object<span class="token punctuation">.</span><span class="token function">entries</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span>note<span class="token punctuation">)</span><span class="token punctuation">.</span><span class="token function">forEach</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token parameter"><span class="token punctuation">[</span>key<span class="token punctuation">,</span> value<span class="token punctuation">]</span></span><span class="token punctuation">)</span> <span class="token operator">=></span> <span class="token punctuation">{</span>
  console<span class="token punctuation">.</span><span class="token function">log</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token template-string"><span class="token template-punctuation string">`</span><span class="token interpolation"><span class="token interpolation-punctuation punctuation">${</span>key<span class="token interpolation-punctuation punctuation">}</span></span><span class="token string">: </span><span class="token interpolation"><span class="token interpolation-punctuation punctuation">${</span>value<span class="token interpolation-punctuation punctuation">}</span></span><span class="token template-punctuation string">`</span></span><span class="token punctuation">)</span>
<span class="token punctuation">}</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span></code></pre></div>
<p>Or you could accomplish the same thing using a <a href="https://www.digitalocean.com/community/tutorials/how-to-construct-for-loops-in-javascript"><code class="language-text">for</code> loop</a>:</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="js"><pre class="language-js"><code class="language-js"><span class="token comment">// Using a for loop</span>
<span class="token keyword">for</span> <span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token keyword">let</span> <span class="token punctuation">[</span>key<span class="token punctuation">,</span> value<span class="token punctuation">]</span> <span class="token keyword">of</span> Object<span class="token punctuation">.</span><span class="token function">entries</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span>note<span class="token punctuation">)</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span> <span class="token punctuation">{</span>
  console<span class="token punctuation">.</span><span class="token function">log</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token template-string"><span class="token template-punctuation string">`</span><span class="token interpolation"><span class="token interpolation-punctuation punctuation">${</span>key<span class="token interpolation-punctuation punctuation">}</span></span><span class="token string">: </span><span class="token interpolation"><span class="token interpolation-punctuation punctuation">${</span>value<span class="token interpolation-punctuation punctuation">}</span></span><span class="token template-punctuation string">`</span></span><span class="token punctuation">)</span>
<span class="token punctuation">}</span></code></pre></div>
<p>Either way, you will receive the following:</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="terminal"><pre class="language-terminal"><code class="language-terminal">id: 1
title: My first note
date: 01/01/1970</code></pre></div>
<p>Object destructuring and array destructuring can be combined in a single destructuring assignment. <a href="https://www.digitalocean.com/community/tutorials/understanding-default-parameters-in-javascript">Default parameters</a> can also be used with destructuring, as seen in this example that sets the default date to <a href="https://www.digitalocean.com/community/tutorials/understanding-date-and-time-in-javascript#the-date-object"><code class="language-text">new Date()</code></a>.</p>
<p>First, declare the <code class="language-text">note</code> object:</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="js"><pre class="language-js"><code class="language-js"><span class="token keyword">const</span> note <span class="token operator">=</span> <span class="token punctuation">{</span>
  title<span class="token operator">:</span> <span class="token string">'My first note'</span><span class="token punctuation">,</span>
  author<span class="token operator">:</span> <span class="token punctuation">{</span>
    firstName<span class="token operator">:</span> <span class="token string">'Sherlock'</span><span class="token punctuation">,</span>
    lastName<span class="token operator">:</span> <span class="token string">'Holmes'</span><span class="token punctuation">,</span>
  <span class="token punctuation">}</span><span class="token punctuation">,</span>
  tags<span class="token operator">:</span> <span class="token punctuation">[</span><span class="token string">'personal'</span><span class="token punctuation">,</span> <span class="token string">'writing'</span><span class="token punctuation">,</span> <span class="token string">'investigations'</span><span class="token punctuation">]</span><span class="token punctuation">,</span>
<span class="token punctuation">}</span></code></pre></div>
<p>Then destructure the object, while also setting a new <code class="language-text">date</code> variable with the default of <code class="language-text">new Date()</code>:</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="js"><pre class="language-js"><code class="language-js"><span class="token keyword">const</span> <span class="token punctuation">{</span>
  title<span class="token punctuation">,</span>
  date <span class="token operator">=</span> <span class="token keyword">new</span> <span class="token class-name">Date</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span><span class="token punctuation">,</span>
  author<span class="token operator">:</span> <span class="token punctuation">{</span>firstName<span class="token punctuation">}</span><span class="token punctuation">,</span>
  tags<span class="token operator">:</span> <span class="token punctuation">[</span>personalTag<span class="token punctuation">,</span> writingTag<span class="token punctuation">]</span><span class="token punctuation">,</span>
<span class="token punctuation">}</span> <span class="token operator">=</span> note

console<span class="token punctuation">.</span><span class="token function">log</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span>date<span class="token punctuation">)</span></code></pre></div>
<p><code class="language-text">console.log(date)</code> will then give output similar to the following:</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="terminal"><pre class="language-terminal"><code class="language-terminal">Fri May 08 2020 23:53:49 GMT-0500 (Central Daylight Time)</code></pre></div>
<p>As shown in this section, the destructuring assignment syntax adds a lot of flexibility to JavaScript and allows you to write more succinct code. In the next section, you will see how spread syntax can be used to expand data structures into their constituent data entries.</p>
<h2 id="spread" style="position:relative;"><a href="#spread" aria-label="spread permalink" class="anchor before"><svg aria-hidden="true" focusable="false" height="16" version="1.1" viewBox="0 0 16 16" width="16"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z"></path></svg></a>Spread</h2>
<p><em>Spread</em> syntax (<code class="language-text">...</code>) is another helpful addition to JavaScript for working with arrays, objects, and function calls. Spread allows objects and iterables (such as arrays) to be unpacked, or expanded, which can be used to make shallow copies of data structures to increase the ease of data manipulation.</p>
<h3 id="spread-with-arrays" style="position:relative;"><a href="#spread-with-arrays" aria-label="spread with arrays permalink" class="anchor before"><svg aria-hidden="true" focusable="false" height="16" version="1.1" viewBox="0 0 16 16" width="16"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z"></path></svg></a>Spread with Arrays</h3>
<p>Spread can simplify common tasks with arrays. For example, let's say you have two arrays and want to combine them:</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="js"><pre class="language-js"><code class="language-js"><span class="token comment">// Create an Array</span>
<span class="token keyword">const</span> tools <span class="token operator">=</span> <span class="token punctuation">[</span><span class="token string">'hammer'</span><span class="token punctuation">,</span> <span class="token string">'screwdriver'</span><span class="token punctuation">]</span>
<span class="token keyword">const</span> otherTools <span class="token operator">=</span> <span class="token punctuation">[</span><span class="token string">'wrench'</span><span class="token punctuation">,</span> <span class="token string">'saw'</span><span class="token punctuation">]</span></code></pre></div>
<p>Originally you would use <a href="https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Global_Objects/Array/concat"><code class="language-text">concat()</code></a> to concatenate the two arrays:</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="js"><pre class="language-js"><code class="language-js"><span class="token comment">// Concatenate tools and otherTools together</span>
<span class="token keyword">const</span> allTools <span class="token operator">=</span> tools<span class="token punctuation">.</span><span class="token function">concat</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span>otherTools<span class="token punctuation">)</span></code></pre></div>
<p>Now you can also use spread to unpack the arrays into a new array:</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="js"><pre class="language-js"><code class="language-js"><span class="token comment">// Unpack the tools Array into the allTools Array</span>
<span class="token keyword">const</span> allTools <span class="token operator">=</span> <span class="token punctuation">[</span><span class="token operator">...</span>tools<span class="token punctuation">,</span> <span class="token operator">...</span>otherTools<span class="token punctuation">]</span>

console<span class="token punctuation">.</span><span class="token function">log</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span>allTools<span class="token punctuation">)</span></code></pre></div>
<p>Running this would give the following:</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="terminal"><pre class="language-terminal"><code class="language-terminal">[&quot;hammer&quot;, &quot;screwdriver&quot;, &quot;wrench&quot;, &quot;saw&quot;]</code></pre></div>
<p>This can be particularly helpful with immutability. For example, you might be working with an app that has <code class="language-text">users</code> stored in an array of objects:</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="js"><pre class="language-js"><code class="language-js"><span class="token comment">// Array of users</span>
<span class="token keyword">const</span> users <span class="token operator">=</span> <span class="token punctuation">[</span>
  <span class="token punctuation">{</span>id<span class="token operator">:</span> <span class="token number">1</span><span class="token punctuation">,</span> name<span class="token operator">:</span> <span class="token string">'Ben'</span><span class="token punctuation">}</span><span class="token punctuation">,</span>
  <span class="token punctuation">{</span>id<span class="token operator">:</span> <span class="token number">2</span><span class="token punctuation">,</span> name<span class="token operator">:</span> <span class="token string">'Leslie'</span><span class="token punctuation">}</span><span class="token punctuation">,</span>
<span class="token punctuation">]</span></code></pre></div>
<p>You could use <code class="language-text">push</code> to modify the existing array and add a new user, which would be the mutable option:</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="js"><pre class="language-js"><code class="language-js"><span class="token comment">// A new user to be added</span>
<span class="token keyword">const</span> newUser <span class="token operator">=</span> <span class="token punctuation">{</span>id<span class="token operator">:</span> <span class="token number">3</span><span class="token punctuation">,</span> name<span class="token operator">:</span> <span class="token string">'Ron'</span><span class="token punctuation">}</span>

users<span class="token punctuation">.</span><span class="token function">push</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span>newUser<span class="token punctuation">)</span></code></pre></div>
<p>But this changes the <code class="language-text">user</code> array, which we might want to preserve.</p>
<p>Spread allows you to create a new array from the existing one and add a new item to the end:</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="js"><pre class="language-js"><code class="language-js"><span class="token keyword">const</span> updatedUsers <span class="token operator">=</span> <span class="token punctuation">[</span><span class="token operator">...</span>users<span class="token punctuation">,</span> newUser<span class="token punctuation">]</span>

console<span class="token punctuation">.</span><span class="token function">log</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span>users<span class="token punctuation">)</span>
console<span class="token punctuation">.</span><span class="token function">log</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span>updatedUsers<span class="token punctuation">)</span></code></pre></div>
<p>Now the new array, <code class="language-text">updatedUsers</code>, has the new user, but the original <code class="language-text">users</code> array remains unchanged:</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="terminal"><pre class="language-terminal"><code class="language-terminal">[{id: 1, name: &quot;Ben&quot;}
 {id: 2, name: &quot;Leslie&quot;}]

[{id: 1, name: &quot;Ben&quot;}
 {id: 2, name: &quot;Leslie&quot;}
 {id: 3, name: &quot;Ron&quot;}]</code></pre></div>
<p>Creating copies of data instead of changing existing data can help prevent unexpected changes. In JavaScript, when you create an object or array and assign it to another variable, you are not actually creating a new object—you are passing a reference.</p>
<p>Take this example, in which an array is created and assigned to another variable:</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="js"><pre class="language-js"><code class="language-js"><span class="token comment">// Create an Array</span>
<span class="token keyword">const</span> originalArray <span class="token operator">=</span> <span class="token punctuation">[</span><span class="token string">'one'</span><span class="token punctuation">,</span> <span class="token string">'two'</span><span class="token punctuation">,</span> <span class="token string">'three'</span><span class="token punctuation">]</span>

<span class="token comment">// Assign Array to another variable</span>
<span class="token keyword">const</span> secondArray <span class="token operator">=</span> originalArray</code></pre></div>
<p>Removing the last item of the second Array will modify the first one:</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="js"><pre class="language-js"><code class="language-js"><span class="token comment">// Remove the last item of the second Array</span>
secondArray<span class="token punctuation">.</span><span class="token function">pop</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span>

console<span class="token punctuation">.</span><span class="token function">log</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span>originalArray<span class="token punctuation">)</span></code></pre></div>
<p>This will give the output:</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="terminal"><pre class="language-terminal"><code class="language-terminal">[&quot;one&quot;, &quot;two&quot;]</code></pre></div>
<p>Spread allows you to make a shallow copy of an array or object, meaning that any top level properties will be cloned, but nested objects will still be passed by reference. For simple arrays or objects, a shallow copy may be all you need.</p>
<p>If you write the same example code, but copy the array with spread, and the original Array will no longer be modified:</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="js"><pre class="language-js"><code class="language-js"><span class="token comment">// Create an Array</span>
<span class="token keyword">const</span> originalArray <span class="token operator">=</span> <span class="token punctuation">[</span><span class="token string">'one'</span><span class="token punctuation">,</span> <span class="token string">'two'</span><span class="token punctuation">,</span> <span class="token string">'three'</span><span class="token punctuation">]</span>

<span class="token comment">// Use spread to make a shallow copy</span>
<span class="token keyword">const</span> secondArray <span class="token operator">=</span> <span class="token punctuation">[</span><span class="token operator">...</span>originalArray<span class="token punctuation">]</span>

<span class="token comment">// Remove the last item of the second Array</span>
secondArray<span class="token punctuation">.</span><span class="token function">pop</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span>

console<span class="token punctuation">.</span><span class="token function">log</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span>originalArray<span class="token punctuation">)</span></code></pre></div>
<p>The following will be logged to the console:</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="terminal"><pre class="language-terminal"><code class="language-terminal">[&quot;one&quot;, &quot;two&quot;, &quot;three&quot;]</code></pre></div>
<p>Spread can also be used to convert a <a href="https://www.digitalocean.com/community/tutorials/understanding-map-and-set-objects-in-javascript">set</a>, or any other <a href="https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Iteration_protocols#Iterable_examples">iterable</a> to an Array.</p>
<p>Create a new set and add some entries to it:</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="js"><pre class="language-js"><code class="language-js"><span class="token comment">// Create a set</span>
<span class="token keyword">const</span> set <span class="token operator">=</span> <span class="token keyword">new</span> <span class="token class-name">Set</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span>

set<span class="token punctuation">.</span><span class="token function">add</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token string">'octopus'</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span>
set<span class="token punctuation">.</span><span class="token function">add</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token string">'starfish'</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span>
set<span class="token punctuation">.</span><span class="token function">add</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token string">'whale'</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span></code></pre></div>
<p>Next, use the spread operator with <code class="language-text">set</code> and log the results:</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="js"><pre class="language-js"><code class="language-js"><span class="token comment">// Convert Set to Array</span>
<span class="token keyword">const</span> seaCreatures <span class="token operator">=</span> <span class="token punctuation">[</span><span class="token operator">...</span>set<span class="token punctuation">]</span>

console<span class="token punctuation">.</span><span class="token function">log</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span>seaCreatures<span class="token punctuation">)</span></code></pre></div>
<p>This will give the following:</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="terminal"><pre class="language-terminal"><code class="language-terminal">[&quot;octopus&quot;, &quot;starfish&quot;, &quot;whale&quot;]</code></pre></div>
<p>This can also be useful for creating an array from a string:</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="js"><pre class="language-js"><code class="language-js"><span class="token keyword">const</span> string <span class="token operator">=</span> <span class="token string">'hello'</span>

<span class="token keyword">const</span> stringArray <span class="token operator">=</span> <span class="token punctuation">[</span><span class="token operator">...</span>string<span class="token punctuation">]</span>

console<span class="token punctuation">.</span><span class="token function">log</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span>stringArray<span class="token punctuation">)</span></code></pre></div>
<p>This will give an array with each character as an item in the array:</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="terminal"><pre class="language-terminal"><code class="language-terminal">[&quot;h&quot;, &quot;e&quot;, &quot;l&quot;, &quot;l&quot;, &quot;o&quot;]</code></pre></div>
<h3 id="spread-with-objects" style="position:relative;"><a href="#spread-with-objects" aria-label="spread with objects permalink" class="anchor before"><svg aria-hidden="true" focusable="false" height="16" version="1.1" viewBox="0 0 16 16" width="16"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z"></path></svg></a>Spread with Objects</h3>
<p>When working with objects, spread can be used to copy and update objects.</p>
<p>Originally, <a href="https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Global_Objects/Object/assign"><code class="language-text">Object.assign()</code></a> was used to copy an object:</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="js"><pre class="language-js"><code class="language-js"><span class="token comment">// Create an Object and a copied Object with Object.assign()</span>
<span class="token keyword">const</span> originalObject <span class="token operator">=</span> <span class="token punctuation">{</span>enabled<span class="token operator">:</span> <span class="token boolean">true</span><span class="token punctuation">,</span> darkMode<span class="token operator">:</span> <span class="token boolean">false</span><span class="token punctuation">}</span>
<span class="token keyword">const</span> secondObject <span class="token operator">=</span> Object<span class="token punctuation">.</span><span class="token function">assign</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token punctuation">{</span><span class="token punctuation">}</span><span class="token punctuation">,</span> originalObject<span class="token punctuation">)</span></code></pre></div>
<p>The <code class="language-text">secondObject</code> will now be a clone of the <code class="language-text">originalObject</code>.</p>
<p>This is simplified with the spread syntax—you can shallow copy an object by spreading it into a new one:</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="js"><pre class="language-js"><code class="language-js"><span class="token comment">// Create an object and a copied object with spread</span>
<span class="token keyword">const</span> originalObject <span class="token operator">=</span> <span class="token punctuation">{</span>enabled<span class="token operator">:</span> <span class="token boolean">true</span><span class="token punctuation">,</span> darkMode<span class="token operator">:</span> <span class="token boolean">false</span><span class="token punctuation">}</span>
<span class="token keyword">const</span> secondObject <span class="token operator">=</span> <span class="token punctuation">{</span><span class="token operator">...</span>originalObject<span class="token punctuation">}</span>

console<span class="token punctuation">.</span><span class="token function">log</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span>secondObject<span class="token punctuation">)</span></code></pre></div>
<p>This will result in the following:</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="terminal"><pre class="language-terminal"><code class="language-terminal">{enabled: true, darkMode: false}</code></pre></div>
<p>Just like with arrays, this will only create a shallow copy, and nested objects will still be passed by reference.</p>
<p>Adding or modifying properties on an existing object in an immutable fashion is simplified with spread. In this example, the <code class="language-text">isLoggedIn</code> property is added to the <code class="language-text">user</code> object:</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="js"><pre class="language-js"><code class="language-js"><span class="token keyword">const</span> user <span class="token operator">=</span> <span class="token punctuation">{</span>
  id<span class="token operator">:</span> <span class="token number">3</span><span class="token punctuation">,</span>
  name<span class="token operator">:</span> <span class="token string">'Ron'</span><span class="token punctuation">,</span>
<span class="token punctuation">}</span>

<span class="token keyword">const</span> updatedUser <span class="token operator">=</span> <span class="token punctuation">{</span><span class="token operator">...</span>user<span class="token punctuation">,</span> isLoggedIn<span class="token operator">:</span> <span class="token boolean">true</span><span class="token punctuation">}</span>

console<span class="token punctuation">.</span><span class="token function">log</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span>updatedUser<span class="token punctuation">)</span></code></pre></div>
<p>This will output the following:</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="terminal"><pre class="language-terminal"><code class="language-terminal">{id: 3, name: &quot;Ron&quot;, isLoggedIn: true}</code></pre></div>
<p>One important thing to note with updating objects via spread is that any nested object will have to be spread as well. For example, let's say that in the <code class="language-text">user</code> object there is a nested <code class="language-text">organization</code> object:</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="js"><pre class="language-js"><code class="language-js"><span class="token keyword">const</span> user <span class="token operator">=</span> <span class="token punctuation">{</span>
  id<span class="token operator">:</span> <span class="token number">3</span><span class="token punctuation">,</span>
  name<span class="token operator">:</span> <span class="token string">'Ron'</span><span class="token punctuation">,</span>
  organization<span class="token operator">:</span> <span class="token punctuation">{</span>
    name<span class="token operator">:</span> <span class="token string">'Parks &amp; Recreation'</span><span class="token punctuation">,</span>
    city<span class="token operator">:</span> <span class="token string">'Pawnee'</span><span class="token punctuation">,</span>
  <span class="token punctuation">}</span><span class="token punctuation">,</span>
<span class="token punctuation">}</span></code></pre></div>
<p>If you tried to add a new item to <code class="language-text">organization</code>, it would overwrite the existing fields:</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="js"><pre class="language-js"><code class="language-js"><span class="token keyword">const</span> updatedUser <span class="token operator">=</span> <span class="token punctuation">{</span><span class="token operator">...</span>user<span class="token punctuation">,</span> organization<span class="token operator">:</span> <span class="token punctuation">{</span>position<span class="token operator">:</span> <span class="token string">'Director'</span><span class="token punctuation">}</span><span class="token punctuation">}</span>

console<span class="token punctuation">.</span><span class="token function">log</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span>updatedUser<span class="token punctuation">)</span></code></pre></div>
<p>This would result in the following:</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="terminal"><pre class="language-terminal"><code class="language-terminal">id: 3
name: &quot;Ron&quot;
organization: {position: &quot;Director&quot;}</code></pre></div>
<p>If mutability is not an issue, the field could be updated directly:</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="js"><pre class="language-js"><code class="language-js">user<span class="token punctuation">.</span>organization<span class="token punctuation">.</span>position <span class="token operator">=</span> <span class="token string">'Director'</span></code></pre></div>
<p>But since we are seeking an immutable solution, we can spread the inner object to retain the existing properties:</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="js"><pre class="language-js"><code class="language-js"><span class="token keyword">const</span> updatedUser <span class="token operator">=</span> <span class="token punctuation">{</span>
  <span class="token operator">...</span>user<span class="token punctuation">,</span>
  organization<span class="token operator">:</span> <span class="token punctuation">{</span>
    <span class="token operator">...</span>user<span class="token punctuation">.</span>organization<span class="token punctuation">,</span>
    position<span class="token operator">:</span> <span class="token string">'Director'</span><span class="token punctuation">,</span>
  <span class="token punctuation">}</span><span class="token punctuation">,</span>
<span class="token punctuation">}</span>

console<span class="token punctuation">.</span><span class="token function">log</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span>updatedUser<span class="token punctuation">)</span></code></pre></div>
<p>This will give the following:</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="terminal"><pre class="language-terminal"><code class="language-terminal">id: 3
name: &quot;Ron&quot;
organization: {name: &quot;Parks &amp; Recreation&quot;, city: &quot;Pawnee&quot;, position: &quot;Director&quot;}</code></pre></div>
<h3 id="spread-with-function-calls" style="position:relative;"><a href="#spread-with-function-calls" aria-label="spread with function calls permalink" class="anchor before"><svg aria-hidden="true" focusable="false" height="16" version="1.1" viewBox="0 0 16 16" width="16"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z"></path></svg></a>Spread with Function Calls</h3>
<p>Spread can also be used with arguments in function calls.</p>
<p>As an example, here is a <code class="language-text">multiply</code> function that takes three parameters and multiplies them:</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="js"><pre class="language-js"><code class="language-js"><span class="token comment">// Create a function to multiply three items</span>
<span class="token keyword">function</span> <span class="token function">multiply</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token parameter">a<span class="token punctuation">,</span> b<span class="token punctuation">,</span> c</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span> <span class="token punctuation">{</span>
  <span class="token keyword">return</span> a <span class="token operator">*</span> b <span class="token operator">*</span> c
<span class="token punctuation">}</span></code></pre></div>
<p>Normally, you would pass three values individually as arguments to the function call, like so:</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="js"><pre class="language-js"><code class="language-js"><span class="token function">multiply</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token number">1</span><span class="token punctuation">,</span> <span class="token number">2</span><span class="token punctuation">,</span> <span class="token number">3</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span></code></pre></div>
<p>This would give the following:</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="terminal"><pre class="language-terminal"><code class="language-terminal">6</code></pre></div>
<p>However, if all the values you want to pass to the function already exist in an array, the spread syntax allows you to use each item in an array as an argument:</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="js"><pre class="language-js"><code class="language-js"><span class="token keyword">const</span> numbers <span class="token operator">=</span> <span class="token punctuation">[</span><span class="token number">1</span><span class="token punctuation">,</span> <span class="token number">2</span><span class="token punctuation">,</span> <span class="token number">3</span><span class="token punctuation">]</span>

<span class="token function">multiply</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token operator">...</span>numbers<span class="token punctuation">)</span></code></pre></div>
<p>This will give the same result:</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="terminal"><pre class="language-terminal"><code class="language-terminal">6</code></pre></div>
<blockquote>
<p><strong>Note:</strong> Without spread, this can be accomplished by using <code class="language-text">apply()</code>:</p>
</blockquote>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="js"><pre class="language-js"><code class="language-js"><span class="token function">multiply</span><span class="token punctuation">.</span><span class="token function">apply</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token keyword">null</span><span class="token punctuation">,</span> <span class="token punctuation">[</span><span class="token number">1</span><span class="token punctuation">,</span> <span class="token number">2</span><span class="token punctuation">,</span> <span class="token number">3</span><span class="token punctuation">]</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span></code></pre></div>
<p>This will give:</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="terminal"><pre class="language-terminal"><code class="language-terminal">6</code></pre></div>
<p>Now that you have seen how spread can shorten your code, you can take a look at a different use of the <code class="language-text">...</code> syntax: rest parameters.</p>
<h2 id="rest-parameters" style="position:relative;"><a href="#rest-parameters" aria-label="rest parameters permalink" class="anchor before"><svg aria-hidden="true" focusable="false" height="16" version="1.1" viewBox="0 0 16 16" width="16"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z"></path></svg></a>Rest Parameters</h2>
<p>The last feature you will learn in this article is the <em>rest parameter</em> syntax. The syntax appears the same as spread (<code class="language-text">...</code>) but has the opposite effect. Instead of unpacking an array or object into individual values, the rest syntax will create an array of an indefinite number of arguments.</p>
<p>In the function <code class="language-text">restTest</code> for example, if we wanted <code class="language-text">args</code> to be an array composed of an indefinite number of arguments, we could have the following:</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="js"><pre class="language-js"><code class="language-js"><span class="token keyword">function</span> <span class="token function">restTest</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token parameter"><span class="token operator">...</span>args</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span> <span class="token punctuation">{</span>
  console<span class="token punctuation">.</span><span class="token function">log</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span>args<span class="token punctuation">)</span>
<span class="token punctuation">}</span>

<span class="token function">restTest</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token number">1</span><span class="token punctuation">,</span> <span class="token number">2</span><span class="token punctuation">,</span> <span class="token number">3</span><span class="token punctuation">,</span> <span class="token number">4</span><span class="token punctuation">,</span> <span class="token number">5</span><span class="token punctuation">,</span> <span class="token number">6</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span></code></pre></div>
<p>All the arguments passed to the <code class="language-text">restTest</code> function are now available in the <code class="language-text">args</code> array:</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="terminal"><pre class="language-terminal"><code class="language-terminal">[1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6]</code></pre></div>
<p>Rest syntax can be used as the only parameter or as the last parameter in the list. If used as the only parameter, it will gather all arguments, but if it's at the end of a list, it will gather every argument that is remaining, as seen in this example:</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="js"><pre class="language-js"><code class="language-js"><span class="token keyword">function</span> <span class="token function">restTest</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token parameter">one<span class="token punctuation">,</span> two<span class="token punctuation">,</span> <span class="token operator">...</span>args</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span> <span class="token punctuation">{</span>
  console<span class="token punctuation">.</span><span class="token function">log</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span>one<span class="token punctuation">)</span>
  console<span class="token punctuation">.</span><span class="token function">log</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span>two<span class="token punctuation">)</span>
  console<span class="token punctuation">.</span><span class="token function">log</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span>args<span class="token punctuation">)</span>
<span class="token punctuation">}</span>

<span class="token function">restTest</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token number">1</span><span class="token punctuation">,</span> <span class="token number">2</span><span class="token punctuation">,</span> <span class="token number">3</span><span class="token punctuation">,</span> <span class="token number">4</span><span class="token punctuation">,</span> <span class="token number">5</span><span class="token punctuation">,</span> <span class="token number">6</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span></code></pre></div>
<p>This will take the first two arguments individually, then group the rest into an array:</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="terminal"><pre class="language-terminal"><code class="language-terminal">1
2
[3, 4, 5, 6]</code></pre></div>
<p>In older code, the <code class="language-text">arguments</code> variable could be used to gather all the arguments passed through to a function:</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="js"><pre class="language-js"><code class="language-js"><span class="token keyword">function</span> <span class="token function">testArguments</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span> <span class="token punctuation">{</span>
  console<span class="token punctuation">.</span><span class="token function">log</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span>arguments<span class="token punctuation">)</span>
<span class="token punctuation">}</span>

<span class="token function">testArguments</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token string">'how'</span><span class="token punctuation">,</span> <span class="token string">'many'</span><span class="token punctuation">,</span> <span class="token string">'arguments'</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span></code></pre></div>
<p>This would give the following output:</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="terminal"><pre class="language-terminal"><code class="language-terminal">Arguments(3) [&quot;how&quot;, &quot;many&quot;, &quot;arguments&quot;]</code></pre></div>
<p>However, this has a few disadvantages. First, the <code class="language-text">arguments</code> variable cannot be used with arrow functions.</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="js"><pre class="language-js"><code class="language-js"><span class="token keyword">const</span> <span class="token function-variable function">testArguments</span> <span class="token operator">=</span> <span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span> <span class="token operator">=></span> <span class="token punctuation">{</span>
  console<span class="token punctuation">.</span><span class="token function">log</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span>arguments<span class="token punctuation">)</span>
<span class="token punctuation">}</span>

<span class="token function">testArguments</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token string">'how'</span><span class="token punctuation">,</span> <span class="token string">'many'</span><span class="token punctuation">,</span> <span class="token string">'arguments'</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span></code></pre></div>
<p>This would yield an error:</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="terminal"><pre class="language-terminal"><code class="language-terminal">Uncaught ReferenceError: arguments is not defined</code></pre></div>
<p>Additionally, <code class="language-text">arguments</code> is not a true array and cannot use methods like <a href="https://www.digitalocean.com/community/tutorials/how-to-use-array-methods-in-javascript-iteration-methods#map()"><code class="language-text">map</code> and <code class="language-text">filter</code></a> without first being converted to an array. It also will collect all arguments passed instead of just the rest of the arguments, as seen in the <code class="language-text">restTest(one, two, ...args)</code> example.</p>
<p>Rest can be used when destructuring arrays as well:</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="js"><pre class="language-js"><code class="language-js"><span class="token keyword">const</span> <span class="token punctuation">[</span>firstTool<span class="token punctuation">,</span> <span class="token operator">...</span>rest<span class="token punctuation">]</span> <span class="token operator">=</span> <span class="token punctuation">[</span><span class="token string">'hammer'</span><span class="token punctuation">,</span> <span class="token string">'screwdriver'</span><span class="token punctuation">,</span> <span class="token string">'wrench'</span><span class="token punctuation">]</span>

console<span class="token punctuation">.</span><span class="token function">log</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span>firstTool<span class="token punctuation">)</span>
console<span class="token punctuation">.</span><span class="token function">log</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span>rest<span class="token punctuation">)</span></code></pre></div>
<p>This will give:</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="terminal"><pre class="language-terminal"><code class="language-terminal">hammer
[&quot;screwdriver&quot;, &quot;wrench&quot;]</code></pre></div>
<p>Rest can also be used when destructuring objects:</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="js"><pre class="language-js"><code class="language-js"><span class="token keyword">const</span> <span class="token punctuation">{</span>isLoggedIn<span class="token punctuation">,</span> <span class="token operator">...</span>rest<span class="token punctuation">}</span> <span class="token operator">=</span> <span class="token punctuation">{</span>id<span class="token operator">:</span> <span class="token number">1</span><span class="token punctuation">,</span> name<span class="token operator">:</span> <span class="token string">'Ben'</span><span class="token punctuation">,</span> isLoggedIn<span class="token operator">:</span> <span class="token boolean">true</span><span class="token punctuation">}</span>

console<span class="token punctuation">.</span><span class="token function">log</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span>isLoggedIn<span class="token punctuation">)</span>
console<span class="token punctuation">.</span><span class="token function">log</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span>rest<span class="token punctuation">)</span></code></pre></div>
<p>Giving the following output:</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="terminal"><pre class="language-terminal"><code class="language-terminal">true
{id: 1, name: &quot;Ben&quot;}</code></pre></div>
<p>In this way, rest syntax provides efficient methods for gathering an indeterminate amount of items.</p>
<h2 id="conclusion" style="position:relative;"><a href="#conclusion" aria-label="conclusion permalink" class="anchor before"><svg aria-hidden="true" focusable="false" height="16" version="1.1" viewBox="0 0 16 16" width="16"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z"></path></svg></a>Conclusion</h2>
<p>In this article, you learned about destructuring, spread syntax, and rest parameters. In summary:</p>
<ul>
<li>Destructuring is used to create varibles from array items or object properties.</li>
<li>Spread syntax is used to unpack iterables such as arrays, objects, and function calls.</li>
<li>Rest parameter syntax will create an array from an indefinite number of values.</li>
</ul>
<p>Destructuring, rest parameters, and spread syntax are useful features in JavaScript that help keep your code succinct and clean.</p>
<p>If you would like to see destructuring in action, take a look at <a href="https://www.digitalocean.com/community/tutorials/how-to-customize-react-components-with-props#step-2-%E2%80%94-building-dynamic-components-with-props">How To Customize React Components with Props</a>, which uses this syntax to destructure data and pass it to custom front-end components. If you'd like to learn more about JavaScript, return to our <a href="https://www.digitalocean.com/community/tutorial_series/how-to-code-in-javascript">How To Code in JavaScript series page</a>.</p></content:encoded><author>hello@taniarascia.com</author></item><item><title><![CDATA[Writing an Emulator in JavaScript (Chip-8)]]></title><description><![CDATA[I spent a good portion of my childhood playing emulated NES and SNES games on my computer, but I never imagined I'd write an emulator myself…]]></description><link>https://www.taniarascia.com/writing-an-emulator-in-javascript-chip8/</link><guid isPermaLink="false">https://www.taniarascia.com/writing-an-emulator-in-javascript-chip8/</guid><pubDate>Mon, 13 Apr 2020 00:00:00 GMT</pubDate><content:encoded><p>I spent a good portion of my childhood playing emulated NES and SNES games on my computer, but I never imagined I'd write an emulator myself one day. However, <a href="https://sergeev.io/">Vanya Sergeev</a> challenged me to write a <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/CHIP-8">Chip-8</a> interpreter to learn some of the basic concepts of lower-level programming languages and how a CPU works, and the end result is a Chip-8 emulator in JavaScript that I wrote with his guidance.</p>
<p>Although there are endless implementations of the Chip-8 interpreter in every programming language imaginable, this one is a bit unique. My Chip8.js code interfaces with not just one but three environments, existing as a web app, a CLI app, and a native app.</p>
<p>You can take a look at the web app demo and the source here:</p>
<ul>
<li><a href="https://taniarascia.github.io/chip8/">Demo</a></li>
<li><a href="https://github.com/taniarascia/chip8">Source code</a></li>
</ul>
<p>There are plenty of guides on how to make a Chip-8 emulator, such as <a href="http://mattmik.com/files/chip8/mastering/chip8.html">Mastering Chip8</a>, <a href="http://www.multigesture.net/articles/how-to-write-an-emulator-Chip-8-interpreter/">How to Write an Emulator</a>, and most importantly, <a href="http://devernay.free.fr/hacks/chip8/C8TECH10.HTM">Cowgod's Chip-8 Technical Reference</a>, the primary resource used for my own emulator, and a website so old it ends in <code class="language-text">.HTM</code>. As such, this isn't intended to be a how-to guide, but an overview of how I built the emulator, what major concepts I learned, and some JavaScript specifics for making a browser, CLI, or native app.</p>

<h4 id="contents" style="position:relative;"><a href="#contents" aria-label="contents permalink" class="anchor before"><svg aria-hidden="true" focusable="false" height="16" version="1.1" viewBox="0 0 16 16" width="16"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z"></path></svg></a>Contents</h4>
