generator<span class="token punctuation">.</span><span class="token function">next</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token number">200</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span></code></pre></div>
<p>This will give the following output:</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="terminal"><pre class="language-terminal"><code class="language-terminal">100
200
{value: &quot;The end&quot;, done: true}</code></pre></div>
<p>It is also possible to seed the generator with an initial value. In the following example, we'll make a <code class="language-text">for</code> loop and pass each value into the <code class="language-text">next()</code> method, but pass an argument to the inital function as well:</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="js"><pre class="language-js"><code class="language-js"><span class="token keyword">function</span><span class="token operator">*</span> <span class="token function">generatorFunction</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token parameter">value</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span> <span class="token punctuation">{</span>
  <span class="token keyword">while</span> <span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token boolean">true</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span> <span class="token punctuation">{</span>
    value <span class="token operator">=</span> <span class="token keyword">yield</span> value <span class="token operator">*</span> <span class="token number">10</span>
  <span class="token punctuation">}</span>
<span class="token punctuation">}</span>

<span class="token comment">// Initiate a generator and seed it with an initial value</span>
<span class="token keyword">const</span> generator <span class="token operator">=</span> <span class="token function">generatorFunction</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token number">0</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span>

<span class="token keyword">for</span> <span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token keyword">let</span> i <span class="token operator">=</span> <span class="token number">0</span><span class="token punctuation">;</span> i <span class="token operator">&lt;</span> <span class="token number">5</span><span class="token punctuation">;</span> i<span class="token operator">++</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span> <span class="token punctuation">{</span>
  console<span class="token punctuation">.</span><span class="token function">log</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span>generator<span class="token punctuation">.</span><span class="token function">next</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span>i<span class="token punctuation">)</span><span class="token punctuation">.</span>value<span class="token punctuation">)</span>
<span class="token punctuation">}</span></code></pre></div>
<p>We'll retrieve the value from <code class="language-text">next()</code> and yield a new value to the next iteration, which is the previous value times ten. This will give the following:</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="terminal"><pre class="language-terminal"><code class="language-terminal">0
10
20
30
40</code></pre></div>
<p>Another way to deal with starting up a generator is to wrap the generator in a function that will always call <code class="language-text">next()</code> once before doing anything else.</p>
<h2 id="asyncawait-with-generators" style="position:relative;"><a href="#asyncawait-with-generators" aria-label="asyncawait with generators permalink" class="anchor before"><svg aria-hidden="true" focusable="false" height="16" version="1.1" viewBox="0 0 16 16" width="16"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z"></path></svg></a><code class="language-text">async</code>/<code class="language-text">await</code> with Generators</h2>
<p>An <a href="https://www.digitalocean.com/community/tutorials/how-to-write-asynchronous-code-in-node-js">asynchronous function</a> is a type of function available in ES6+ JavaScript that makes working with asynchronous data simpler and easier to understand by making it appear synchronous. Generators have a more extensive array of capabilities than asynchronous functions, but are capable of replicating similar behavior. Implementing asynchronous programming in this way can increase the flexibility of your code.</p>
<p>In this section, we will demonstrate an example of reproducing <a href="https://www.digitalocean.com/community/tutorials/how-to-write-asynchronous-code-in-node-js#writing-javascript-with-asyncawait"><code class="language-text">async</code>/<code class="language-text">await</code></a> with generators.</p>
<p>Let's build an asynchronous function that uses <a href="https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Fetch_API">the Fetch API</a> to get data from the <a href="https://jsonplaceholder.typicode.com/">JSONPlaceholder API</a> (which provides example <a href="https://www.digitalocean.com/community/tutorials/how-to-work-with-json-in-javascript">JSON</a> data for testing purposes) and logs the response to the console.</p>
<p>Start out by defining an asynchronous function called <code class="language-text">getUsers</code> that fetches data from the API and returns an array of objects, then call <code class="language-text">getUsers</code>:</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="js"><pre class="language-js"><code class="language-js"><span class="token keyword">const</span> <span class="token function-variable function">getUsers</span> <span class="token operator">=</span> <span class="token keyword">async</span> <span class="token keyword">function</span> <span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span> <span class="token punctuation">{</span>
  <span class="token keyword">const</span> response <span class="token operator">=</span> <span class="token keyword">await</span> <span class="token function">fetch</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token string">'https://jsonplaceholder.typicode.com/users'</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span>
  <span class="token keyword">const</span> json <span class="token operator">=</span> <span class="token keyword">await</span> response<span class="token punctuation">.</span><span class="token function">json</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span>

  <span class="token keyword">return</span> json
<span class="token punctuation">}</span>

<span class="token comment">// Call the getUsers function and log the response</span>
<span class="token function">getUsers</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span><span class="token punctuation">.</span><span class="token function">then</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token parameter">response</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span> <span class="token operator">=></span> console<span class="token punctuation">.</span><span class="token function">log</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span>response<span class="token punctuation">)</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span></code></pre></div>
<p>This will give the following JSON data:</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="terminal"><pre class="language-terminal"><code class="language-terminal">
[ {id: 1, name: &quot;Leanne Graham&quot; ...},
  {id: 2, name: &quot;Ervin Howell&quot; ...},
  {id: 3, name&quot;: &quot;Clementine Bauch&quot; ...},
  {id: 4, name: &quot;Patricia Lebsack&quot;...},
  {id: 5, name: &quot;Chelsey Dietrich&quot;...},
  {id: 6, name: &quot;Mrs. Dennis Schulist&quot;...},
  {id: 7, name: &quot;Kurtis Weissnat&quot;...},
  {id: 8, name: &quot;Nicholas Runolfsdottir V&quot;...},
  {id: 9, name: &quot;Glenna Reichert&quot;...},
  {id: 10, name: &quot;Clementina DuBuque&quot;...}]</code></pre></div>
<p>Using generators, we can create something almost identical that does not use the <code class="language-text">async</code>/<code class="language-text">await</code> keywords. Instead, it will use a new function we create, and <code class="language-text">yield</code> values instead of <code class="language-text">await</code> promises.</p>
<p>In the following code block, we define a function called <code class="language-text">getUsers</code> that uses our new <code class="language-text">asyncAlt</code> function (which we will write later on) to mimic <code class="language-text">async</code>/<code class="language-text">await</code>.</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="js"><pre class="language-js"><code class="language-js"><span class="token keyword">const</span> getUsers <span class="token operator">=</span> <span class="token function">asyncAlt</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token keyword">function</span><span class="token operator">*</span> <span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span> <span class="token punctuation">{</span>
  <span class="token keyword">const</span> response <span class="token operator">=</span> <span class="token keyword">yield</span> <span class="token function">fetch</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token string">'https://jsonplaceholder.typicode.com/users'</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span>
  <span class="token keyword">const</span> json <span class="token operator">=</span> <span class="token keyword">yield</span> response<span class="token punctuation">.</span><span class="token function">json</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span>

  <span class="token keyword">return</span> json
<span class="token punctuation">}</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span>

<span class="token comment">// Invoking the function</span>
<span class="token function">getUsers</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span><span class="token punctuation">.</span><span class="token function">then</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token parameter">response</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span> <span class="token operator">=></span> console<span class="token punctuation">.</span><span class="token function">log</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span>response<span class="token punctuation">)</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span></code></pre></div>
<p>As we can see, it looks almost identical to the <code class="language-text">async</code>/<code class="language-text">await</code> implementation, except that there is a generator function being passed in that yields values.</p>
<p>Now we can create an <code class="language-text">asyncAlt</code> function that resembles an asynchronous function. <code class="language-text">asyncAlt</code> has a generator function as a parameter, which is our function that yields the promises that <code class="language-text">fetch</code> returns. <code class="language-text">asyncAlt</code> returns a function itself, and resolves every promise it finds until the last one:</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="js"><pre class="language-js"><code class="language-js"><span class="token comment">// Define a function named asyncAlt that takes a generator function as an argument</span>
<span class="token keyword">function</span> <span class="token function">asyncAlt</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token parameter">generatorFunction</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span> <span class="token punctuation">{</span>
  <span class="token comment">// Return a function</span>
  <span class="token keyword">return</span> <span class="token keyword">function</span> <span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span> <span class="token punctuation">{</span>
    <span class="token comment">// Create and assign the generator object</span>
    <span class="token keyword">const</span> generator <span class="token operator">=</span> <span class="token function">generatorFunction</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span>

    <span class="token comment">// Define a function that accepts the next iteration of the generator</span>
    <span class="token keyword">function</span> <span class="token function">resolve</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token parameter">next</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span> <span class="token punctuation">{</span>
      <span class="token comment">// If the generator is closed and there are no more values to yield,</span>
      <span class="token comment">// resolve the last value</span>
      <span class="token keyword">if</span> <span class="token punctuation">(</span>next<span class="token punctuation">.</span>done<span class="token punctuation">)</span> <span class="token punctuation">{</span>
        <span class="token keyword">return</span> Promise<span class="token punctuation">.</span><span class="token function">resolve</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span>next<span class="token punctuation">.</span>value<span class="token punctuation">)</span>
      <span class="token punctuation">}</span>

      <span class="token comment">// If there are still values to yield, they are promises and</span>
      <span class="token comment">// must be resolved.</span>
      <span class="token keyword">return</span> Promise<span class="token punctuation">.</span><span class="token function">resolve</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span>next<span class="token punctuation">.</span>value<span class="token punctuation">)</span><span class="token punctuation">.</span><span class="token function">then</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token parameter">response</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span> <span class="token operator">=></span> <span class="token punctuation">{</span>
        <span class="token keyword">return</span> <span class="token function">resolve</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span>generator<span class="token punctuation">.</span><span class="token function">next</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span>response<span class="token punctuation">)</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span>
      <span class="token punctuation">}</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span>
    <span class="token punctuation">}</span>

    <span class="token comment">// Begin resolving promises</span>
    <span class="token keyword">return</span> <span class="token function">resolve</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span>generator<span class="token punctuation">.</span><span class="token function">next</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span>
  <span class="token punctuation">}</span>
<span class="token punctuation">}</span></code></pre></div>
<p>This will give the same output as the <code class="language-text">async</code>/<code class="language-text">await</code> version:</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="terminal"><pre class="language-terminal"><code class="language-terminal">[ {id: 1, name: &quot;Leanne Graham&quot; ...},
  {id: 2, name: &quot;Ervin Howell&quot; ...},
  {id: 3, name&quot;: &quot;Clementine Bauch&quot; ...},
  {id: 4, name: &quot;Patricia Lebsack&quot;...},
  {id: 5, name: &quot;Chelsey Dietrich&quot;...},
  {id: 6, name: &quot;Mrs. Dennis Schulist&quot;...},
  {id: 7, name: &quot;Kurtis Weissnat&quot;...},
  {id: 8, name: &quot;Nicholas Runolfsdottir V&quot;...},
  {id: 9, name: &quot;Glenna Reichert&quot;...},
  {id: 10, name: &quot;Clementina DuBuque&quot;...}]</code></pre></div>
<p>Note that this implementation is for demonstrating how generators can be used in place of <code class="language-text">async</code>/<code class="language-text">await</code>, and is not a production-ready design. It does not have error handling set up, nor does it have the ability to pass parameters into the yielded values. Though this method can add flexibility to your code, often <code class="language-text">async/await</code> will be a better choice, since it abstracts implementation details away and lets you focus on writing productive code.</p>
<h2 id="conclusion" style="position:relative;"><a href="#conclusion" aria-label="conclusion permalink" class="anchor before"><svg aria-hidden="true" focusable="false" height="16" version="1.1" viewBox="0 0 16 16" width="16"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z"></path></svg></a>Conclusion</h2>
<p>Generators are processes that can halt and resume execution. They are a powerful, versatile feature of JavaScript, although they are not commonly used. In this tutorial, we learned about generator functions and generator objects, methods available to generators, the <code class="language-text">yield</code> and <code class="language-text">yield*</code> operators, and using generators with finite and infinite data sets. We also explored one way to implement asynchronous code without nested callbacks or long promise chains.</p>
<p>If you would like to learn more about JavaScript syntax, take a look at our <a href="/this-bind-call-apply-javascript">Understanding This, Bind, Call, and Apply in JavaScript</a> and <a href="/understanding-map-and-set-javascript">Understanding Map and Set Objects in JavaScript</a> tutorials.</p></content:encoded><author>hello@taniarascia.com</author></item><item><title><![CDATA[macOS Monterey: Setting up a Mac for Development]]></title><description><![CDATA[Last Updated: 1/28/2022 I have to set up a MacBook Pro fairly often - when starting a new job and when buying a new personal computer. I…]]></description><link>https://www.taniarascia.com/setting-up-a-brand-new-mac-for-development/</link><guid isPermaLink="false">https://www.taniarascia.com/setting-up-a-brand-new-mac-for-development/</guid><pubDate>Mon, 17 Feb 2020 00:00:00 GMT</pubDate><content:encoded><p><em>Last Updated: 1/28/2022</em></p>
<p>I have to set up a MacBook Pro fairly often - when starting a new job and when buying a new personal computer. I created this article back in 2015 when I got my first Mac and have been updating it ever since with whatever I need as my job evolves. I'm primarily a full-stack web developer, so most of my needs will revolve around JavaScript/Node.js.</p>
<h2 id="getting-started" style="position:relative;"><a href="#getting-started" aria-label="getting started permalink" class="anchor before"><svg aria-hidden="true" focusable="false" height="16" version="1.1" viewBox="0 0 16 16" width="16"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z"></path></svg></a>Getting Started</h2>
<p>The setup assistant will launch once you turn the computer on. Enter your language, time zone, Apple ID, and so on. The first thing you should do is update macOS to get the latest security updates and patches.</p>
<ul>
<li><a href="#homebrew">Install apps via Homebrew</a></li>
<li><a href="#shell">Shell setup with zsh</a></li>
<li><a href="#nodejs">Set up Node via nvm</a></li>
<li><a href="#git">Set up git config</a></li>
<li><a href="#ssh">Set up SSH keys and config</a></li>
<li><a href="#macos-settings">macOS settings</a></li>
<li><a href="#application-settings">Application settings</a></li>
</ul>
<h2 id="homebrew" style="position:relative;"><a href="#homebrew" aria-label="homebrew permalink" class="anchor before"><svg aria-hidden="true" focusable="false" height="16" version="1.1" viewBox="0 0 16 16" width="16"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z"></path></svg></a>Homebrew</h2>
<p>Install the <a href="https://brew.sh/">Homebrew</a> package manager. This will allow you to install almost any app from the command line.</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="shell"><pre class="language-shell"><code class="language-shell"><span class="command-line-prompt"><span data-user=root data-host=localhost></span></span>/bin/bash -c <span class="token string">"<span class="token variable"><span class="token variable">$(</span><span class="token function">curl</span> -fsSL https://raw.githubusercontent.com/Homebrew/install/master/install.sh<span class="token variable">)</span></span>"</span></code></pre></div>
<p>Make sure everything is up to date.</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="shell"><pre class="language-shell"><code class="language-shell"><span class="command-line-prompt"><span data-user=root data-host=localhost></span></span>brew update</code></pre></div>
<blockquote>
<p>Note: On the M1 install, there will be a few errors at the end, you'll have to run the commands to add to path, then run <code class="language-text">brew doctor</code> and run the commands listed.</p>
</blockquote>

  todoist <span class="token punctuation">\</span></code></pre></div>
<h2 id="shell" style="position:relative;"><a href="#shell" aria-label="shell permalink" class="anchor before"><svg aria-hidden="true" focusable="false" height="16" version="1.1" viewBox="0 0 16 16" width="16"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z"></path></svg></a>Shell</h2>
<p>Catalina comes with <a href="http://zsh.sourceforge.net/">zsh</a> as the default shell. Install <a href="https://ohmyz.sh/">Oh My Zsh</a> for sensible defaults.</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="shell"><pre class="language-shell"><code class="language-shell"><span class="command-line-prompt"><span data-user=root data-host=localhost></span></span><span class="token function">sh</span> -c <span class="token string">"<span class="token variable"><span class="token variable">$(</span><span class="token function">curl</span> -fsSL https://raw.github.com/ohmyzsh/ohmyzsh/master/tools/install.sh<span class="token variable">)</span></span>"</span></code></pre></div>
<p>I add a few alises.</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="bash"><pre class="language-bash"><code class="language-bash"><span class="command-line-prompt"><span data-user=root data-host=localhost></span><span data-user=root data-host=localhost></span></span><span class="token builtin class-name">alias</span> <span class="token assign-left variable">cat</span><span class="token operator">=</span><span class="token string">"bat"</span>
<span class="token builtin class-name">alias</span> <span class="token assign-left variable">ls</span><span class="token operator">=</span><span class="token string">"exa"</span></code></pre></div>
<h2 id="nodejs" style="position:relative;"><a href="#nodejs" aria-label="nodejs permalink" class="anchor before"><svg aria-hidden="true" focusable="false" height="16" version="1.1" viewBox="0 0 16 16" width="16"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z"></path></svg></a>Node.js</h2>
<p>Use <a href="https://github.com/nvm-sh/nvm/blob/master/README.md">Node Version Manager (nvm)</a> to install Node.js. This allows you to easily switch between Node versions, which is essential.</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="shell"><pre class="language-shell"><code class="language-shell"><span class="command-line-prompt"><span data-user=root data-host=localhost></span></span><span class="token function">curl</span> -o- https://raw.githubusercontent.com/nvm-sh/nvm/v0.39.1/install.sh <span class="token operator">|</span> <span class="token function">bash</span></code></pre></div>
<h3 id="install" style="position:relative;"><a href="#install" aria-label="install permalink" class="anchor before"><svg aria-hidden="true" focusable="false" height="16" version="1.1" viewBox="0 0 16 16" width="16"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z"></path></svg></a>Install</h3>
<p>Install the latest version.</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="shell"><pre class="language-shell"><code class="language-shell"><span class="command-line-prompt"><span data-user=root data-host=localhost></span></span>nvm <span class="token function">install</span> node</code></pre></div>
<p>Restart terminal and run the final command.</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="shell"><pre class="language-shell"><code class="language-shell"><span class="command-line-prompt"><span data-user=root data-host=localhost></span></span>nvm use node</code></pre></div>
<p>Confirm that you are using the latest version of Node and npm.</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="shell"><pre class="language-shell"><code class="language-shell"><span class="command-line-prompt"><span data-user=root data-host=localhost></span></span>node -v <span class="token operator">&amp;&amp;</span> <span class="token function">npm</span> -v</code></pre></div>
<h3 id="update" style="position:relative;"><a href="#update" aria-label="update permalink" class="anchor before"><svg aria-hidden="true" focusable="false" height="16" version="1.1" viewBox="0 0 16 16" width="16"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z"></path></svg></a>Update</h3>
<p>For later, here's how to update nvm.</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="shell"><pre class="language-shell"><code class="language-shell"><span class="command-line-prompt"><span data-user=root data-host=localhost></span></span>nvm <span class="token function">install</span> node --reinstall-packages-from<span class="token operator">=</span>node</code></pre></div>
<h3 id="change-version" style="position:relative;"><a href="#change-version" aria-label="change version permalink" class="anchor before"><svg aria-hidden="true" focusable="false" height="16" version="1.1" viewBox="0 0 16 16" width="16"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z"></path></svg></a>Change version</h3>
<p>Here's how to switch to another version and use it.</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="shell"><pre class="language-shell"><code class="language-shell"><span class="command-line-prompt"><span data-user=root data-host=localhost></span></span>nvm <span class="token function">install</span> xx.xx</code></pre></div>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="shell"><pre class="language-shell"><code class="language-shell"><span class="command-line-prompt"><span data-user=root data-host=localhost></span></span>nvm use xx.xx</code></pre></div>
<p>And to set the default:</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="shell"><pre class="language-shell"><code class="language-shell"><span class="command-line-prompt"><span data-user=root data-host=localhost></span></span>nvm <span class="token builtin class-name">alias</span> default xx.xx</code></pre></div>
<h2 id="git" style="position:relative;"><a href="#git" aria-label="git permalink" class="anchor before"><svg aria-hidden="true" focusable="false" height="16" version="1.1" viewBox="0 0 16 16" width="16"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z"></path></svg></a>Git</h2>
<p>The first thing you should do with Git is <a href="https://git-scm.com/book/en/v2/Getting-Started-First-Time-Git-Setup">set your global configuration</a>.</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="shell"><pre class="language-shell"><code class="language-shell"><span class="command-line-prompt"><span data-user=root data-host=localhost></span></span><span class="token function">touch</span> ~/.gitconfig</code></pre></div>
<p>Input your config and create some aliases.</p>
<div class="filename">.gitconfig</div>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="bash"><pre class="language-bash"><code class="language-bash"><span class="command-line-prompt"><span data-user=root data-host=localhost></span><span data-user=root data-host=localhost></span><span data-user=root data-host=localhost></span><span data-user=root data-host=localhost></span><span data-user=root data-host=localhost></span><span data-user=root data-host=localhost></span><span data-user=root data-host=localhost></span><span data-user=root data-host=localhost></span><span data-user=root data-host=localhost></span><span data-user=root data-host=localhost></span><span data-user=root data-host=localhost></span><span data-user=root data-host=localhost></span><span data-user=root data-host=localhost></span><span data-user=root data-host=localhost></span><span data-user=root data-host=localhost></span><span data-user=root data-host=localhost></span><span data-user=root data-host=localhost></span><span data-user=root data-host=localhost></span><span data-user=root data-host=localhost></span><span data-user=root data-host=localhost></span><span data-user=root data-host=localhost></span></span><span class="token punctuation">[</span>user<span class="token punctuation">]</span>
  name   <span class="token operator">=</span> Firstname Lastname
  email  <span class="token operator">=</span> you@example.com
<span class="token punctuation">[</span>github<span class="token punctuation">]</span>
  user   <span class="token operator">=</span> username
<span class="token punctuation">[</span>alias<span class="token punctuation">]</span>
  a      <span class="token operator">=</span> <span class="token function">add</span>
  ca     <span class="token operator">=</span> commit -a
  cam    <span class="token operator">=</span> commit -am
  cm     <span class="token operator">=</span> commit -m
  s      <span class="token operator">=</span> status
  p      <span class="token operator">=</span> push
  pom    <span class="token operator">=</span> push origin master
  puom   <span class="token operator">=</span> pull origin master
  cob    <span class="token operator">=</span> checkout -b
  co     <span class="token operator">=</span> checkout
  fp     <span class="token operator">=</span> fetch --prune --all
  l      <span class="token operator">=</span> log --oneline --decorate --graph
  lall   <span class="token operator">=</span> log --oneline --decorate --graph --all
  <span class="token function">ls</span>     <span class="token operator">=</span> log --oneline --decorate --graph --stat
  lt     <span class="token operator">=</span> log --graph --decorate --pretty<span class="token operator">=</span>format:<span class="token string">'%C(yellow)%h%Creset%C(auto)%d%Creset %s %Cgreen(%cr) %C(bold blue)%an%Creset'</span></code></pre></div>
<p>With the above aliases, I can run <code class="language-text">git s</code> instead of <code class="language-text">git status</code>, for example. The less I have to type, the happier I am.</p>
<h2 id="ssh" style="position:relative;"><a href="#ssh" aria-label="ssh permalink" class="anchor before"><svg aria-hidden="true" focusable="false" height="16" version="1.1" viewBox="0 0 16 16" width="16"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z"></path></svg></a>SSH</h2>
<h3 id="generate-ssh-key" style="position:relative;"><a href="#generate-ssh-key" aria-label="generate ssh key permalink" class="anchor before"><svg aria-hidden="true" focusable="false" height="16" version="1.1" viewBox="0 0 16 16" width="16"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z"></path></svg></a>Generate SSH key</h3>
<p>You can <a href="https://help.github.com/articles/generating-a-new-ssh-key-and-adding-it-to-the-ssh-agent/">generate an SSH key</a> to distribute.</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="shell"><pre class="language-shell"><code class="language-shell"><span class="command-line-prompt"><span data-user=root data-host=localhost></span></span>ssh-keygen -t ed25519 -C <span class="token string">"your_email@example.com"</span></code></pre></div>
<p>Start ssh-agent.</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="text"><pre class="language-text"><code class="language-text">eval "$(ssh-agent -s)"</code></pre></div>
<p>Add key.</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="shell"><pre class="language-shell"><code class="language-shell"><span class="command-line-prompt"><span data-user=root data-host=localhost></span></span>ssh-add -K ~/.ssh/id_rsa</code></pre></div>
<h3 id="config" style="position:relative;"><a href="#config" aria-label="config permalink" class="anchor before"><svg aria-hidden="true" focusable="false" height="16" version="1.1" viewBox="0 0 16 16" width="16"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z"></path></svg></a>Config</h3>
<p>Simplify the process of SSHing into other boxes with your SSH config file. Create <code class="language-text">~/.ssh/config</code> if it does not already exist.</p>
<p>Add the following contents, changing the variables for any hosts that you connect to. Using the below will be the same as running <code class="language-text">ssh -i ~/.ssh/key.pem user@example.com</code>.</p>
<div class="filename">~/.ssh/config</div>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="bash"><pre class="language-bash"><code class="language-bash"><span class="command-line-prompt"><span data-user=root data-host=localhost></span><span data-user=root data-host=localhost></span><span data-user=root data-host=localhost></span><span data-user=root data-host=localhost></span><span data-user=root data-host=localhost></span><span data-user=root data-host=localhost></span><span data-user=root data-host=localhost></span><span data-user=root data-host=localhost></span><span data-user=root data-host=localhost></span></span>Host *
  AddKeysToAgent <span class="token function">yes</span>
  UseKeychain <span class="token function">yes</span>
  IdentityFile ~/.ssh/id_ed25519

Host myssh
  HostName example.com
  User user
  IdentityFile ~/.ssh/key.pem</code></pre></div>
<p>Now just run the alias to connect.</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="shell"><pre class="language-shell"><code class="language-shell"><span class="command-line-prompt"><span data-user=root data-host=localhost></span></span><span class="token function">ssh</span> myssh</code></pre></div>
<h2 id="macos-settings" style="position:relative;"><a href="#macos-settings" aria-label="macos settings permalink" class="anchor before"><svg aria-hidden="true" focusable="false" height="16" version="1.1" viewBox="0 0 16 16" width="16"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z"></path></svg></a>macOS Settings</h2>

<h3 id="security-and-privacy" style="position:relative;"><a href="#security-and-privacy" aria-label="security and privacy permalink" class="anchor before"><svg aria-hidden="true" focusable="false" height="16" version="1.1" viewBox="0 0 16 16" width="16"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z"></path></svg></a>Security and Privacy</h3>
<ul>
<li>Allow apps downloaded from App Store and identified developers</li>

In JavaScript, developers often spend a lot of time deciding the correct data…]]></description><link>https://www.taniarascia.com/understanding-map-and-set-javascript/</link><guid isPermaLink="false">https://www.taniarascia.com/understanding-map-and-set-javascript/</guid><pubDate>Wed, 12 Feb 2020 00:00:00 GMT</pubDate><content:encoded><p><em>This article was originally written for <a href="https://www.digitalocean.com/community/tutorials/understanding-map-and-set-objects-in-javascript">DigitalOcean</a>.</em></p>
<p>In JavaScript, developers often spend a lot of time deciding the correct data structure to use. This is because choosing the correct data structure can make it easier to manipulate that data later on, saving time and making code easier to comprehend. The two predominant data structures for storing collections of data are <a href="/understanding-objects-in-javascript">Objects</a> and <a href="/understanding-arrays-in-javascript">Arrays</a> (a type of object). Developers use Objects to store key/value pairs and Arrays to store indexed lists. However, to give developers more flexibility, the ECMAScript 2015 specification introduced two new types of iterable objects: Maps, which are ordered collections of key/value pairs, and Sets, which are collections of unique values.</p>
<p>In this article, you will go over the Map and Set objects, what makes them similar or different to Objects and Arrays, the properties and methods available to them, and examples of some practical uses.</p>
<h2 id="maps" style="position:relative;"><a href="#maps" aria-label="maps permalink" class="anchor before"><svg aria-hidden="true" focusable="false" height="16" version="1.1" viewBox="0 0 16 16" width="16"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z"></path></svg></a>Maps</h2>
<p>A Map is a collection of key/value pairs that can use any <a href="https://www.digitalocean.com/community/tutorials/understanding-data-types-in-javascript">data type</a> as a key and can maintain the order of its entries. Maps have elements of both Objects (a unique key/value pair collection) and Arrays (an ordered collection), but are more similar to Objects conceptually. This is because, although the size and order of entries is preserved like an Array, the entries themselves are key/value pairs like Objects.</p>
<p>Maps can be initialized with the <code class="language-text">new Map()</code> syntax:</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="js"><pre class="language-js"><code class="language-js"><span class="token keyword">const</span> map <span class="token operator">=</span> <span class="token keyword">new</span> <span class="token class-name">Map</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span></code></pre></div>
<p>This gives us an empty Map:</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="terminal"><pre class="language-terminal"><code class="language-terminal">Map(0) {}</code></pre></div>
<h3 id="adding-values-to-a-map" style="position:relative;"><a href="#adding-values-to-a-map" aria-label="adding values to a map permalink" class="anchor before"><svg aria-hidden="true" focusable="false" height="16" version="1.1" viewBox="0 0 16 16" width="16"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z"></path></svg></a>Adding Values to a Map</h3>
<p>You can add values to a map with the <code class="language-text">set()</code> method. The first argument will be the key, and the second argument will be the value.</p>
<p>The following adds three key/value pairs to <code class="language-text">map</code>:</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="js"><pre class="language-js"><code class="language-js">map<span class="token punctuation">.</span><span class="token function">set</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token string">'firstName'</span><span class="token punctuation">,</span> <span class="token string">'Luke'</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span>
map<span class="token punctuation">.</span><span class="token function">set</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token string">'lastName'</span><span class="token punctuation">,</span> <span class="token string">'Skywalker'</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span>
map<span class="token punctuation">.</span><span class="token function">set</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token string">'occupation'</span><span class="token punctuation">,</span> <span class="token string">'Jedi Knight'</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span></code></pre></div>
<p>Here we begin to see how Maps have elements of both Objects and Arrays. Like an Array, we have a zero-indexed collection, and we can also see how many items are in the Map by default. Maps use the <code class="language-text">=></code> syntax to signify key/value pairs as <code class="language-text">key => value</code>:</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="terminal"><pre class="language-terminal"><code class="language-terminal">Map(3)
0: {&quot;firstName&quot; =&gt; &quot;Luke&quot;}
1: {&quot;lastName&quot; =&gt; &quot;Skywalker&quot;}
2: {&quot;occupation&quot; =&gt; &quot;Jedi Knight&quot;}</code></pre></div>
<p>This example looks similar to a regular object with string-based keys, but we can use any data type as a key with Map.</p>
<p>In addition to manually setting values on a Map, we can also initialize a Map with values already. We do this using an Array of Arrays containing two elements that are each key/value pairs, which looks like this:</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="terminal"><pre class="language-terminal"><code class="language-terminal">[ [&#39;key1&#39;, &#39;value1&#39;],
  [&#39;key2&#39;, &#39;value2&#39;] ]</code></pre></div>
<p>Using the following syntax, we can recreate the same Map:</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="js"><pre class="language-js"><code class="language-js"><span class="token keyword">const</span> map <span class="token operator">=</span> <span class="token keyword">new</span> <span class="token class-name">Map</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token punctuation">[</span>
  <span class="token punctuation">[</span><span class="token string">'firstName'</span><span class="token punctuation">,</span> <span class="token string">'Luke'</span><span class="token punctuation">]</span><span class="token punctuation">,</span>
  <span class="token punctuation">[</span><span class="token string">'lastName'</span><span class="token punctuation">,</span> <span class="token string">'Skywalker'</span><span class="token punctuation">]</span><span class="token punctuation">,</span>
  <span class="token punctuation">[</span><span class="token string">'occupation'</span><span class="token punctuation">,</span> <span class="token string">'Jedi Knight'</span><span class="token punctuation">]</span><span class="token punctuation">,</span>
<span class="token punctuation">]</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span></code></pre></div>
<p>Incidentally, this syntax is the same as the result of calling <a href="/how-to-use-object-methods-in-javascript"><code class="language-text">Object.entries()</code></a> on an Object. This provides a ready-made way to convert an Object to a Map, as shown in the following code block:</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="js"><pre class="language-js"><code class="language-js"><span class="token keyword">const</span> luke <span class="token operator">=</span> <span class="token punctuation">{</span>
  firstName<span class="token operator">:</span> <span class="token string">'Luke'</span><span class="token punctuation">,</span>
  lastName<span class="token operator">:</span> <span class="token string">'Skywalker'</span><span class="token punctuation">,</span>
  occupation<span class="token operator">:</span> <span class="token string">'Jedi Knight'</span><span class="token punctuation">,</span>
<span class="token punctuation">}</span>

<span class="token keyword">const</span> map <span class="token operator">=</span> <span class="token keyword">new</span> <span class="token class-name">Map</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span>Object<span class="token punctuation">.</span><span class="token function">entries</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span>luke<span class="token punctuation">)</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span></code></pre></div>
<p>Alternatively, you can turn a Map back into an Object or an Array with a single line of code.</p>
<p>The following converts a Map to an Object:</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="js"><pre class="language-js"><code class="language-js"><span class="token keyword">const</span> obj <span class="token operator">=</span> Object<span class="token punctuation">.</span><span class="token function">fromEntries</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span>map<span class="token punctuation">)</span></code></pre></div>
<p>This will result in the following value of <code class="language-text">obj</code>:</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="terminal"><pre class="language-terminal"><code class="language-terminal">{firstName: &quot;Luke&quot;, lastName: &quot;Skywalker&quot;, occupation: &quot;Jedi Knight&quot;}</code></pre></div>
<p>Now, let's convert a Map to an Array:</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="js"><pre class="language-js"><code class="language-js"><span class="token keyword">const</span> arr <span class="token operator">=</span> Array<span class="token punctuation">.</span><span class="token function">from</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span>map<span class="token punctuation">)</span></code></pre></div>
<p>This will result in the following Array for <code class="language-text">arr</code>:</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="terminal"><pre class="language-terminal"><code class="language-terminal">[ [&#39;firstName&#39;, &#39;Luke&#39;],
  [&#39;lastName&#39;, &#39;Skywalker&#39;],
  [&#39;occupation&#39;, &#39;Jedi Knight&#39;] ]</code></pre></div>
<h3 id="map-keys" style="position:relative;"><a href="#map-keys" aria-label="map keys permalink" class="anchor before"><svg aria-hidden="true" focusable="false" height="16" version="1.1" viewBox="0 0 16 16" width="16"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z"></path></svg></a>Map Keys</h3>
<p>Maps accept any data type as a key, and do not allow duplicate key values. We can demonstrate this by creating a map and using non-string values as keys, as well as setting two values to the same key.</p>
<p>First, let's initialize a map with non-string keys:</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="js"><pre class="language-js"><code class="language-js"><span class="token keyword">const</span> map <span class="token operator">=</span> <span class="token keyword">new</span> <span class="token class-name">Map</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span>

map<span class="token punctuation">.</span><span class="token function">set</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token string">'1'</span><span class="token punctuation">,</span> <span class="token string">'String one'</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span>
map<span class="token punctuation">.</span><span class="token function">set</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token number">1</span><span class="token punctuation">,</span> <span class="token string">'This will be overwritten'</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span>
map<span class="token punctuation">.</span><span class="token function">set</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token number">1</span><span class="token punctuation">,</span> <span class="token string">'Number one'</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span>
map<span class="token punctuation">.</span><span class="token function">set</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token boolean">true</span><span class="token punctuation">,</span> <span class="token string">'A Boolean'</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span></code></pre></div>
<p>This example will override the first key of <code class="language-text">1</code> with the subsequent one, and it will treat <code class="language-text">'1'</code> the string and <code class="language-text">1</code> the number as unique keys:</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="terminal"><pre class="language-terminal"><code class="language-terminal">0: {&quot;1&quot; =&gt; &quot;String one&quot;}
1: {1 =&gt; &quot;Number one&quot;}
2: {true =&gt; &quot;A Boolean&quot;}</code></pre></div>
<p>Although it is a common belief that a regular JavaScript Object can already handle Numbers, booleans, and other primitive data types as keys, this is actually not the case, because Objects change all keys to strings.</p>
<p>As an example, initialize an object with a numerical key and compare the value for a numerical <code class="language-text">1</code> key and a stringified <code class="language-text">"1"</code> key:</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="js"><pre class="language-js"><code class="language-js"><span class="token comment">// Initialize an object with a numerical key</span>
<span class="token keyword">const</span> obj <span class="token operator">=</span> <span class="token punctuation">{</span> <span class="token number">1</span><span class="token operator">:</span> <span class="token string">'One'</span> <span class="token punctuation">}</span>

<span class="token comment">// The key is actually a string</span>
obj<span class="token punctuation">[</span><span class="token number">1</span><span class="token punctuation">]</span> <span class="token operator">===</span> obj<span class="token punctuation">[</span><span class="token string">'1'</span><span class="token punctuation">]</span> <span class="token comment">// true</span></code></pre></div>
<p>This is why if you attempt to use an Object as a key, it will print out the string <code class="language-text">object Object</code> instead.</p>
<p>As an example, create an Object and then use it as the key of another Object:</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="js"><pre class="language-js"><code class="language-js"><span class="token comment">// Create an object</span>
<span class="token keyword">const</span> objAsKey <span class="token operator">=</span> <span class="token punctuation">{</span> foo<span class="token operator">:</span> <span class="token string">'bar'</span> <span class="token punctuation">}</span>

<span class="token comment">// Use this object as the key of another object</span>
<span class="token keyword">const</span> obj <span class="token operator">=</span> <span class="token punctuation">{</span>
  <span class="token punctuation">[</span>objAsKey<span class="token punctuation">]</span><span class="token operator">:</span> <span class="token string">'What will happen?'</span><span class="token punctuation">,</span>
<span class="token punctuation">}</span></code></pre></div>
<p>This will yield the following:</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="terminal"><pre class="language-terminal"><code class="language-terminal">{[object Object]: &quot;What will happen?&quot;}</code></pre></div>
<p>This is not the case with Map. Try creating an Object and setting it as the key of a Map:</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="js"><pre class="language-js"><code class="language-js"><span class="token comment">// Create an object</span>
<span class="token keyword">const</span> objAsKey <span class="token operator">=</span> <span class="token punctuation">{</span> foo<span class="token operator">:</span> <span class="token string">'bar'</span> <span class="token punctuation">}</span>

<span class="token keyword">const</span> map <span class="token operator">=</span> <span class="token keyword">new</span> <span class="token class-name">Map</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span>

<span class="token comment">// Set this object as the key of a Map</span>
map<span class="token punctuation">.</span><span class="token function">set</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span>objAsKey<span class="token punctuation">,</span> <span class="token string">'What will happen?'</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span></code></pre></div>
<p>The <code class="language-text">key</code> of the Map element is now the object we created.</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="terminal"><pre class="language-terminal"><code class="language-terminal">key: {foo: &quot;bar&quot;}
value: &quot;What will happen?&quot;</code></pre></div>
<p>There is one important thing to note about using an Object or Array as a key: the Map is using the reference to the Object to compare equality, not the literal value of the Object. In JavaScript <code class="language-text">{} === {}</code> returns <code class="language-text">false</code>, because the two Objects are not the same two Objects, despite having the same (empty) value.</p>
<p>That means that adding two unique Objects with the same value will create a Map with two entries:</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="js"><pre class="language-js"><code class="language-js"><span class="token comment">// Add two unique but similar objects as keys to a Map</span>
map<span class="token punctuation">.</span><span class="token function">set</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token punctuation">{</span><span class="token punctuation">}</span><span class="token punctuation">,</span> <span class="token string">'One'</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span>
map<span class="token punctuation">.</span><span class="token function">set</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token punctuation">{</span><span class="token punctuation">}</span><span class="token punctuation">,</span> <span class="token string">'Two'</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span></code></pre></div>
<p>This will yield the following:</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="terminal"><pre class="language-terminal"><code class="language-terminal">Map(2) {{…} =&gt; &quot;One&quot;, {…} =&gt; &quot;Two&quot;}</code></pre></div>
<p>But using the same Object reference twice will create a Map with one entry.</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="js"><pre class="language-js"><code class="language-js"><span class="token comment">// Add the same exact object twice as keys to a Map</span>
<span class="token keyword">const</span> obj <span class="token operator">=</span> <span class="token punctuation">{</span><span class="token punctuation">}</span>

map<span class="token punctuation">.</span><span class="token function">set</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span>obj<span class="token punctuation">,</span> <span class="token string">'One'</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span>
map<span class="token punctuation">.</span><span class="token function">set</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span>obj<span class="token punctuation">,</span> <span class="token string">'Two'</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span></code></pre></div>
<p>Which will result in the following:</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="terminal"><pre class="language-terminal"><code class="language-terminal">Map(1) {{…} =&gt; &quot;Two&quot;}</code></pre></div>
<p>The second <code class="language-text">set()</code> is updating the same exact key as the first, so we end up with a Map that only has one value.</p>
<h3 id="getting-and-deleting-items-from-a-map" style="position:relative;"><a href="#getting-and-deleting-items-from-a-map" aria-label="getting and deleting items from a map permalink" class="anchor before"><svg aria-hidden="true" focusable="false" height="16" version="1.1" viewBox="0 0 16 16" width="16"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z"></path></svg></a>Getting and Deleting Items from a Map</h3>
<p>One of the disadvantages of working with Objects is that it can be difficult to enumerate them, or work with all the keys or values. The Map structure, by contrast, has a lot of built-in properties that make working with their elements more direct.</p>
<p>We can initialize a new Map to demonstrate the following methods and properties: <code class="language-text">delete()</code>, <code class="language-text">has()</code>, <code class="language-text">get()</code>, and <code class="language-text">size</code>.</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="js"><pre class="language-js"><code class="language-js"><span class="token comment">// Initialize a new Map</span>
<span class="token keyword">const</span> map <span class="token operator">=</span> <span class="token keyword">new</span> <span class="token class-name">Map</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token punctuation">[</span>
  <span class="token punctuation">[</span><span class="token string">'animal'</span><span class="token punctuation">,</span> <span class="token string">'otter'</span><span class="token punctuation">]</span><span class="token punctuation">,</span>
  <span class="token punctuation">[</span><span class="token string">'shape'</span><span class="token punctuation">,</span> <span class="token string">'triangle'</span><span class="token punctuation">]</span><span class="token punctuation">,</span>
  <span class="token punctuation">[</span><span class="token string">'city'</span><span class="token punctuation">,</span> <span class="token string">'New York'</span><span class="token punctuation">]</span><span class="token punctuation">,</span>
  <span class="token punctuation">[</span><span class="token string">'country'</span><span class="token punctuation">,</span> <span class="token string">'Bulgaria'</span><span class="token punctuation">]</span><span class="token punctuation">,</span>
<span class="token punctuation">]</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span></code></pre></div>
<p>Use the <code class="language-text">has()</code> method to check for the existence of an item in a map. <code class="language-text">has()</code> will return a Boolean.</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="js"><pre class="language-js"><code class="language-js"><span class="token comment">// Check if a key exists in a Map</span>
map<span class="token punctuation">.</span><span class="token function">has</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token string">'shark'</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span> <span class="token comment">// false</span>
map<span class="token punctuation">.</span><span class="token function">has</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token string">'country'</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span> <span class="token comment">// true</span></code></pre></div>
<p>Use the <code class="language-text">get()</code> method to retrieve a value by key.</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="js"><pre class="language-js"><code class="language-js"><span class="token comment">// Get an item from a Map</span>
map<span class="token punctuation">.</span><span class="token function">get</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token string">'animal'</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span> <span class="token comment">// "otter"</span></code></pre></div>
<p>One particular benefit Maps have over Objects is that you can find the size of the Map at any time, like you can with an Array. You can get the count of items in a Map with the <code class="language-text">size</code> property. This involves fewer steps than converting an Object to an Array to find the length.</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="js"><pre class="language-js"><code class="language-js"><span class="token comment">// Get the count of items in a Map</span>
map<span class="token punctuation">.</span>size <span class="token comment">// 4</span></code></pre></div>
<p>Use the <code class="language-text">delete()</code> method to remove an item from a Map by key. The method will return a Boolean—<code class="language-text">true</code> if an item existed and was deleted, and <code class="language-text">false</code> if it did not match any item.</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="js"><pre class="language-js"><code class="language-js"><span class="token comment">// Delete an item from a Map by key</span>
map<span class="token punctuation">.</span><span class="token function">delete</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token string">'city'</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span> <span class="token comment">// true</span></code></pre></div>
<p>This will result in the following Map:</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="terminal"><pre class="language-terminal"><code class="language-terminal">Map(3) {&quot;animal&quot; =&gt; &quot;otter&quot;, &quot;shape&quot; =&gt; &quot;triangle&quot;, &quot;country&quot; =&gt; &quot;Bulgaria&quot;}</code></pre></div>
<p>Finally, a Map can be cleared of all values with <code class="language-text">map.clear()</code>.</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="js"><pre class="language-js"><code class="language-js"><span class="token comment">// Empty a Map</span>
map<span class="token punctuation">.</span><span class="token function">clear</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span></code></pre></div>
<p>This will yield:</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="terminal"><pre class="language-terminal"><code class="language-terminal">Map(0) {}</code></pre></div>
<h3 id="keys-values-and-entries-for-maps" style="position:relative;"><a href="#keys-values-and-entries-for-maps" aria-label="keys values and entries for maps permalink" class="anchor before"><svg aria-hidden="true" focusable="false" height="16" version="1.1" viewBox="0 0 16 16" width="16"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z"></path></svg></a>Keys, Values, and Entries for Maps</h3>
<p>Objects can retrieve keys, values, and entries by using the properties of the <code class="language-text">Object</code> constructor. Maps, on the other hand, have prototype methods that allow us to get the keys, values, and entries of the Map instance directly.</p>
<p>The <code class="language-text">keys()</code>, <code class="language-text">values()</code>, and <code class="language-text">entries()</code> methods all return a <code class="language-text">MapIterator</code>, which is similar to an Array in that you can use <code class="language-text">for...of</code> to loop through the values.</p>
<p>Here is another example of a Map, which we can use to demonstrate these methods.</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="js"><pre class="language-js"><code class="language-js"><span class="token keyword">const</span> map <span class="token operator">=</span> <span class="token keyword">new</span> <span class="token class-name">Map</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token punctuation">[</span>
  <span class="token punctuation">[</span><span class="token number">1970</span><span class="token punctuation">,</span> <span class="token string">'bell bottoms'</span><span class="token punctuation">]</span><span class="token punctuation">,</span>
  <span class="token punctuation">[</span><span class="token number">1980</span><span class="token punctuation">,</span> <span class="token string">'leg warmers'</span><span class="token punctuation">]</span><span class="token punctuation">,</span>
  <span class="token punctuation">[</span><span class="token number">1990</span><span class="token punctuation">,</span> <span class="token string">'flannel'</span><span class="token punctuation">]</span><span class="token punctuation">,</span>
<span class="token punctuation">]</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span></code></pre></div>
<p>The <code class="language-text">keys()</code> method returns the keys:</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="js"><pre class="language-js"><code class="language-js">map<span class="token punctuation">.</span><span class="token function">keys</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span></code></pre></div>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="terminal"><pre class="language-terminal"><code class="language-terminal">MapIterator {1970, 1980, 1990}</code></pre></div>
<p>The <code class="language-text">values()</code> method returns the values:</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="js"><pre class="language-js"><code class="language-js">map<span class="token punctuation">.</span><span class="token function">values</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span></code></pre></div>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="terminal"><pre class="language-terminal"><code class="language-terminal">MapIterator {&quot;bell bottoms&quot;, &quot;leg warmers&quot;, &quot;flannel&quot;}</code></pre></div>
<p>The <code class="language-text">entries()</code> method returns an array of key/value pairs:</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="js"><pre class="language-js"><code class="language-js">map<span class="token punctuation">.</span><span class="token function">entries</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span></code></pre></div>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="terminal"><pre class="language-terminal"><code class="language-terminal">MapIterator {1970 =&gt; &quot;bell bottoms&quot;, 1980 =&gt; &quot;leg warmers&quot;, 1990 =&gt; &quot;flannel&quot;}</code></pre></div>
<h3 id="iteration-with-map" style="position:relative;"><a href="#iteration-with-map" aria-label="iteration with map permalink" class="anchor before"><svg aria-hidden="true" focusable="false" height="16" version="1.1" viewBox="0 0 16 16" width="16"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z"></path></svg></a>Iteration with Map</h3>
<p>Map has a built-in <code class="language-text">forEach</code> method, similar to an Array, for built-in iteration. However, there is a bit of a difference in what they iterate over. The callback of a Map's <code class="language-text">forEach</code> iterates through the <code class="language-text">value</code>, <code class="language-text">key</code>, and <code class="language-text">map</code> itself, while the Array version iterates through the <code class="language-text">item</code>, <code class="language-text">index</code>, and <code class="language-text">array</code> itself.</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="js"><pre class="language-js"><code class="language-js"><span class="token comment">// Map</span>
<span class="token class-name">Map</span><span class="token punctuation">.</span>prototype<span class="token punctuation">.</span><span class="token function">forEach</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span>value<span class="token punctuation">,</span> key<span class="token punctuation">,</span> map<span class="token punctuation">)</span> <span class="token operator">=</span> <span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span> <span class="token operator">=></span> <span class="token punctuation">{</span><span class="token punctuation">}</span>

<span class="token comment">// Array</span>
<span class="token class-name">Array</span><span class="token punctuation">.</span>prototype<span class="token punctuation">.</span><span class="token function">forEach</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span>item<span class="token punctuation">,</span> index<span class="token punctuation">,</span> array<span class="token punctuation">)</span> <span class="token operator">=</span> <span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span> <span class="token operator">=></span> <span class="token punctuation">{</span><span class="token punctuation">}</span></code></pre></div>
<p>This is a big advantage for Maps over Objects, as Objects need to be converted with <code class="language-text">keys()</code>, <code class="language-text">values()</code>, or <code class="language-text">entries()</code>, and there is not an simple way to retrieve the properties of an Object without converting it.</p>
<p>To demonstrate this, let's iterate through our Map and log the key/value pairs to the console:</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="js"><pre class="language-js"><code class="language-js"><span class="token comment">// Log the keys and values of the Map with forEach</span>
map<span class="token punctuation">.</span><span class="token function">forEach</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token parameter">value<span class="token punctuation">,</span> key</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span> <span class="token operator">=></span> <span class="token punctuation">{</span>
  console<span class="token punctuation">.</span><span class="token function">log</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token template-string"><span class="token template-punctuation string">`</span><span class="token interpolation"><span class="token interpolation-punctuation punctuation">${</span>key<span class="token interpolation-punctuation punctuation">}</span></span><span class="token string">: </span><span class="token interpolation"><span class="token interpolation-punctuation punctuation">${</span>value<span class="token interpolation-punctuation punctuation">}</span></span><span class="token template-punctuation string">`</span></span><span class="token punctuation">)</span>
<span class="token punctuation">}</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span></code></pre></div>
<p>This will give:</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="terminal"><pre class="language-terminal"><code class="language-terminal">1970: bell bottoms
1980: leg warmers
1990: flannel</code></pre></div>
<p>Since a <code class="language-text">for...of</code> loop iterates over iterables like Map and Array, we can get the exact same result by destructuring the array of Map items:</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="js"><pre class="language-js"><code class="language-js"><span class="token comment">// Destructure the key and value out of the Map item</span>
<span class="token keyword">for</span> <span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token keyword">const</span> <span class="token punctuation">[</span>key<span class="token punctuation">,</span> value<span class="token punctuation">]</span> <span class="token keyword">of</span> map<span class="token punctuation">)</span> <span class="token punctuation">{</span>
  <span class="token comment">// Log the keys and values of the Map with for...of</span>
