<h3 id="when-to-use-map" style="position:relative;"><a href="#when-to-use-map" aria-label="when to use map permalink" class="anchor before"><svg aria-hidden="true" focusable="false" height="16" version="1.1" viewBox="0 0 16 16" width="16"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z"></path></svg></a>When to Use Map</h3>
<p>Summing up, Maps are similar to Objects in that they hold key/value pairs, but Maps have several advantages over objects:</p>
<ul>
<li><strong>Size</strong> - Maps have a <code class="language-text">size</code> property, whereas Objects do not have a built-in way to retrieve their size.</li>
<li><strong>Iteration</strong> - Maps are directly iterable, whereas Objects are not.</li>
<li><strong>Flexibility</strong> - Maps can have any data type (primitive or Object) as the key to a value, while Objects can only have strings.</li>
<li><strong>Ordered</strong> - Maps retain their insertion order, whereas objects do not have a guaranteed order.</li>
</ul>
<p>Due to these factors, Maps are a powerful data structure to consider. However, Objects haves some important advantages as well:</p>
<ul>
<li><strong>JSON</strong> - Objects work flawlessly with <code class="language-text">JSON.parse()</code> and <code class="language-text">JSON.stringify()</code>, two essential functions for working with <a href="https://www.digitalocean.com/community/tutorials/how-to-work-with-json-in-javascript">JSON</a>, a common data format that many REST APIs deal with.</li>
<li><strong>Working with a single element</strong> - Working with a known value in an Object, you can access it directly with the key without the need to use a method, such as Map's <code class="language-text">get()</code>.</li>
</ul>
<p>This list will help you decide if a Map or Object is the right data structure for your use case.</p>
<h2 id="set" style="position:relative;"><a href="#set" aria-label="set permalink" class="anchor before"><svg aria-hidden="true" focusable="false" height="16" version="1.1" viewBox="0 0 16 16" width="16"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z"></path></svg></a>Set</h2>
<p>A Set is a collection of unique values. Unlike a Map, a Set is conceptually more similar to an Array than an Object, since it is a list of values and not key/value pairs. However, Set is not a replacement for Arrays, but rather a supplement for providing additional support for working with duplicated data.</p>
<p>You can initialize Sets with the <code class="language-text">new Set()</code> syntax.</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="js"><pre class="language-js"><code class="language-js"><span class="token keyword">const</span> set <span class="token operator">=</span> <span class="token keyword">new</span> <span class="token class-name">Set</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span></code></pre></div>
<p>This gives us an empty Set:</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="terminal"><pre class="language-terminal"><code class="language-terminal">Set(0) {}</code></pre></div>
<p>Items can be added to a Set with the <code class="language-text">add()</code> method. (This is not to be confused with the <code class="language-text">set()</code> method available to Map, although they are similar.)</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="js"><pre class="language-js"><code class="language-js"><span class="token comment">// Add items to a Set</span>
set<span class="token punctuation">.</span><span class="token function">add</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token string">'Beethoven'</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span>
set<span class="token punctuation">.</span><span class="token function">add</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token string">'Mozart'</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span>
set<span class="token punctuation">.</span><span class="token function">add</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token string">'Chopin'</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span></code></pre></div>
<p>Since Sets can only contain unique values, any attempt to add a value that already exists will be ignored.</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="js"><pre class="language-js"><code class="language-js">set<span class="token punctuation">.</span><span class="token function">add</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token string">'Chopin'</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span> <span class="token comment">// Set will still contain 3 unique values</span></code></pre></div>
<blockquote>
<p><strong>Note</strong>: The same equality comparison that applies to Map keys applies to Set items. Two objects that have the same value but do not share the same reference will not be considered equal.</p>
</blockquote>
<p>You can also initialize Sets with an Array of values. If there are duplicate values in the array, they will be removed from the Set.</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="js"><pre class="language-js"><code class="language-js"><span class="token comment">// Initialize a Set from an Array</span>
<span class="token keyword">const</span> set <span class="token operator">=</span> <span class="token keyword">new</span> <span class="token class-name">Set</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token punctuation">[</span><span class="token string">'Beethoven'</span><span class="token punctuation">,</span> <span class="token string">'Mozart'</span><span class="token punctuation">,</span> <span class="token string">'Chopin'</span><span class="token punctuation">,</span> <span class="token string">'Chopin'</span><span class="token punctuation">]</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span></code></pre></div>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="terminal"><pre class="language-terminal"><code class="language-terminal">Set(3) {&quot;Beethoven&quot;, &quot;Mozart&quot;, &quot;Chopin&quot;}</code></pre></div>
<p>Conversely, a Set can be converted into an Array with one line of code:</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="js"><pre class="language-js"><code class="language-js"><span class="token keyword">const</span> arr <span class="token operator">=</span> <span class="token punctuation">[</span><span class="token operator">...</span>set<span class="token punctuation">]</span></code></pre></div>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="terminal"><pre class="language-terminal"><code class="language-terminal">(3) [&quot;Beethoven&quot;, &quot;Mozart&quot;, &quot;Chopin&quot;]</code></pre></div>
<p>Set has many of the same methods and properties as Map, including <code class="language-text">delete()</code>, <code class="language-text">has()</code>, <code class="language-text">clear()</code>, and <code class="language-text">size</code>.</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="js"><pre class="language-js"><code class="language-js"><span class="token comment">// Delete an item</span>
set<span class="token punctuation">.</span><span class="token function">delete</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token string">'Beethoven'</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span> <span class="token comment">// true</span>

<span class="token comment">// Check for the existence of an item</span>
set<span class="token punctuation">.</span><span class="token function">has</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token string">'Beethoven'</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span> <span class="token comment">// false</span>

<span class="token comment">// Clear a Set</span>
set<span class="token punctuation">.</span><span class="token function">clear</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span>

<span class="token comment">// Check the size of a Set</span>
set<span class="token punctuation">.</span>size <span class="token comment">// 0</span></code></pre></div>
<p>Note that Set does not have a way to access a value by a key or index, like <code class="language-text">Map.get(key)</code> or <code class="language-text">arr[index]</code>.</p>
<h3 id="keys-values-and-entries-for-sets" style="position:relative;"><a href="#keys-values-and-entries-for-sets" aria-label="keys values and entries for sets permalink" class="anchor before"><svg aria-hidden="true" focusable="false" height="16" version="1.1" viewBox="0 0 16 16" width="16"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z"></path></svg></a>Keys, Values, and Entries for Sets</h3>
<p>Map and Set both have <code class="language-text">keys()</code>, <code class="language-text">values()</code>, and <code class="language-text">entries()</code> methods that return an Iterator. However, while each one of these methods have a distinct purpose in Map, Sets do not have keys, and therefore keys are an alias for values. This means that <code class="language-text">keys()</code> and <code class="language-text">values()</code> will both return the same Iterator, and <code class="language-text">entries()</code> will return the value twice. It makes the most sense to only use <code class="language-text">values()</code> with Set, as the other two methods exist for consistency and cross-compatibility with Map.</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="js"><pre class="language-js"><code class="language-js"><span class="token keyword">const</span> set <span class="token operator">=</span> <span class="token keyword">new</span> <span class="token class-name">Set</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token punctuation">[</span><span class="token number">1</span><span class="token punctuation">,</span> <span class="token number">2</span><span class="token punctuation">,</span> <span class="token number">3</span><span class="token punctuation">]</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span>
<span class="token comment">// Get the values of a set</span>
set<span class="token punctuation">.</span><span class="token function">values</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span></code></pre></div>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="terminal"><pre class="language-terminal"><code class="language-terminal">SetIterator {1, 2, 3}</code></pre></div>
<h3 id="iteration-with-set" style="position:relative;"><a href="#iteration-with-set" aria-label="iteration with set permalink" class="anchor before"><svg aria-hidden="true" focusable="false" height="16" version="1.1" viewBox="0 0 16 16" width="16"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z"></path></svg></a>Iteration with Set</h3>
<p>Like Map, Set has a built-in <code class="language-text">forEach()</code> method. Since Sets don't have keys, the first and second parameter of the <code class="language-text">forEach()</code> callback return the same value, so there is no use case for it outside of compatibility with Map. The parameters of <code class="language-text">forEach()</code> are <code class="language-text">(value, key, set)</code>.</p>
<p>Both <code class="language-text">forEach()</code> and <code class="language-text">for...of</code> can be used on Set. First, let's look at <code class="language-text">forEach()</code> iteration:</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="js"><pre class="language-js"><code class="language-js"><span class="token keyword">const</span> set <span class="token operator">=</span> <span class="token keyword">new</span> <span class="token class-name">Set</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token punctuation">[</span><span class="token string">'hi'</span><span class="token punctuation">,</span> <span class="token string">'hello'</span><span class="token punctuation">,</span> <span class="token string">'good day'</span><span class="token punctuation">]</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span>

<span class="token comment">// Iterate a Set with forEach</span>
set<span class="token punctuation">.</span><span class="token function">forEach</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token parameter">value</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span> <span class="token operator">=></span> console<span class="token punctuation">.</span><span class="token function">log</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span>value<span class="token punctuation">)</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span></code></pre></div>
<p>Then we can write the <code class="language-text">for...of</code> version:</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="js"><pre class="language-js"><code class="language-js"><span class="token comment">// Iterate a Set with for...of</span>
<span class="token keyword">for</span> <span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token keyword">const</span> value <span class="token keyword">of</span> set<span class="token punctuation">)</span> <span class="token punctuation">{</span>
  console<span class="token punctuation">.</span><span class="token function">log</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span>value<span class="token punctuation">)</span>
<span class="token punctuation">}</span></code></pre></div>
<p>Both of these strategies will yield the following:</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="terminal"><pre class="language-terminal"><code class="language-terminal">hi
hello
good day</code></pre></div>

<h3 id="when-to-use-set" style="position:relative;"><a href="#when-to-use-set" aria-label="when to use set permalink" class="anchor before"><svg aria-hidden="true" focusable="false" height="16" version="1.1" viewBox="0 0 16 16" width="16"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z"></path></svg></a>When to Use Set</h3>
<p>Set is a useful addition to your JavaScript toolkit, particularly for working with duplicate values in data.</p>
<p>In a single line, we can create a new Array without duplicate values from an Array that has duplicate values.</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="js"><pre class="language-js"><code class="language-js"><span class="token keyword">const</span> uniqueArray <span class="token operator">=</span> <span class="token punctuation">[</span><span class="token operator">...</span><span class="token keyword">new</span> <span class="token class-name">Set</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token punctuation">[</span><span class="token number">1</span><span class="token punctuation">,</span> <span class="token number">1</span><span class="token punctuation">,</span> <span class="token number">2</span><span class="token punctuation">,</span> <span class="token number">2</span><span class="token punctuation">,</span> <span class="token number">2</span><span class="token punctuation">,</span> <span class="token number">3</span><span class="token punctuation">]</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span><span class="token punctuation">]</span> <span class="token comment">// (3) [1, 2, 3]</span></code></pre></div>
<p>This will give:</p>
<div class="gatsby-highlight" data-language="terminal"><pre class="language-terminal"><code class="language-terminal">(3) [1, 2, 3]</code></pre></div>
<p>Set can be used for finding the union, intersection, and difference between two sets of data. However, Arrays have a significant advantage over Sets for additional manipulation of the data due to the <code class="language-text">sort()</code>, <code class="language-text">map()</code>, <code class="language-text">filter()</code>, and <code class="language-text">reduce()</code> methods, as well as direct compatibility with <code class="language-text">JSON</code> methods.</p>
<h2 id="conclusion" style="position:relative;"><a href="#conclusion" aria-label="conclusion permalink" class="anchor before"><svg aria-hidden="true" focusable="false" height="16" version="1.1" viewBox="0 0 16 16" width="16"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z"></path></svg></a>Conclusion</h2>
<p>In this article, you learned that a Map is a collection of ordered key/value pairs, and that a Set is a collection of unique values. Both of these data structures add additional capabilities to JavaScript and simplify common tasks such as finding the length of a key/value pair collection and removing duplicate items from a data set, respectively. On the other hand, Objects and Arrays have been traditionally used for data storage and manipulation in JavaScript, and have direct compatibility with JSON, which continues to make them the most essential data structures, especially for working with REST APIs. Maps and Sets are primarily useful as supporting data structures for Objects and Arrays.</p>
